description:
Warning: Cash only, be prepared! 

Delicious, authentic Vietnamese soup dishes (at the absolute least). We went here the other day after having it on our to-do list for a long time, and it we definitely should have visited sooner. Everything was fantastic. The kitchen is front and center when you walk in, giving you a great look into the work being done to prepare all the meals. It strongly reminded me of wandering into shops for a bit to eat in downtown Ho Chi Minh City. We got seated upstairs and quickly ordered Pho, Bun bo Hue, and Bun Rieu. It came out in 10-15 minutes, a totally reasonable time. 

Each of our dishes came with the appropriate greens to add in on separate plates per meal, like Asian basil, mint, bean sprouts, limes, and a couple other greens. The table was also super stocked with all the other toppings like fish sauce, Sriracha, chili paste, soy sauce, and more. Once everyone had dressed up their meal to their personal taste, it was go time! The bowls were all huge, even the Bun bo Hue that only came in one size. I had a ton of leftovers, so I ended up filling a big take-out cup with my leftovers and eating it later.

While Pho 2000 was cash only, it was an entirely reasonable amount of cash (unlike Swan Oyster Depot) and was definitely one of the cheapest restaurants we've eaten in.  Each of our meals was between $8.50 and $9.50, so even after tip the three of us ate for about 12 dollars a person. Amazing!

I'll definitely be coming back here for an authentic Vietnamese soup, and I hope to explore other portions of the menu too. 

Thanks Pho 2000!
author: John B.

description:
My place to go for Pho!! Been coming to this place over 8 years with my boyfriend! Why five stars because...
1) Pho soup is always on point! (FRESH)
2) Friendly staff
3)All the food is so good  
4) Owners are very nice ;)
author: Hoang L.

description:
Came by the other day for some Cha Gio Imperial rolls and it did not disappoint! Street parking is available and the restaurant is quite basic along with a scary crowd outside in the Tenderloin.

The imperial rolls are authentic and similar to those found in Vietnam! They are made using rice paper wrappers instead of the Chinese wonton wrapper! The inside is filled with ground pork, Vermicelli, a touch of black fungus and a touch of taro! A side of vermicelli is included too!

$7.8 for the imperial rolls after tax. Cash only!
author: Derek S.

description:
CA$H ONLY so go to the ATM before coming here. 

You have to come to Pho 2000 and get the bun rieu & bun bo hue, pho real. Whether you're sober or hungover, Pho 2000 will not disappoint. 

Located in the heart of the TL, Pho 2000 is right next to turtle tower. These two vietnamese restaurants are very different and I personally prefer Pho 2000. Not only is it cheaper, but also has more options (different options) and is a more wholesome experience (generous size, delicious broth). 

Most of the noodle soup comes in two sizes, and the larger size is only $1 more - why would you NOT get the larger size. Soup is flavorful but not overpowering. There are vegan and vegetarian options, so there will be something for everybody.
author: Dana Z.

description: I always kinda thought I didn't link bun rieu but pho 2000 had made me a believer. It's rich and tomatoey in a way that weirdly reminds me of spaghettiOs. But like in a good way. It's quite savory and if you add in a little chili crisp it really works. The small size is pretty large so I'd say go with that unless you're really really hungry.
author: Misha T.

description:
For what this is, I'm going to give them a five for their delicious vegan options at an incredibly reasonable price. So far, I've only had the vegan pho. It was flavorful and the veggies were cooked perfectly...I even had the option of noodle type. I picked wide rice noodles, yum! 

For two people, two pho's, and free tea, our bill was ONLY $17! Whattttttt? Yes, this exists in San Francisco!!!!!!! I'll definitely be back...
author: Christina M.

description:
Today we went to lunch around 10:30 am-11am on a Sunday and there was still plenty of space upstairs to eat lunch so there was no wait at all so we just went straight upstairs to a table. They quickly gave us cups and barely gave us time to look at the menu to decide what we wanted to eat. Luckily, I usually get the same, which is the #1 pho dac biet, combo, so I didn't mind them not giving us time to decide. However, when they came back with our orders, it looks like they've really started to get stingy. The amount of meat is a lot less than before. I mean, the previous time I came here for lunch it looked like they didn't give us much meat, but this time, it's very noticeable. The meat also looks like it's not as good quality as before as well. I posted a picture where you can clearly see a lot of fat on a slice of meat.

This place used to be my favorite pho place because they would give good quality of meat and the quantity was pretty good as well. However, as time has gone by, they've slowly raised prices, but the quality had gone down.

Would I come back? I'm gonna start trying to find a new pho. Unless this place gets better as it used to be, I might not be back...
author: Gilda W.

description:
when you want a bowl of Pho this place is a decent choice.
broth is good, decent size, pretty cheap.
I had a large bowl of # 2 (Pho with rare meat and beef balls).
I enjoyed my bowl and although that it was good, I had better someplace  else.
seating is communal, you will sit with strangers during busy times.
eat and go.
that's it.
author: Rudy H.

description:
I'm still on my hunt to find the best com thit/suong nuong in the city, but have to say Pho 2000 is pretty far up there. I was so glad they finally opened again after vacation, because I've heard a lot of good things from a friend about their pho. 

At first glance, the restaurant is very much a hole in the wall and may even appear dirty to some people. It's small, and traditionally Vietnamese in every way possible. There's also seating upstairs, but there's plenty of staff members who give great service!

Anyway, I ordered a com suong nuong bi cha that came with pork chops, shredded pork and the Vietnamese egg. The thing that surprised me was the extra soup they provided with the entree! I only see this usually in places in the Midwest but definitely is unheard of in SF. The soup was actually delicious and not pho broth like most usually provide but was a canh (Vietnamese soup) that came with cabbage and carrots. The meal was overall delicious and so incredibly affordable for around $10. I'll definitely be coming back to try other dishes and highly recommend this place!
author: My N.

description:
Pretty decent place for pho in the Tenderloin, but not amazing. For a pho restaurant, the service here was actually pretty good. 

The place is quite small and a little dirty. There's an upstairs and the space is quite crammed, but nothing that I wouldn't expect in the neighborhood.

The prices here are pretty good - you'd pay around $8 for a piping hot and giant bowl of noodles! Seriously, their small bowls are probably considered a large at other restaurants. It's a pretty good value if you're looking for something inexpensive and very filling.

On the other hand, my boyfriend wasn't a fan of the beef noodle soup, while I liked my pho ga. The broth was relatively good, and didn't feel like it had too much MSG which we liked. The spring rolls we got came in huge portions! 

Food comes relatively quick, and our waiter was quick to take our order and clear our plates out. I did notice that our small plates that came with the spring rolls were dirty, so we ended up not using them. If sanitation is a concern, I would think twice about coming here.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
I didn't think it was possible to find a place in SF that tasted like home, but the bun rieu here is the rieu deal.  When the bun rieu tastes like Momma's bun rieu, how can you not keep coming back?!

It's is my must get order every time I come and also my recommendation for anyone who wants to try a new Vietnamese noodle soup (other than the normal pho or bun bo hue that's more commonly served at many other Vietnamese restaurants)!  If you love tomato and crab, then you're in for a treat!  It's packed with flavor and soooo savory.  It comes with mint, bean sprouts, and jalapeños on the side too.  I ask for extra mint and cooked bean sprouts each time I come, but the waiter already knows my order when he sees me.  I think that means I've achieved regular status, right?!   Haha.

Anyways, I've also had the pho here and while it's one of the better phos I've had in the city, I'd still rather get the bun rieu.  It's hard to find a place that makes bun rieu as good as Pho 2000 (other than at home with Mom of course c; ).

Cash only & they have a stamp card if you come regularly!
author: Carena N.

description:
One of the bright spots within the Tenderloin District. While Pho is Pho, the customer service was attentive to my dining requests. The dining area alone (while small & compact) was decent. Would've been nice to sit upstairs, yet the Warriors-Rockets Western Conference Finals game was on downstairs. Either way, it was po pretty chill.

FYI, Pho 2000 accepts only cash. No plastic of any kind accepted here whatever, which can be a little inconvenient. Its 2018. Who carries cash on them nowadays?

Anyway, Pho 2000 is a good & inexpensive spot to stop by for either lunch or dinner. You can seriously have dinner for two under $25, which is unheard of in San Francisco.
author: Eric T.

description:
Excellent spot for pho. It's not the cleanest place to go, and I don't believe there is air conditioning, and the cutlery isn't sparkling clean, but the pho is solid. I usually go for the bun rieu (not really sure where else you can find a bowl as good as this one in the city) and once in a while I'll go for a regular pho. Imperial rolls are great here as well. 

Don't forget to stamp your frequent buyer card while you're here!
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Came here for a fast dinner (30 minutes) - it was excellent. I ordered the chicken photo with extra bean sprouts cooked. It came fast and hit the spot on a cold and windy day. 

The broth is pretty good. It's clean. (Sometimes the beef quality can be questionable at Vietnamese places so I went with chicken to play a bit safer). I like the jalapeño and basil accompaniment (will recommend using all of it). The only thing that I would like here is extra veggies that is not broccoli - if they have spinach or Shanghai bok Choy as additional veggies in this with a dash of chili oil, then the dish would be perfect.
author: Rebecca C.

description: This place may look shady but you cannot judge a book by its cover! I've had one of the best bowls of pho here. Their emperor rolls are delightful. Prices are affordable - $10 for a large bowl of pho. It's cash only!
author: Angela T.

description:
I love pho 2000. I love that you can get wide noodles. I much prefer the wide (Hanoi-style) rice noodles than the skinny ones. They're less chewy and smoother and less likely to clump up.

Broth is pretty good. It has a really strong initial flavor but there's not quite enough depth. Despite that, I'd definitely still say that it's one of the best pho places in the city for me. The beef brisket here is incredible--tender and flavorful. The rare beef is the run of the mill what you'd expect. So I'd suggest getting beef brisket and wide noodles. I also like beef balls so I always get those too. 

It's a pretty cramped place and when you dine service is a little lackluster because they're so flustered. But people are actually really nice. I came to get take out and they had my order all ready to go by the time I arrived (and despite my various requests they got everything right!) super generous with the greens as well. I definitely preferred eating in the comfort of my own home since as mentioned it's kinda cramped here. Would recommend doing that if you could just swing by and pick up.
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
I came here with my friends because we wanted to try a new restaurant to eat pho. Furthermore, my first impression of the place was that it was a bit cramped, dark, and dirty. But, I got over that feeling and ordered a Large #13 Pho-Ga/Chicken Pho and #J Beef Carpaccio w/ Lime.

I thought the broth was pretty flavorful and I personally like it when the broth has a relatively translucent color. The chicken didn't taste too special to me, but I enjoyed how soft the meat was. I think my only gripe is that the large bowl didn't really look like it's any more food from the regular size bowl. So I'd probably stick to the smaller bowl next time.

I thought the Beef Carpaccio was great. It was cut thinly and was a good compliment to the pho. Mixing it with the fish sauce & mint made it really delish.

They accept cash only. The pricing is pretty good and I appreciate how they're open till 8:30 pm on weekdays & weekends. They serve the food super fast too.
author: Victor L.

description:
Very solid Pho.  Good broth and the noodles are no clumped together like most pho restaurants.

Haven't tried the other dishes, but will definitely come back to try.
author: Hien D.

description:
This pho restaursnt is really close to the us passport office so I came here after dropping off my passport application. 

They are open early, and close early. There was a decent amount of customers for 10am in the morning.  I haven't had bun rieu in a long time, so decided to get the bun rieu here. The meatballs weren't quite as delicious as the ones my mom made, but at least the soup was pretty flavorful. 

Cash only, family owned and a great hole in the wall Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
The lower the health score rating, the more authentic and legit these restaurants are. But if you're that turned off, your loss. After a night of drinking the night before, my friend and I came here in search for some good ol' pho to heal us. At a little past 10am, there was no wait and quick service. We were given hot tea to start as we both ordered the Bun Bo Hue ($8.80).

The bowl of bun bo hue was humongous! The two of us could've easily shared one bowl, but we both had leftovers for dinner instead. I ain't complaining since this bowl of bun bo hue was so damn good. The leftovers was just as great later that night, by the way. The flavors were strong and packed with meat and pork blood (my fave!). For what it's worth, this is the best bun bo hue in the bay at such a cheap price too!

P.S. Note that it's CASH ONLY though!
author: Cindy Z.

description: Best Pho in town! Great value for the cost. They don't have alcohol and it's cash only, but it gives it that feel of an authentic place in Little Saigon.
author: Casey T.

description:
Good solid pho but not better than some other spots here in the city . Do the healthy code violations scare me? Not one bit...and it actually wasn't as bad as I thought based on the reviews. 

I got my usual large combo pho and put some hoisin sauce to add to the flavor. I enjoyed the taste on a cold/rainy SF day but it was not so good that I would make it a point to return hence the 3 star rating. 

Service was friendly and the place was full as well.

The world needs a SF Bay Area Pho Rankings...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 
Rod's Pho Rankings for SF Bay Area:
1 Ly's Vietnamese Cuisine
2 Turtle Tower
3 Rang Dong Restaurant
4 Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant
5 Pho Huynh Hiep 2 - Kevin's Noodle House
6 Mai's Kitchen
7 Noodles Pho Me
8 Chopsticks Pho & Grill
9 Pho VN Vietnamese Restaruant
10 Pho 2000
11 Pho Vi Hoa
12 Bistro Viet House
13 Pho Ty II
14 Pho Pasteur
15 Kim Huong
16 Pho 99
author: Rod M.

description: The shrimp and pork rolls weren't great, but the special combination pho was very good.  Thought their pho broth was unique in that it was very heavy on clove flavors.  A matter of preference, but I liked it.  Service was fast, and we were in and out in 45 minutes.
author: Simon L.

description:
Don't let the location deter you! Located in Little Saigon in the Tenderloin, there's lots of Vietnamese restaurants to choose from. While the area may be considered dangerous and full of homeless people, I urge you to give it a shot. 

Know that you'll be going for the food and not for atmosphere. The inside is nothing to rave about, but it's clean. I ordered pho, and it's so cheap! A small will be $7.80 and a large is $8.80. Similar to another review, the large is way bigger than I expected. Portion sizes are definitely generous. The broth sided more towards a cinnamon flavor. However, it still had good taste. 

So, if you want cheap Vietnamese food and huge portions, give this place a shot! As said before, don't let the location prevent you from missing this place.
author: Brandon S.

description: This pho spot is pho-king delicious! Came here from Portland and needed some soup in my life after a long weekend, ordered the Pho Dac Biet (small) - I was surprised when it came because it looked like a large to me, when they confirmed that it was a small I was very happy and relieved I didn't get the large I had intended on getting. I always like to taste the broth first before I put on any additional sauces (Hoisin, sriracha, chili oil, pepper, etc) so that I know what I need more of but the broth had so much flavor and I was really surprised at how much flavor it had (it wasn't greasy like most places) I would have given them 5 stars but this place was cash only and my husband had to walk across the street to an atm. Next Time I come to SF and need a Pho fix I will def come here again.
author: Starla U.

description:
Staring this review saying I am not a pho expert by any means. That said, I thought the pho here was really good. I got brisket and meatballs. The broth was very flavorful. 

It's a very small place so you share tables but that didn't bother me. Also, cash only!
author: Nakita H.

description:
Health standards in question? Sold. Honestly the place didn't look amazingly clean to me, but hole in the wall and the food was legit? I got no complaints. I've eaten at tons of places in other countries in significantly worse condition, and don't get sick, but buyer beware I guess. 

Pho is off the chain. Got the chicken pho and shrimp rolls, and everything was tasty. Had to add a lot of spice to the pho but that's generally how It goes for me so I got no issues. Come here, spend minimal money, and be happy.

Pros:
Pho
Shrimp rolls
Ambiance
Price

Cons:
Cleanliness
Service - hella slow. If you're in a time crunch just go to the cashier and pay
author: Vyshak C.

description: The only pho spot I'll go to when I'm in town. They have the fish sauce and chili oil that I need when eating pho. Pho spots in Chinatown don't have that for some odd reason. The pho here always hits the spot for me! I'll be back for sure!
author: Victoria C.

description:
My friend and I came across this area after a day of waking around doing touristy things.  We saw a large group waking in so we decided to give it a try especially with the food yelp reviews.  

Once we sat down we were concerned about the health safety warning that was posted on yelp,  but honestly I have used to pho places having issues and we were really hungry. The place seemed older and a bit dirty. 

My friend and I ordered pho #2 and #12 small bowl. They were similar with rare beef but I had beef balls and she had steak. They came out in less than 10 minutes and the portions were a decent size for a small. I really liked that the broth wasn't greasy but flavorful. They  gave the fixings on the side that you can three in as well. This was pretty good and I would definitely try them again.
author: Michele S.

description:
Good, but honestly not great. I was expecting more from a place that many touted as the 'best pho restaurant in San Francisco'.

Prices are decent, broth is decent, the meat in my bowl at least was very fatty, and the noodles were a little too clumpy. Overall, I'd probably be back if I was in the area and craving pho: otherwise, I'd skip it and head over to Japantown for some ramen.
author: Hannah H.

description: Been here a couple times when we needed our pho fix. It's cash only but the place is decently clean, quick and delicious. I've tried their combo pho and their bun reiu. Both were really goods. I super like their bun reiu though. I love all things tomato and they make it really good here. They don't offer the special fish paste you can put in there though. My bf usually gets a rice dish, which he likes. And we've had their spring rolls and the make your own egg rolls (with the lettuce, egg rolls, noodles, herbs, etc). Everything we've had has been pretty good.
author: Alison W.

description: I ordered No. 20. The beef was really well flavored and tender which was really good! The noodles with the sweet sour sauce was a bit light, therefore only 4-stars. But in overall not bad :)
author: Yiwen W.

description:
I eat in some sketchy spots. 

But a health inspection of 68 with 0 willingness to improve is not ok. 

7 health violations in 2015, and none of them were fixed for their most recent routine (not unscheduled) inspection.

Not quite sure what to say. I ate here a few weeks ago. I was getting ready to write a good review with cute photos (let's be clear, the photos are still happening). 

A lesson for me to look beyond ambiance and glitter.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
How I wish there is a Pho2000 in NYC so I can go there every. single. day. 

I would say it's one of the best restaurant to order an bun rieu. If you don't know what a bun rieu  is, well SHAME ON YOU.... But to save you the hassle, it's a noodle soup with crab and shrimp paste, some ground pork, eggs in this DELICIOUS tomato soup. It's seriously the best I have around the city. Beside the bun rieu (which is what I usually come here for), the original beef pho is also very yummy. 

Side note: they offer stamp card (yes, STAMP CARD for those that dines there a lot), once you collect 10 bowls then you get one free! What a deal!
author: Stacey T.

description: What I love finding are pho places that actually carry amazing broth and many options on their menu. Found this gem while looking for a place to eat & honestly this one had the most reviews out of the other restaurants so I opted for this place. This restaurant is rather small, but it gets pretty busy. On a rainy Sunday morning, tables filled up quickly. I love it when a restaurant have options and this place has many options ranging from pho to bun rieu/bun bo hue to rice plates, and noodles. I always go for pho ga so #13 it was with the option of regular rice noodles or the thick wide rice noodle. I usually get regular so I chose the thick one this time. Their size small was pretty big to me with lots of chicken meat. The broth was really fragrant without it being too salty or over the top. This is a good place for pho and I'd definitely come back whenever I'm in the area!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Came here with le bf on a Saturday night around 7pm because we were craving pho, but some of the other places we were looking at had already closed. 

Oh, and I'm giving this place 3.5 stars rounded up to a 4, because this is a family business. 

Right when we walked in, you could immediately tell that this place was a family run business. Though all the tables were occupied on the ground floor, we were told to walk up stairs where there were open tables. It was also about 10-15 degrees hotter upstairs, and everybody who had worn a jacket outside, slowly took them off, the longer they sat upstairs.

We ordered:
1. Pork and shrimp (fresh) rolls
2. Imperial rolls
3. Small meatball and rare steak pho
4. Small rare steak and tripe pho

The pork and shrimp fresh rolls were the first things to come out. They came out rather quickly. You could tell they were just made, which was nice. There was plenty of dipping sauce.

The imperial rolls took some time. They probably arrived about 10-15 minutes after our fresh rolls came out. They were nice and crispy and served with some lettuce, pickled carrots, cucumber slices, vermicelli noodles, and plenty of fish sauce. We didn't end up finishing them, but they came out so hot and crispy. 

My pho was the rare steak and tripe pho (#9 on the menu). The noodles were a bit undercooked. There was plenty of rare steak, but not really any tripe. The pho broth was also underdeveloped. The depth of flavor wasn't there. It felt like it could have been cooked for a few more hours. It was pretty one dimensional, compared to other pho broths at other pho places. 

Le bf who ordered the meatball and rare steak also agrees with the pho broth being underdeveloped. He said that there was a ton of rare steak, compared to other pho places, but the broth was disappointing. 

Sitting upstairs meant that the service wasn't as good. If you wanted something, like a refill of water, you would either need to go downstairs to flag somebody down, or you would need to wait until somebody came upstairs (to deliver food to a table or to seat a party). I thought that was a bit annoying. I also noticed that food didn't come out in the same order in which orders were placed. For example, we ordered before another table, but because we ordered appetizers in addition to pho, our pho came well after the other table got their pho. We got our pho when they had finished their bowls of pho. There were many awkwardly long pauses between receiving the items we ordered. 

Though it was good to try need pho places in the city, I don't think that this place makes it onto our go-to pho places list. The appetizers were good, but the pho just wasn't good enough.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Wow, this place is bomb! 

Apparently Pho 2000 is still killing it in 2017. It's super authentic and affordable, too! I had never tried bun rieu before so I ordered it. Simply amazing! It was basically rice noodle in a rich crab and tomato broth. I got a small but man it was big enough for two meals for only 7 bucks. I couldn't even finish it and took about 1/3 back to my office. 

It's a no frills Viennese joint so don't expect anything fancy. Bring cash and be prepared to sit at communal tables. I'm totally coming back because this is the real deal!
author: Angela F. W.

description:
Pho 2000 had some nearby parking spaces across the street. there were cautionary towaway sign in front.of many parking spaces. reserved for PGE, it implied at the corner of the sign. since it was near noon on sunday and no work had started, i and others parked there.

Pho 2000 was getting filled up, 2nd tier also.
usual viet eats. went for the Bun Rieu. should be gone pho.

eats: Bun Rieu:(lg. 8,80)
-"crab paste, shrimp paste, chewy pork, tomato, pork loaf, bean sprout, egg, lime squeeze,'
jalapeno slices".
-nice tasty soup, just didn't authentic enough, red hue dominated more than crab paste.

take outs:
-service quick, kitchen is in front of eatery.
-only one bathroom, in use all the time.
-pho for sure next time.
author: Victor G.

description:
Just only a small size noodle bowl but it made me so full!!! It's one of the good Vietnamese resto in Tenderloin. The atmosphere is ok, i dont feel really pack and they have 2nd floor available. 

Price VS Portion = worth !
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
I tried bun rieu for the first time here and fell in love! The red soup is intimidating at first, but the broth isn't spicy at all. Bun rieu is a type of pho made with pork, crab paste, and tomatoes. I highly recommend it! The broth was light and the noodles were easy to eat. The small bowl was pretty big too. I didn't even finish all the noodles.

Most of my coworkers ordered the vermicelli with bbq pork and imperial rolls and liked it.

Be sure to get here earlier around lunch time, because it's a small restaurant and it fills up pretty fast.
author: Tara A.

description:
Probably the best pho restaurant in the area. Small place in the Tenderloin so it's not the best walk getting there, but the food is delicious.

I like to sit upstairs and sit on the edge. They sometimes get a little annoyed when I request to sit at a specific spot, though. 

Cash only.
author: Do P.

description:
Area is very bad! lots of homeless people around here...

Pho is a bit pricey, got the pho and spring rolls and came out to $18.
Tasted okay but they forgot my sauce for the spring rolls.
Don't come here alone...
author: James S.

description:
Am I thrilled that this place has health code violations? No. Did that stop me from trying it? Of course not. Admittedly, I wish this place was much cleaner, but out of sight out of mind right? Had the chicken pho and loved it. Loaded it up with a ton of spice and loved it even more. The portions are huge - split one with a friend and we still weren't able to finish. Check it out! 


Tips - cash only and closed on Tuesday's!
author: Chandani D.

description: My go to spot in the city. I frequently brace myself and trek through the tenderloin for this spot - it's that good. Their BBH, while not as pungent as other more traditional BBH, is delicious and huge and filled with tasty morsels of meat. Their rice plates are delicious and the pho is pretty top notch, filled with heavy umami. Chase it with a delicious iced coffee. Strongly recommend this place, especially for the value of what you get.
author: Robin Y.

description:
CASH ONLY.
My pho expert friends tell me this place is one of the best in the city.
Definitely a great place to come on a rainy day, when you're hungover, when you want food fast, when you want to eat your feelings (because what else are feelings good for, namsayin? jk), or just craving pho. Right next to the poppin Turtle Tower, but I think this place is way better.
author: Annie S.

description: Do you appreciate hole-in-the-wall restaurants? Or maybe mom and pop shop that have the taste of home? Need a pick me up? Well, this place is it. They are not a fancy place, but a place filled with comfort with smell of soups and noodles. I have to warn you, the location of Pho 2000 is not the best, but the food is worth the trip! I've tried many Pho places across the Bay area and this place definitely ranked at the top!
author: Jie L.

description: This place was good but there were a few downsides. I don't recommend walking here because it's in a bad neighborhood and it is cash only.
author: Emma A.

description: My coworker and I wanted to get some homey soup. Well at least I wanted to because I was dying from my hangover. Their pho Ga is really delicious! Very light and flavorful, if you want a little more flavor and don't mind the fatty oil, get the fatty oil added to it! Recommend it, and I am a big Pho fan. Love it! Will come back here!!
author: Ritney N.

description:
Searching for Pho turns up a list of restaurants that turned out to not speak English nor have pho. 3 blocks up and down the mountains, we finally find a place that serves my favorite all time  dish.

Pho 2000 has a very interesting layout, as you walk through the kitchen section to the seating area. It's like a brewery tour, where you see all the hardware before you get the sampling. Except there is no friendly guide, or pleasantries exchanged.

Anytime you see bowls the size of bath tub's, thats the sign for foodies to GTH out! No proud chef would waste their effort just to pour it on for volume. A practice reserved for the buffets and feeding carousel that is now becoming the signature of American food.

On my Combination pho, the broth is missing the smell of the dancing herb's, absent of the taste of essence in a collagen rich base. The included several different styles of meat has decent seasoning. Except the meatball, it's in between a thawed factory made filler, to a mushy bouncy Goodyear elasticity. Good for a K.O'ed boxer's rehab, or someone working on a higher clamping force to rival a gator.

Lesson learned, drive down to San Jose for Pho.
author: Tim J.

description: Real Vietnam pho! You can feel the smell upon opening the door. The special pho contains all the thing. Recommend the beef ball inside, juicy and fresh. The dry pho is also tasty. It has mint and a lot of veggie! Egg roll inside is my favorite, crispy but not oily! Really good place to enjoy the pho!
author: Mengrou L.

description: I'll bet all 10 of my Yelp Elite badges that this is one of the top 3, if not THE best, Pho place in San Francisco. I've tried a lot of pho places and been to Vietnam twice. Nothing is nearly as good here. Some places get close, but IMHO, this is the best. When you walk in, turn left and note the massive cauldron pot simmering with the day's broth. This broth takes HOURS to make and you can really tell. When your soup arrives, take a smell of the fragrant ingredients. You may smell a bit of star anise or the slightest hint of pepper. I love adding in the basil, sprouts, lime, etc into the broth, but at the same time, I always feel the slightest remorse because I am altering such a masterpiece broth. I almost always take the #1, small. It's enough for me, though I would finish a large too. The meat inside is way tender; the brisket almost falls apart before it enters my mouth. The tendon is super tender and the beef balls have the best peppery taste. If I could change one thing, it would be to get the citrus they serve up in Vietnam, you know, those little green things that are bright orange on the inside? They just don't survive the trip over to the States, so we'll have to suffice with lime. If you are dining with friend, compliment with the imperial rolls--never a bad time for those. If you are solo, they will sell you one for $3, sans the lettuce. Can't wait to return.
author: Brian J.

description:
Ok, while not the cleanest restaurant I've ever seen, this place has quite possibly the best Pho in the city. Ingredients are always super fresh and the Imperial roles are LEGIT. 

Note for vegetarians - I brought my dad here, a vegetarian of 30 years. He was concerned that the veg pho wouldn't be completely meat free but it was. The broth was beautiful and full of fresh vegetables. My dad added some Hoisin and chili's and he was in heaven.
author: Tracey L.

description:
Pho 2000 is more of an ironic pho shop than a self-ironic pho shop, one that's Y2Good. They're not millenium-themed but born from the days when 2000 seemed like the hopeful future that didn't already pass.

Their Pho Chay lives up to that hopeful future 17 years ago, lol. I got a big bowl of this veggie pho with the vegan broth and it didn't disappoint. Their large size for a dollar extra is very large and filling. The large bowl looks almost unconquerable at first glance but comes with a lot of broth and enough noodles, vegetables, lime, basil and chilies to keep the soup unboring.

The way they organize people for seating is like human tetris. Since I don't have friends anymore in San Francisco, I ate by myself and was seated on table for four downstairs that needed bussing. When they sat me downstairs, I lept up upstairs and saw the entire upstairs was empty. They then sat two more guys on the same table as me that turned into our tiny communal table. I get why they do it, but it was only like 4pm. 

It didn't matter as I was desperately hungry. I didn't want to move around much after going upstairs as my energy was depleted. I was staying at a dig nearby in the Tenderloin and it was delicious and inexpensive for San Francisco standards, including the burgeoning rise of boutique restaurants on Larkin.
author: Chris G.

description: Quick and tasty not to mention cheap! I came here when I was sick and NEEDED chicken pho. I actually had gone to another Pho around the corner but upon walking in I had noticed the tables hadn't been picked up, dishes all over, the lady didn't acknowledge I had sat down so I walked out and walked to Pho 2000. Got my pho in mins!
author: Sandy P.

description:
Not the cleanest place, but I still give 5 stars for their pho. Fresh ingredients, authentic broth, and succulent rare beef slices. I come here very regularly and their pho has never disappointed me. I also recommend vegetarian roll if you want a light appetizer.

Cash only.
author: J R.

description:
Go-to pho place in the city. Always. The meat is actually good. Like it's not just filler meat that you actually want to spit out or chew hesitantly not knowing if it's gonna give you food poisoning or not. I've been more times than I can count but every time I'm still shocked at how good the meat actually is... 

Don't be the person at the table next to me who asked the waiter if they had gluten free soy sauce. They don't.
author: Nicole L.

description: best pho place i've tried in san francisco. not sure why it took me so long to get here - but it's in a not great part of town - however, across from the chairman!  we got the pork & shrimp spring rolls to share - those were fantastic - and they even give you enough peanut sauce! yummm. i got the no. 11 - large for $1 or so more - and worth it! the broth is flavorful yet light, noodles were nicely done, and the toppings were great. low health score but i felt pretty clean even after drinking all the broth. would come back in a heartbeat!
author: Christina L.

description:
One of the better Pho places in Larkin. They have lots of seating, including upstairs.

The noodles for the pho were great and the broth was not filled with MSG. Service is really good here and the price isn't too bad for being in SF.

Came here for lunch on Saturday and the place still had a lot of seating available.

I have nothing to complain about this place...except the bun bo hue. The bun bo hue had really good noodles but the broth didn't have that spicy kick that I enjoy.

I'd stick with the pho if I come here!
author: Sang P.

description:
My 2nd favorite bowl of Pho in Little Saigon (with Bodega Bistro being my 1st).  But well ahead of the many other joints I tried.  They hit the mark in all the important categories: broth complexity, meat quality and noodle-to-broth ratio.  Also, it's quite inexpensive.  But it's no secret, so get there early or face a big lunch line.

Pho Bo: I'm pretty consistent with my pho ordering, so I have a really good benchmark to compare against.  My ideal Pho Bo squad consists of Rare Steak, Brisket, Flank and Meatball.  I'm just not into the chewy/gelatinous textures of tendon and tripe.  Anyway, I've been eating in Little Saigon a lot lately since the cloudy/rainy weather has been perfect for pho.  I was really impressed by the bowl here.  Complex and savory broth.  Ample amounts of meat and, most importantly, good cuts.  Some fat, but not overwhelming so you don't feel like they're just giving you a bunch of cheap cuts.  The perfect amount of noodles in my opinion, leaving tons of room for broth.
author: Adam B.

description: Definitely one of the best pho restaurants in the city, and a great bang for your buck at that! You can get a massive bowl of pho for just $8 bucks, one that was enough for lunch and leftovers. This place is definitely not glamorous, so don't come here if you are looking for an upscale place. It is definitely authentic though, with awesome broth, all types of wet and dry pho, and rice dishes as well. Come here if you are not looking to impress anyone except for your stomach.
author: Ross S.

description: I'm from Los Angeles and I haven't been impressed with most of the Pho or Ramen places here. For me, it's all about the broth and this place is excellent! I had the pork soup with noodles  Amazing broth and I loved that the soup has fresh tomatoes in it and I could taste the onions! Great Flavor. I'm a very quiet person when I go out and the servers here don't mind just serving me and letting me be. Overall, I would say this place is still probably family owned and very authentic. The woman cooking the food is an Amazing Chef ‍ I would recommend this location.
author: Sean V.

description: The bun rieu was ok... the pho was not that good... not much flavor in the bun rieu which is crab paste noodle...
author: Michael P.

description:
One of the many Pho places on Larkin. Inside is a bit dark, with some yellow walls to kind of offset it. There is no outdoor seating, although there is a upstairs that has more seating. The kitchen is right in front of the restaurant if you want to see what their cooking. 

I usually get the combination Pho. The large size is definitely large and will fill you up if you come hungry. There is plenty of meat and noodles, and the broth is definitely solid. I also recommend getting the Vermicelli as it is also very solid here as well.

The service here is good and they serve the food in a fast, timely manner. I definitely recommend this spot when if you're looking for something that is not Pho Ga (go to turtle tower for that) and not looking to break the bank.
author: Jason P.

description:
I've been eating here for years now, and the food has always been delicious! I've been meaning to write a review for this place, but I finally gotten a chance to. 

My go to is Bun Bo Hue, and I add their in house chili into it. They are not cheap and stingy with meat! Hate going to places where they give you 4 pieces of meat per bowl of pho. 

Service is also great here, especially for a mom and pop shop. Came here today during rush hour, witness the servers dealing with entitled customers with complicated orders is definitely worthy of a round of applause. I used to work in the restaurant industry, and it takes a lot of patience to deal with assholes like that. So if you are an entitled and complicated customer where it is always me me me, they will take care of yo ass. However, word of advice, don't be that asshole. 

Overall, it is a 5 Star on everything here! The only negative is this restaurant only accepts cash; not worth of deducting a star from that.
author: Zihao Y.

description:
The ONLY place i get pho in SF! Been eating here the last 3 years since i move into the city. And i gotta say this place (although cash only) is the best pho i ever had in my life. 
So worth the walk to an atm machine to eat at this gem.
author: Justin S.

description:
Tastes nasty. I ordered the bbq pork with egg roll over rice. The bbq pork is not freshly grilled and I could instantly tell as I bit into the meat. It wasn't steaming hot and some parts of the meat where not warm. It seems like they got the meat and microwaved it. The egg roll was freshly grilled and
I did enjoy that. No thanks, I rather head on to turtle towers next door their food is freshly grilled so you don't have to worry about getting microwaved meat. This place is cash only.
author: Russell T.

description:
A big fan of Pho, I was excited to see what Pho 2000 had to offer in the streets of Little Saigon. 

Inside, you get your typical casual Vietnamese restaurant setup. They have cheap tables and chairs, and the place isn't that clean (the bathroom was a disaster), but at least the service was good. They are constantly running around, and really gave off the impression that they were working their hardest to keep their busy restaurant running. 

I really enjoyed my pho. It wasn't the best I've ever had, but the soup was well-flavored, noodles were made right, the all the extra meats they usually include were awesome. I thought the soup was a little bit on the lighter side, but that could be good depending what your taste buds are like; I like spicy and more flavorful things so this soup wasn't the best for me. Still, it wasn't a bad soup though, and the quick service made it a nice experience.
author: Michael Y.

description:
This place is by far the best Vietnamese restaurant experience I've had in San Francisco.  The quality of their soup base for pho is excellent, and does not leave you quenched for thirst the entire rest of the day.  

Items I highly recommend:
- deep fried spring rolls (use the lettuce to wrap the spring rolls)
- mixed beef pho bowl (you can choose the size you want)
author: Colette C.

description:
Pho isn't authentic unless it has a number in it [Ali Wong reference]. This is the new advice I live on when I'm finding pho places, and Ali Wong's advice is spot on. I'm actually not a huge rice noodle fan so I don't normally seek out pho (Gasp!) when I'm hungover or craving noodles, but Pho 2000 was some of the best pho I've ever had. It's in a rather unassuming spot right in the tenderloin, but it's definitely worth the trip out. 4/5 stars only because I decided to walk to the restaurant and the journey there was a bit terrifying (it was right up through 6th street). 

[Pho]
I tried the Spring rolls and #4 Pho. The prices are very very reasonable! I got the regular size bowl for around ~$7 with tax, and it was A LOT of food. The meat was well cooked and the broth was very flavorful and so tasty! It was also great that my mouth wasn't super dry after I had the pho, meaning that there isn't as much MSG used in the food here. The spring rolls were also very fresh and I would recommend trying them. Pho 2000 really won me over even though I'm not a pho lover..

If you're looking for your hangover cure or are just craving great pho, Pho 2000 really does the job. Thanks for the advice Ali Wong!
author: Alice Z.

description:
Me: What would you rate Pho 2000 on a scale of one-to-five?
Roommate: I'd give it a five.
Me: I'm thinking a three or four.
Roommate: What?? Their pho is really good!
Me: Yeah, but their spring rolls aren't. Also, people on Yelp are complaining about the cleanliness.
Roommate: That's what gives it extra flavor!
Me: TRUUUU.

TL;DR: Pho is good. Apps are okay. No frills, cash only joint. Lack of cleanliness (allegedly) adds to the flavor.
author: Trevor M.

description:
A no frill pho eatery, probably one of the better ones.
Sure it's in a somewhat shady area but you got decent bang for your buck.
The size of the bun noodle was huge, I could totally dunk my whole face in there. Not so much meat topping, but a lot of noodle! However, the roast pork and the egg rolls topping were quite yummy (especially the combination of glass noodle and chopped vegetables inside the egg rolls).
#15 Bun rie was interesting (noodle soup with crab and shrimp paste, etc). It got a slight sourness that can be refreshing even during summer. 
I didn't feel too thirsty upon leaving, so I am guessing they don't pour a whole bowl of msg in their broth; which is a great thing.
Cash only!
author: Jenny T.

description: I thought this place was very good and pretty big as well. The pho broth was tasty and egg rolls were yummy.
author: Tina L.

description: Been coming here since it opened. This is the best pho in the city in my opinion. Good flavor, price and consistency.
author: Neill T.

description:
I've been to a ton of Vietnamese restaurants this one kind of just blends into the more lack luster of the mediocre. 
Don't get me wrong, the pho was pretty good, but I've had better. Especially considering that this place is just one of the many Vietnamese restaurants in the area. 
There are too many other places for me to feel inclined to revisit this spot.

And no fish cake!? Coooome ooon!

Ps. Also it is cash only
author: Cal J.

description: Came here on a Wednesday afternoon. Ordered special combo pho, a seafood pho, and a Thai tea. Both pho's tasted fine. The seafood in the pho didn't taste very fresh, but the broth was really good. The broth for the special combo pho tasted a bit too cinnamon-y. Thai tea was a bit watered down. However, rices were cheap and food came quickly. Service was nice too.
author: Annie C.

description:
A pho restaurant that has so much more to offer!

Classic Little Saigon Hole-in-the-wall restaurant that offers multiple pages of authentic and comforting Vietnamese food.
This is my go-to on a rainy day. When I have a small sniffle. When I'm hungry but still want to eat light. And ESPECIALLY when I don't have to dance that night and can loosen the belt buckle a little bit.

Sit down, order a "small" bowl of pho and a few minutes later a bowl that can be mistaken as large is brought out. Top with all your favorite garnishes and herbs and dig in!

Although most people here eat the beef pho (Kyle H. claims it's the best he's ever had..except maybe my mom's), I eat the Veggie pho. The broth is very light, but I just love how loaded with veggies it is! Broccoli, carrots, tofu, zucchini, onions, etc. Once I load up my bowl with mint, cilantro, bean sprouts, and jalapenos, I have an overflowing bowl of soupy goodness.

When I finish the entire bowl, I am thoroughly stuffed, but not bloated. I feel great!

Other vegetarian offerings include:

Banh Xeo Chay (Vietnamese Yellow Crepe)-Really good and oversized!
Goi Cuon Chay (Vietnamese Rolls)
Cha Gio Chay (Veggie Egg Rolls)
Bun Chay (Vermicelli Noodles with Tofu)
Various Vegetable & Rice Dishes

So even if you're not in the mood or a fan of pho (these people exist??), there are things you can eat while your friends gorge on oversized bowls of noodles and broth.

Oh, and like a true small sized Vietnamese gem, this place is easy on the wallet! Less than $10 for most items!
author: Lanie L.

description:
Price is good, but it is far from my office. Overall the bun bo hue was tasty, but there was a few issues. I felt it is be a little oilier that most broths, the broth was heavier and not as clean as other Bun Bo Hue and the onions were not soaked (bitter onion flavor).

It had the standard meats: brisket, blood cub and pork cake, but it did not tendon or pork shoulder, which I LOVE. I think the Pho is better the Bun Bo Hue, as the flavor was a nice clean beefiness.

The price and how fast the togo order makes me go back and order the pho, not the bun bo hue.
author: Mei L.

description:
Great PHO spot in the Tenderloin.

Staff is clean, quick and friendly. The menu is HUGE and has so many options (meat and vegetarian or seafood)! They also have other great entrees than just PHO.

We ordered: 
- Seafood Pho w/ wide noodles (small size portion was BIG for me. I couldn't finish it).
- Imperial Rolls (veggie) - delish but a bit greasy.
- Shrimp Chow mein - huge portion a teency weency bit salty.
- Vietnamese iced coffee, SUPER STRONG and delish
- Thai iced tea.

The ONLY reason I'm giving this restaurant 4 instead of 5 is because it's CASH ONLY. Which was a super bummer since we didn't realize until we were done with our meal and my husband had to go leave to find an ATM. I just feel with technology these days and living in a big city, you HAVE to HAVE a card option - even square or something! 

Other than that, I'd definitely come back :)
author: Anastacia W.

description: I've eaten here a couple of times this winter. I've usually eaten around 430-5pm so there isn't a wait. It's cheap, it's good and in this ghetto hood. I wouldn't want to venture here myself but I was with someone that had eaten here a few times and knows the area. I think the best thing I had here wasn't the pho or bum rieu but the imperial rolls! Highly recommend ordering that if you're ever in this part of town.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Pho and Congee are the go to meal choices whenever I'm sick. I ordered the Pho House Special, small. I was definitely tempted to upsize to a large for only $1 more, but having have done this too many times previously and knowing a large pho would push me past nirvana and into the state of having to loosen a belt buckle, I mustered the willpower to stick with the small. The small turned out to be a pretty substantial amount of food, I walked out feeling blissfully comfortable. 

Now about that pho: 

Broth - Fatty. When my spoon slipped into the oily abyss, it resurfaced with a viscous new coat that demanded multiple tissues for clean up. 

Noodles - Al dente perfection. I love noodles with a bit of spring in the chew. These rice noodles were prepared just perfectly. No soggy noodles here!

Meat - Mixed fattiness. House special is always fun to get because it's a mix of meats, tendons and balls. In this case, it was a mix of fatty beef, fatty beef and a little bit of tripe. Not sure where the balls went. 

Overall service was quick and each table is given a personal tea pot, so not qualms about water service. 

After I make my rounds through the tenderloin pho houses I'd likely come back again but next time making a request to see if the oil in the broth can be skimmed off and also for some leaner cuts of meat. 

P.S Bring cash.
author: Janice K.

description: Food is delicious here. Very tasty and they serve it quick. It's good when you're in a rush since it comes out quick. They also have stamp cards, so if you are a frequent customer, remember to ask for one !
author: K. O.

description:
Hole in the wall Vietnamese food, but very delicious! 

We ordered the fried imperial rolls, bun bo hue, and pho bo. All of our items tasted great, but there was a lot of msg in my soup. 

Location is not in the safest part of town, so be aware coming here. 

Nonetheless, pho is always a great idea!
author: Claire W.

description:
I was craving Vietnamese food after an administrative nightmare at Kaiser, so I picked my study bug up at the Main Library and wandered in for some good eats. 

He "wasn't hungry" so we ordered an order of Imperial rolls and a large #1 pho. The Imperial rolls came with lots of vegetation and fish sauce and were fried to perfection! I thought I had had them before, but the crispy skin was not the smooth kind on spring rolls I expected. We shared the generous portion of pho; the broth was sweeter than most, but still very tasty.

I enjoyed the open kitchen up front and how light and airy the restaurant is. The tea is very strong and tasted even better with a mint sprig from our Imperial roll garnishes. Service was very efficient and it was the first time I had ever had the server wait until we finished our appetizers before bringing the entree!

At about $10pp this is definitely a return destination when I'm in the area!
author: Angela L.

description:
Disgustingly good. If you're expecting a clean restaurant with superb customer service, please look elsewhere.

If you're looking for legit and cheap pho - come check out Pho 2000, which is rooted at the heart of San Francisco's beloved Tenderloin district. 

I've been here about 5+ times and have never been disappointed. I'd order their Beef Combination Special or Seafood Pho, which is generally under $10 after top and taxes. If you're super hungry, upgrade the size. You can either choose you're traditional thin noodles, or customize it with wide noodles.

Huge portions. Flavorful broth. I can eat this every week. 

Overall, I'm happy this place exists. On weekends, its relatively popping. During weekdays during lunch, there could be a long wait, so plan accordingly.

Oh and they are a "Cash Only" place!
author: Chinsin S.

description: I try to come here every Sunday for Pho, it's that good. I've eaten at hundreds of Pho restaurants over the years and this place is my favorite. Wait staff are great, but the Pho is incredible. Never had a bad meal here. Cash only, but don't worry it's priced modestly.
author: shawn p.

description: Yes they have very good pho there I've eaten there many many times and always satisfied. I very much would recommend it to anybody who feel like eating Vietnamese food. Parking is kind of bad though unless you're lucky, enjoy!!
author: Pete L.

description: Linda the owner and cook rocks. Great prices and great people. Family owned.
author: Bombiz V.

description: My to go place for pho!!! I work only a few blocks away and sometimes come here for lunch.  the soup in the pho taste so much better than a lot of other vietnamese restaurants.  definitely recommended!!!
author: Ben Z.

description:
Definitely one of my top pho places but they're not perfect.(but who is?)

Come here for quick services, somewhat clean environment, variety in menu, hot piping and delicious broth. But don't come here if you're expecting a spacious pho restaurant where the service is top notch, or if you only have a credit card (cash only). (Which is like any other normal asian restaurant.) I been here a couple of times already, and each time I was not disappointed in the broth. The pho here is good, flavorful and you can tell that their broth has been infused with delicious beef bones and fat for hours. I honestly don't even know why, but this place has also been the only pho places where they gave me way more meat than noodles. (Like seriously, it threw me off so much that I basically ended up just eating meat at the end..)

Also, I love the 'no bulltsh*t' attitude I see from the waiters here. They tell you how it is and will not give in to entitled customers. I seen a waiter straight up tell customers that they can not rearrange the tables and did not care that they will lose their business.
author: Jenny N.

description:
3.5 stars

PHO TAI BO VIEN. 

I love them beef ballzzz and rare steak. 

The broth is fragrant, not too salty (no msg?) and rice noodles cooked just right. 

I also love their pho ga and cha gio. 

But what we LOVE most about this place is the value. $7.89 for a BIG bowl. When it's raining outside (and guess what? California DOES get rain!) ain't nothing better than a bowl of pho.
author: Janice C.

description: My go to for Pho take out. They package up the meat and the noodles in a cardboard box, then fill up the plastic tub to the top with broth. Some other places jam the meat and the noodles into the tub so a) by the time you get it home it's super overcooked meat and soggy noodles, and b) you don't get as much broth which is the reason why you're getting pho!
author: David J.

description: I have two friends who rave about this place so I had to check it out. It was good but I still prefer Yummy Yummy's bun bo hue over theirs. Pho 2000 was a bit bland and my partner was also not as excited about her food.
author: Tina T.

description:
I have been eating here for a few times but the only reason is the how fast they are, inexpensive and the proximity to my home. On a cold evening, or afternoon pho is what I like to eat. 

This place is just disgustingly dirty. I eat here, then walk into a bathroom and immediately fighting the gag reflex. The grime and slime all over. 

Please charge more but ensure the cleanliness of the place where food is prepared and served. Seriously.
author: Anelya S.

description:
There are two things in life that makes me very happy: a bomb ass burrito and a piping hot bowl of pho. 

A great bowl of pho is quite simple: a clear broth, a generous abundance of fresh beef cuts/yummy goodness, and fresh noodles. And guess what? Pho 2000 delivers on this! (Let's look past the part where the soup was a bit oily, but other than that, it was a very happy experience.) I liked how their "small" bowl  of pho was quite generous compared to other pho restaurants in SF and I felt pleasantly full. 

Minus one star for the restaurant being stuffy upstairs. I was literally sweating bullets when I was eating and thought I was transported back to the time I had pho in Vietnam lol. Other than that, I will definitely will visit Pho 2000 again ^___^
author: Eva L.

description: Highly recommend the beef pho and the imperial rolls. It's relatively inexpensive.  Service level is decent considering the price you pay for a place in Little Saigon.
author: Andrew S.

description: Things could have been better such as the cleanliness of the facility. Food was mediocre, I've had better. Service is ok. But, I didn't read the yelp reviews to know their facility is cash only.
author: Amy P.

description:
Nice people, fast service and solid non-Americanized Vietnamese.

It's a small space with shared tables, and pretty much a hole in the wall on an okay block. 

Cost ( cuz I'm a cheapskate):  22 for 2 people w/o tip, so pricier than most in this 'hood, but the portions were large.

I'm a fan.

:)
author: El B.

description:
Pros (over it's competitors on the same block):

1. Opens at 8:30 (except Tuesdays... sniffle sniffle) 
2. more meat than competitors (slightly)
3. more noodles and broth in to-go orders than competitors
4. faster than competitors (by a minute or two)
5. huge pot of stock simmering round the clock makes the place smell incredible  

Cons

1. slightly more fat content in the broth than TT next door

Preferences:

1. broth packs less punch than TT but equally savory and delicious. hard to pick a favorite but TT may have a very slight edge on the beef broth, but you get a little less of everything in that broth.

Can't go wrong. But if I'm hungry before 10:30, I'm dialing 800-PHO-2000 every time.
author: Mike V.

description:
Been going here for over a decade now. The food is always very good and consistent. We usually get bun rieu (#15) and/or bun cha gio thit nung (#17) and it's the best in California as far as I've experienced.

Prices are more than reasonable.
author: L D.

description:
The bun rieu was delicious. 

-2 stars for the service.  Now I understand that this is a hole-in-the-wall place, and I shouldn't expect service to be stellar.  However, it feels unfair to be seated first, then have the table right next to you get seated, have their order taken first, served, then leave the establishment before you've even been provided your appetizer.  Maybe they were regulars, or maybe they knew the owners; either way it did get in the way of a pleasant dining experience.
author: Andy C.

description:
Great price for a large bowl of yummy pho!! I got the chicken pho (by the way... the large size is VERY LARGE). Also got the fresh rolls, which were good. Great pricing too. 

Would definitely come again, but not 5 stars because it didn't really blow me away.
author: Caley Z.

description: I dig this place a lot. Even though it is next door to one of "the best" pho places in the city, TURDle Tower, it far exceeds it. Service is speedy, the tea is amazing and their broth is very good. Feels a lot more homey than most Vietnamese restaurants and if they are busy enough you might get to sit upstairs, which is kinda fun.
author: Spencer C.

description:
After a night of fun, pho is always a good go to meal. Our group of 8 came for breakfast and were seated upstairs. We split the imperial rolls, shrimp rolls and I ordered the large portion of pho and was pretty satisfied with my meal. The shrimp rolls were very forgettable and I would not recommend ordering them. The imperial rolls were worth getting albeit a bit pricey. They were super hot fresh out of the oven, so be careful not to burn the roof of your mouth.

This place is cash only.
author: Edward W.

description:
Pho 2000 offers the best pho in SF and it's the only place I go to if I have a choice.

When I first moved to SF two years ago I couldn't find a good pho restaurant.  I was pointed to Kevin's noodle house and PPQ on Irving but neither satisfied my taste.  Both didn't have the strong aroma of herbs and tasted more like a Chinese noodle soup as opposed to southern style Vietnamese pho.  As a side note, I've become accustomed to most of the Vietnamese restaurants in SF being owned by the ethnically Chinese so I'm not surprised and typically head to SJ if I want great Vietnamese food.  Next on the list to try was turtle tower and honestly, it's good if I don't come in with a mindset of eating southern style pho.  TT lacks all the spices, toppings and sauces that I'm used to.

Pho 2000 is a no frills restaurant with the most authentic broth.  The broth is full of flavor, the service size is huge.  Don't expect to eat at a 5 star restaurant, expect a hole in the wall with authentic southern pho.  They also make the pho in the front which is pretty cool.  Reminds me of my trips to Vietnam where pho is served in the morning often times as street food.
author: Simon L.

description: Amazing and nice pho in SFO. The location is easy to find it. Nice place to come it again.
author: Maggie H.

description:
Pho anyone? By far, my favorite Pho place in the city. It can get crowded so I try to go off-hours. 

The food is very authentic South Vietnamese, pho broth is perfect, as well as the cha gio and bi cuon. These are almost always my go-to items on the menu. Sometimes I will get them to-go if it's too crowded.
author: Thuy V.

description:
Absolutely THE BEST PHO IN TOWN!
I always come back because you just won't get any better pho anywhere in San Francisco. 
Plus, their imperial rolls are to die for! But anything you order on the menu is always fresh and delicious. I definitely recommend.
author: Justyna M.

description:
As an SF native and currently still living here, I already have my staple Vietnamese restaurants in mind. I rarely would go out of my way to try a new place just because I know my favorites won't ever fail me, but it so happened that my sister and I decided to try out a different place in the TL since we were in the area and craving soup noodle after watching the Warriors game at a nearby bar.

We walked in and got seated immediately by the door, with others in Warriors gear slowly trickling in after we did. We got an order of imperial rolls and a large bun rieu. My goodness, their portions here are HUGE! And service was great! I have to say, their imperial rolls are the best I've had so far and definitely beat the other Vietnamese places I've been to. They come with a little side of rice noodles, cucumber, carrot, lettuce, cilantro and mint. These rolls are fat and come in 8 pieces (two huge rolls cut into fours). Then we got our large sized bun rieu to share and it was the perfect amount for us. LOTS of crab meat (more than I've ever seen before in a dish) , LOTS of noodles, and a good amount of tomato & the Vietnamese style pork sausage. And the bill turned out to be about $16 total! Not bad at all! Only downside about here is that the place is off Larkin and it isn't the cleanest/friendliest area in the city, but if you're looking for some quick, cheap hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese food in the Tenderloin and hefty portions, this is a great choice!
author: Kathleen S.

description: I would not come back here. The only pro is their fast service. The restaurant was a bit warm. Their beef pho was more salty than anything. My daughters spoon smelled like bleach and all other utensils did not seem clean I literally had to clean them with the napkins and water that they provided.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Value! Value! Value!

Main courses starting at $8, who can resist... especially if the food is actually decent/good!

It looks like a hole-in-the-wall from the outside but once you enter you'll see there's even an upstairs area - maximum use of space! 

You'll be seated quickly and just within minutes you have your food served... wow. So yes, service is fast and efficient.

The food was good - came here for the BO PHO ($8) which also comes in a large version for $10. But even my regular size was more than I could finish. The broth tasted fresh and together with the beef and vegetables I had a great pho.

Too bad they close at 9pm otherwise - 4 stars.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
$8.50 for a large bowl of delicious pho? Count me in!! Would definitely recommend this place to anyone in need of a hangover cure or who just wants to enjoy delicious noodles, meat, and broth (:
CASH ONLY so don't forget to bring your bills!!
author: Mio W.

description: Small space inside and it reminded of Tu Lan. I wound up being sat next to a stranger but that added to my dining experience here. I ordered a small #4, but the bowl looked like a large at other places. Broth wasn't salty or too oily. Generous amount of raw steak, flank, tendon, and noodles. It filled me up pretty good and all for $8. Good bang for your buck here.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
Mediocre pho and a tense staff hard to tell if most of them don't speak English or choose not to. The lady chefs near the door, ouch, so terse. I don't want to eat their frustration. The beef used in the pho is rough compared to Turtle Tower's beef.

Only went there because I always forget that Turtle Tower closes on Thursday.  Will be avoiding going back to Pho 2000 because their old school stern Asian noodle joint attitude is tired and the pho, though the bowl is gigantic, meh.

It's 2017. I refuse to enable a restaurant that acts grouchy distant and uptight it's toxic those days are over and it's cash only so my friend hoofed it to a bank machine and back to pay the bill. 

BYE FELICIA
author: SF T.

description:
Seriously. Some of the best pho ive ever had. Very busy place...but everyone was very nice.
The food was absolutely killer!!!!! Seriously......so good!!!! 
And the prices??? How can you beat them!!! Plus...they dont skrimp on the food at all. THERES ALOT OF FOOD!!!!
author: Wade F.

description:
I don't normally like to wander into the TL, but for Pho 2000, I will.

What looks like a hole in the wall is actually a pretty spacious restaurant. (As spacious as SF can get, I guess!) When you walk in, you can see the kitchen, which definitely prepares your stomach.

Note-worthy dishes:
- Bun Rieu: I can never find this dish anywhere, so it was so nice to finally try it at a restaurant!
- Bun Bo Hue: Flavorful, but not MSG-y.
- Seafood Pho: Heard it's good so I'll be back to try!
- Vermicelli Bowl: First time trying this dish here, and I know I'll be ordering this more.

Dishes are around $8, and they're cash only! Service is fast and friendly. 

I usually satisfy my Vietnamese food cravings in San Jose, but with this hidden gem of a spot, I can eat to my heart's desire in the city too!
author: Christine S.

description:
Large #12 please (yes, I can finish it).

The thing about pho places is that everyone thinks their pho restaurant is the best one, except this one really is. The pictures on Yelp should already have you drooling!

The pho here is absolutely delicious! The broth is perfectly savory and is accompanied with generous portions of meat, and noodley noms. You won't be able to stop dipping and slurping until your bowl is empty. 

This little hole in the wall is worth stopping in when you're craving a giant bowl of hot pho. 

Veg friendly, too!

Cash only!
author: Shereen A.

description: Great place to get Pho!  This would be great for those Sunday hangovers. I left full, happy and with enough spare leftovers to take home after ordering a small. They served my Pho at the perfect temp paired with some nice hot green tea. I ordered a number 8 (rare beer steak and rice noodles) Everything hit the spot and I will be returning!
author: Leslie T.

description:
Always prompt service and the waiters are very nice. 

I usually order their bun bo hue with fancy pork or bun rieu. Very consistent and flavorful. 

Bun rieu has lots of tomato flavor which I like.
author: Lennox B.

description:
Pho bowls are huge. Service was very kind. A little hot upstairs but they have little fans to keep you cool.


Great priceeeee too :)
author: Stephanie A.

description: This is one of my favourite Vietnamese restaurants in SF. It has all of the good phos, vermicelli,  rice plates, and even bun rieu. This is a very authentic place and reasonable price.   You can tell that it's authentic when you  order the rice plate with pork chop,  egg, and shredded pork and they give you the real Vietnamese steamed egg instead of a fried egg. Cash only though. I came here with a few friends from church on a Sat for lunch and we didn't need to wait long.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Pretty good pho for a Tenderloin spot! I usually go to Pho Tan Hoa on Jones, but thought I'd try Pho 2000 because of the amazing Yelp reviews.

It didn't disappoint! Very good and I like how clean and open it is. The open kitchen is nice.

I had the combination pho beef noodle soup, small, with coconut water and it was all delicious! Highly recommend this place.
author: Billy S.

description: Old school mom pops pho spot in TL, cash only sucks but the Pho is one of my favs in SF.
author: Johnny B.

description: Best pho I've ever had (2nd place to my mom's pho, of course!).  The ingredients are very fresh, and the broth is clear, savory, and sweet.  My favorite is the meatball pho! Their meatballs are so soft yet so chewy and bouncy. I've recommended this place to everyone I know, and it's become their favorite pho place!
author: Phuong L.

description: Best pho in San Francisco, hands down.  What else is there to say? The imperial rolls are good, too.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Delicious, cheap bowls of pho! Not in the best part of town unfortunately but the inside of the restaurant feels cozy. Service was quick and attentive.

The small size is already very filling and only costs $7. I got the special combination rice noodle soup which came with all the different types of beef. My favorite one was the beef balls. The soup was light and flavorful. I didn't need to add any sauce to it.
author: Linda X.

description:
Watched the waiter wipe the table & pushed food crumbs on to chairs & the floor instead of in his hand  or dish to put in trash.
COCKROACH ran across the table right before food arrived!
CASH ONLY!
Got FOOD POISONING!
author: Lou F.

description:
I stayed in the Mission District for 4 days and knew I wanted to check this place out. I got bun bo hue which was very good - not the best since it didn't have pig knuckle which is my favorite part of this dish. The vietnamese iced coffee was very good as well.

Service was good with the server seating me and giving me the menu immediately, and bringing out my food after only waiting a few minutes. 

On my last day, I was craving Vietnamese again and I was researching other places to go, but I just couldn't find any place that was rated as good as this place on Yelp. So I went here again (I know I should check out as many restaurants as possible in SF but my first experience was so good, I wanted to come back). This time I called for takeout an hour before they closed, and I was afraid I'd get an attitude for ordering so late, but that didn't happen. I got # 17 bun cha gio thit nuong (vermicelli noodles with bbq'd pork and spring rolls) and it was ready when I arrived 20 minutes later. This dish is amazing. Generous portions of everything - they didn't skimp out on the pork and didn't fill half the container with cucumber. 

I'll definitely be coming back to this place whenever I'm in SF again. I want to try all their dishes!
author: Stacey E.

description: Excellent Bun Rieu that was not too salty. The smaller bowl was enough to fill me up during lunch.  Good value also. Imperial roll was really food but not the best. Overall excellent value for lunch in the TL.
author: K C.

description:
Our other spot is closed on Saturdays unbeknownst to us.  So we ended up here.  The food is pretty good.  I remember coming here many years ago when they first opened.  It's a cash only joint.  What really turns me off is how filthy this place has become.

We were greeted and seated with great friendliness and served attentively.  Our rare steak pho and shrimp/pork spring rolls came out quickly.  Both were good but not great.  The meats were not as tender as other places or even flavorful.  Some of the basil leaves were wilted.  There are no green onions in the pho.  It was missing a little bit of love.  Our iced coffees were as expected and strong.  I could have probably enjoyed my meal better if the place was cleaner.  Every condiment container was coated with grime. Touching things with a napkin was the ideal way.  I observed another patron doing the same.  The mirror against the wall had fingerprints and crap all over.  It doesn't look like it's seen Windex in a few months.  The bathroom was atrocious.  They store their compost and recycling bin inside.  You can imagine the smell and of course the lack of cleanliness on the walls and floor.

Although, the food was decent, this place is dirty.  The health score speaks volumes, and quite frankly it makes eating here unappetizing.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Bun Rieu-crab paste tomato soup 

The balance of sweetness, acidity and savoriness melded quite well and probably the best I have had so far since moving to SF. Portions were good for the price and will leave you satisfied. 

Cash only 

Overall Thoughts

A definite go to spot for me in the Tenderloin if I am ever in the need of noodle soup
author: Eddie W.

description:
Why I go 4-Stars is because they have an overall range of menu, accessibility and a great spot that all adds up to an excellent low-cost Vietnamese Restaurant.  

The more I come here, the more I appreciate it.  In reality, this is such a reliable range of good food at good prices and a super-convenient range of hours.  It's also a nicely finished restaurant in terms of space and decor.  Not trendy, but engrossing in it's own way.  Given its prime Little Saigon location, it's a definite go-to for Pho, Bun, and all the other good stuff.  I'd still like to be able to get a cheaper version of the Cha Gio (Imperial Rolls).  Occasionally I run into minor quality issues with meat, but it's not something that keeps me from making this a go-to.  The pluses way outweigh the minuses.  

I love the big $7.45 bowls of Soup.  I REALLY love the Bun Rieu - Crab and Shrimp Flavors, Ground and Fancy Pork with a Tomato Broth and Noodles.  I'd go straight Pho Tai if you want to go in that direction.  They provide ample ways to season your Pho.  I also dig the Pork and Imperial Roll Noodles.  I grew up on these!  (Side note, I grew up in Minneapolis and my Mom introduced me to Bun Salads and Southeast Asian food, in general.  (Particularly Vietnamese food))  I also love the good and super-fast service too.  It is open by 8:30am a lot of days, and, this stuff is good at that hour.  What I do not like is the Tuesday closing, because I almost always find myself wanting it on Tuesday.  Much like Turtle Tower, this wrinkle is definitely a bummer.

One of my favorite things about living here is being nine blocks up the hill in SF from all this great Vietnamese food.  This is one of the cornerstones.  And, super-unSFlike, actually a terrific value.
author: Adam S.

description:
There are so many places for Pho in the area and I want to try them all. It's been really cold out, so I decided to try Pho 2000 out for lunch.

When I got there, I sat with a table of coworkers. Everyone had ordered, yet they were quick to get in my order and it even arrived first. We drank tea while waiting. 

I ordered what I always order, the Rare Beef Brisket with Beef Meatballs, here it's the #2. I ordered a small and it was BIG for a small at $6.89. It was plenty, but if you want more the large is $7.89 and a HUGE bowl. 

They give you basil, spouts, lemon and jalapeño which are not offered at Turtle Tower next door. I asked for extra jalapeños and they brought me a lot. I love it spicy and didn't let them go to waste.

The soup broth was so good. Very comforting and all the heat warmed me up. It was a great bowl of Pho and I will be back again soon.
