author: Rebekah T.

description:
I wasn't feeling well this week and needed a Pho fix stat. I hope those of you reading this know that Pho is a cure all for everything. Just saying. Walking home from my office, I checked Yelp and found Pho 2000 in a seedy part of the Tenderloin. Most of the best Pho in SF is in this neighborhood or the Inner Richmond, so it's tough to go wrong. 

For me, it's hard to distinguish good pho from great pho as most in SF fall in either of those two categories. I suppose it usually comes down to the quality of broth and meat/protein thats sitting in your massive bowl. Pho 2000's broth was light and clean. Just the way I like it. Sometimes you find Pho broth can be to "fatty" and tough to consume, but I was impressed with how refined this one was. The chicken in the Pho Ga was mostly white meat and the accompanying bean sprouts, basil, and glass noodles were fantastic. 

Fresh, quick and satisfying. This is why I love Pho. I'll be back...
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I frequent this place after a heavy night of drinking. Their pho hits the spot! You know it's legit when you see the huge pho pot right as you walk in. 

Delicious clear broth, huge bowls, generous meat portions, and always piping hot. The chicken pho is also a great option with a lighter tasting broth. Most recently, I got the bun rieu (tomato seafood/pork noodle soup) which was also delicious. 

Small hole-in-the-wall, but their food is a great price. Cash only of course, but luckily there's an ATM located at the Lee's Sandwich down the street.
author: Minh N.

description:
Alright. I'll admit it, Pho 2000 is my go-to-place for pho. I won't deny the fact that at first i was very hesitant to even come back a second time, but it's good. 

CASH ONLY! 

Pho 2000 is the in the heart of the Tenderloin and offers authentic Vietnamese pho. If you're not familiar think of it as the chicken noodle soup of Vietnam. 

I typically get the Pho Tai (pho with rare beef steak but don't worry the warm broth cooks the beef so it's no longer rare) or the rice plate with pork. Both don't disappoint. 

They have a TV, so this tends to be our spot Sunday mornings after a night of drinking during football season. 

This place isn't fancy but it does the job.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Not sure how they got all these stars.  The rice isn't even broken rice.  Bun bo hue is ok. Nothing too special.  They don't accept credit cards, cash only, in this day of age? Get with the program.  The bathroom was disgust, the kitchen was gross.  How did they pass safety inspection?  Rediculous!
author: Vanessa T.

description: Solid chicken salad. Can't wait to visit when I can eat more things. Overall, awesome hole-in-the-wall place, featuring cheap, authentic food. What more could you want?!
author: Shendi X.

description:
There is no shortage of pho spots in Little Saigon and Pho 2000 has become a consistent lunch destination for my friend and I. It's near the more popular Turtle Tower, but Pho 2000 offers something that Turtle Tower does not and that is BASIL. Turtle Tower serves Ha Noi style Vietnamese cuisine where basil is painfully absent. 

Pho 2000 offers the pho I am familiar with  including the well known accouterments of basil, bean sprouts, lime, and jalapenos. My go to order is the Rice noodle soup with rare steak and beef balls and Thai tea. The Thai tea is a must whenever I order pho. It has become an inseparable combo for me. I am not a big fan of the tendon that is used here so I opt out of it. The beef balls and rare steak are under seasoned and can sometimes be a little chewy but the broth makes up for it. I am a fan of the clove/nutmeg nutty and sweet flavor and these ingredient(s) seem to be more pronounced at the Pho 2000 broth. I'm not actually sure if they use those ingredients but I like the sweeter broth. I refrain from adding the chili oil, hoisin sauce, or Sriracha in fear of hiding the aromatics of the soup. It's a solid pho joint in Little Saigon. It's CASH ONLY so make sure you have a $20 on you.
author: David M.

description:
Pho 2000 is like a bowl of pho: you never know what you're gonna get. Or is that chocolate? Whatever, life's a gamble. You rarely get what you expect. 

Located in the tender-nob, it can be a sketchy walk at night but overall it's harmless. I enjoy coming here when I want pho because the bowls are big, cheap, and oftentimes delicious. Pho isn't an exact science though, so sometimes when I come it's too greasy, or too bland, or too meh. I'd say 7.5 times out of 10, pho 2000 does it right. 

Don't get the big noodles though. BEWARE of the big noodles, they are not like the ones you eat at your grandma's house. The big noodles here are mushy and unappetizing. Stick with tiny noodles and you'll be satisfied with your decision. 

I had the imperial rolls once and they were yummy. Very crispy and served with a bunch of lettuce, which is quite authentic. I also tried the bun xeo (pancake crepe thingie) but it was nothing special, I'd pass on that next time. 

The place has a homey feel and I always see the same staff so I assume it's family-owned. Don't expect warm service, but they are super quick. You'll be in and out in less than 45 minutes.
author: Shaina V.

description:
Living in South Bay where access to CHEAP, GIGANTOR, DELICIOUS, FRESH pho in SJ is abundant...I just can't seem to love this SF spot.

I had the small size seafood pho, and since so many yelpers were saying that the SMALL was in fact a large in their eyes...I thought cool, alright, I'm going to be extremely stuffed just like they were. Wrong. I keep forgetting that I don't eat like the typical small asian girl, so I definitely could have benefited from a large. HOWEVER, one gold star to pho 2000 for having different noodle types: thin and thick! I am a noodle savant and I absolutely appreciate that choice, and obviously I always go thin with my pho. Not only was portion size underwhelming, the seafood used was all "faux" from imitation crab to weird rubbery squid and fish cake. At least have some real fish slices or crab balls and what not.

Service is super efficient and awesome, shoutout to the two guys serving on an early Thursday evening. Another gold star for the complimentary hot tea upon being seated! I think the pho itself wasn't tremendously tasty, nor was it the best bowl I've had (SJ holds that title down for me).

It could be that my taste buds are spoiled by the delicious pho spots in South Bay, but I think that it's a whole combination of the small portion, lack of seafood in the actual seafood pho, scary-dirty health standards, lack of employee cleanliness courtesy (saw the pho lady cough into the kitchen...gross), and all-around lackluster pho just didn't fill me up. However, all things considered, I can see why SF people might think this is the best "legit" pho they've ever had, but come to the South Bay and we'll show you a pho-freakin' good time.
author: Jodi H.

description: Came here for lunch. Fast, food came out within 5 minutes. Cheap, $10 for a large bowl of soup, includes tax and tips. Had left over to go for afternoon snack. Yummy broth, had the bun rieu, very very very tasty broth, everyone blend well together. Will return.
author: Kris J.

description:
Cheap, GIANT bowls of pho. I like the #3 which has all the different types of meat in it-- don't come in too late though, I came in once at 730 (they close at 830) and at 840 sharp they walked by the table with a shout over their shoulder of "You have to leave now, bye!". 

Hey, customer service isn't great, but the food is pretty good. Cash only.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
Once my friend and I entered, we were seated at their upstairs dining area. We ordered the vermicelli bowl w/pork & imperial rolls and large bowl of pho with steak & beef balls. Our waiter warned us that the large bowl was quite huge which was very considerate! The pho broth had a different taste that I never experienced but still good. The vermicelli bowl had plenty of pork and 4 pieces of imperial rolls which made me super full. 

If you sit upstairs you will be neglected... after our waiter gave us our food he didn't come back to check on us. Our bill was $17.80 - cheap dinner!!

CASH ONLY
author: Sully B.

description: The first best pho place on Larkin street. If you are looking for chicken pho, you may be better off going to Turtle Tower down the block.
author: Karl K.

description:
The tenderloin is changing. Maybe because it was a rainy night, there were not as many people standing around.  

Found Pho2000 on YELP since my friend suggested pho before the ballet.

The place was almost full on Sunday just after 5.  It's a good value.  It's reassuring to see huge pots of soup cooking on the stove in front.

We both had pho tai, the rare beef with thin rice noodles in soup.  Flavor was ok and the quantity of soup was very generous for a small.  We probably should have ordered an appetizer since I got hungry later.

If you're in the neighborhood this is a quick warm meal.
author: Joanna S.

description:
This place is my favorite pho place in the area. It's exactly what you want with a flavorful broth and perfect noodles. It's right by my work place and its a convenient walk. 

I always get one of the phos so I'm never disappointed. Once my coworker ordered the Chow mein and it was literally noodles with a couple pieces of vegetables so I'm not sure I would ever order that for myself. The portion looked a little small too.

I prefer this place over turtle tower next door for pho.

Cash only.
author: Mimi T.

description:
When it is raining in San Francisco, and I am recovering from a wine and whiskey hangover the only thing I wanted was a steaming hot bowl of Pho.  Luckily, Pho 2000 is just  a few short blocks from my apartment and after reading the reviews of the veggie and beef broth being some of the best in town I knew this was just the spot to cure my cravings.  A small hole in the wall restaurant located in the "little Saigon" area of the Tenderloin, Pho 2000 is situated amongst a ton of other Pho and Vietnamese spots with constant lines out the door of hungry soup seekers.  We walked into Pho 2000 around 1PM on a rainy Saturday and waited about 1 minute before being sat at a table.  FYI, they double seat people, so if there are just two of you it is likely that they will sit  a solo diner at your table so they really get the most of their space. 
 
Being vegan, it is always tough to find a spot with a decent (or any) option for non-meat broth.  Pho 2000 offers one vegetarian Pho option in either small or large, thin or thick noodles.  I went for the small with thin noodles as I feel like sometimes the large just means larger amount of broth and not necessarily a good ratio with the veggies/noodles.  My fiancé went for the beef Pho with tripe and rare steak (large). One of the best things about eating Pho is the affordable price tag and quick service.  At Pho 2000 you are immediately greeted with a steaming pot of tea and once the server takes your order the food is up in less than 10 minutes.  For me, the small was a perfect size.  Add in the jalapenos, fresh basil, bean sprouts, and of course a little Sriracha and I was in heaven.  The pho included tofu, broccoli, zucchini, bok choy and of course the delicious thin noodles.  After letting the broth take in all the added extras for a few minutes I was left with a perfectly spicy and flavorful, but light, veggie broth that I just wanted to take my bowl and begin the drink it. Mmm.  The large size was just as expected, LARGE. My fiancé is the type of guy who can put down food like no one's business and he couldn't even finish this thing but said it was tough to put it down because the broth was so good. 

Cash only.  Two people + full bellies and at $20 (including tip) for a meal this has now become my new go-to Pho spot in town.
author: Kelsey B.

description: Best pho! Hole in the wall place in the TL. When you walk in, you can see a giant pot of broth that surely has been simmering for hours. Flavorful, aromatic, herbaceous - one of my favorite places to eat in SF.
author: N L.

description:
I'm not sure what the story behind the name Pho 2000 is, but I would like to hear it!

I was in the area with my girlfriend and she was craving pho - well she always is haha.

Pho 2000 looks like a small family owned business, so it was definitely something to look forward to. As I was reading the reviews, I saw that the imperial rolls were the one of the most popular items on the menu. We ordered one pho with rare beef and the rolls. The pho broth was flavorful and the noodles were cooked well. The imperial rolls were a bit greasy bit I loved the filling and the crunch! 

I wish the service was a little faster since I went before the lunch rush and there were only 2 other parties. 

All in all it was a pleasant experience.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
A nice place to go for a quick Pho fix! I've eaten lunch here a couple times with multiple people. Although they're quite busy during lunch hours, the service is quick and food gets served within ten-ish minutes of ordering. 

I usually get their Bun Rieu, Pho Tai, or Pho Ga - just simple stuff. Make sure you make a "bib" or that you're not wearing white if you're eating the Bun Rieu, the soup is tomato-red and you're going to get splash back if you're not careful (which happened to me, LOL). I'm not a fan of rare meat, so I just dunk the rare steak into the hot broth for my Pho Tai, which helps to make it well done. The Pho Ga is a perfect chicken-soup type of a meal if you have a cold!

One complaint I have is it can get pretty stuffy and hot when the weather is nice, especially if you're sitting on the second level. They have an air conditioner/fan up there, but it's not that strong. 

Overall, this is a good place to go for quick and cheap Vietnamese food!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Great pho in the Tenderloin!

Bowls are quite large. I was really full after eating the small and it's $7.10, which is the cheapest I've found in the TL. The Sunset has cheaper places (i.e. Kevin's Noodle House). Portions are generous - huge bowls, lots of noodles, good amount of meat, and lots of vegetables that you can add. The broth itself was thicker and more flavorful than I usually expect in pho broth (I like it light, not too overpowering) so that was a little suspect to me and made me question if it had MSG. I didn't get thirsty after which is a good sign. But either way it tasted great, and is obviously well worth the money!
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Better Pho than Great Saigon in Chinatown. The number 11 with beef flank, tripe, and steak actually consisted of real slices of meat. However, the tripe was almost nonexistent.  

The broth lacked any depth and tasted water down but at least it didn't smell or taste overwhelmingly of allspice. 

The noodles were fine and the side veggies of bean sprouts, mint leaves, and jalapeños were incredibly fresh. And then we spotted the lemon slices and were disappointed.

Decent place to get pho on a cold winter day.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Craved some pho one chilly morning and ended up at Pho 2000.  It's small, but we got seated immediately...which was great cause I was getting hangry.  I didn't care much for the cinnamony broth, but thoroughly enjoyed the warmth from the soup.  

There were limited utensils and condiments at the tables, so we had to share with our table neighbors.  Service was quick and so was our meal.

CASH ONLY
author: Lyn C.

description:
CASH ONLY!

I. AM. A. FAN! It's located in the tenderloin, but it's not a bad area! Open early and they move quickly!! Right when you get in, they seat you immediately in the downstairs or upstairs area (WARNING: Upstairs gets hot!). In most pho restaurants, I feel like the workers move slowly whenever you ask them for something like a water refill or something. Well, they move FAST here. Everything is BOOM BOOM BOOM. I LOVE IT. 

They give you plenty of meat and noodles. However, sometimes I wish i had less noodles cause I just like drinking their broth LOL. They also sell a bowl of Bun Rieu (one size only) which is absolutely delicious. The grounded pork is minced instead of in whole chunk which was a little weird but still delicious!

PRICES: it's around 7.50 for a small bowl of pho which is totally fine because the bowl is actually a decent size. 

GOOD JOB PHO 2000! I hope one day you accept card, it's so hard making sure I have enough cash all the time.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Excellent bun rieu! 
Will definitely be back to try the pho... hopefully not while nursing a hangover.

CASH ONLY!!
author: Lucy N.

description:
I can't believe the amount of stars this place has received. Let me start off by saying I was really turned off by the sight of the microwave. And I know I know I'm sure there are other restaurants that use them but just seeing how much they used it already started giving me bad vibes. But I true to put that aside and judge them on the food. 

The waiters were really prompt and helpful. I noticed when the cooks needed help, they were thee to give a hand. 

We started off with the spring roll pork and shrimp. Unsurprisingly it was premade. The wrapper was unpleasantly sticky. Like it had been sitting in the fridge for awhile. I too a bite and made my bf eat the rest. 

I order a number 3 large. The broth was plain and oily. Not as much tendon and tripe as I would have liked. 

My bf ordered number 15. Pretty much the same as number three but instead of flank he got brisket. He thought this place was okay.

Thirty minute after we got home, I got a major headache. I felt dizzy and my mouth was very dry. So that gave me an indication they OBVIOUSLY use MSG. That was the worst experience I've EVER had at any pho restaurant. I've never had that bad of reaction before. I just had to wait it out until it went away. STAT CLEAR OF THIS PLACE. Go to miss Saigon instead!!!!
author: Lynn C.

description:
My new go-to pho spot in SF. 

Clean, great pho, and right across the street from Saigon Sandwich so I can grab some cheap Vietnamese food for the road.
author: Chris C.

description: Food is pretty good. Not the best Pho i've had, but still delicious. Service is quick.
author: Rey-Joy D.

description: My only complaint is that it's cash only... otherwise, it's a must try for all those who enjoy food, Vietnamese food, and a cozy place where people can hang and get to know each other.
author: Aaron W.

description: This place is the equivalent of a dive bar. Pho is great but sometimes can be hit and miss. Prices are cheap, service good but not in the best neighborhood with pretty dated interior. I have eaten here many times and keep coming back.
author: Paul V.

description:
It's a busy pho restaurant but the staff is still smiley. And I feel like the Asian restaurant way is to have customers share tables with strangers, so they'll normally ask you to sit near the wall if you're given a bigger table so they can squeeze in as many customers as they can during rush hours - which is totally fine.

The pho - broth is super clear and it tastes delicious. Use a soup spoon, load the spoon up with meat and noodles, dip it into the soup, and slurp it all up. It goes down super smooth. It's kinda weird to say but the broth is just...cleaner than other places for some reason. It's a really specific "feeling" - I don't even know how to explain it. But I've heard of people who don't like pho mainly because of the feeling that the broth is just forever sitting in meat all day so they think 

The ONLY reason I gave them 4 stars is because they don't have the Three-Colored Drink, which kinda equals infinite sadness for me. I mean I'm pretty sure it's a legit Vietnamese thing to have this dessert drink...
author: Athena C.

description: Good taste and large portion of rice meal. Enough vegetables for the health. Many choices on the menu. Very popular and almost full.
author: Cynthia Y.

description: Super authentic, divey and awesome. Stumbled upon by accident and was so happy I did.
author: Emily S.

description: Very good Pho in SF. I have been trying many Pho in South Bay, and Pho Bo here is among best. Testy soup, fresh meets and noodle.
author: Daisuke Y.

description:
The fact that this place is open at 930am makes it 5 stars.

I woke up craving pho, but most places in the Mission open after 11am, so I was SO thankful for Pho 2000. The pho is good - definitely hits the spot. 

The location is pretty sketchy.. but if you're going around 10am on a weekend like I am.. there's nothing to worry about.
author: Angela L.

description: Great price and good food super great imperial rolla and close to where i live . Cant be more happy.
author: Arash S.

description: Amazing food, amazing service, for an excellent price. Some of the best pho I've ever had. I wish I were in SF for longer to go again!
author: Emily W.

description:
While this place isn't in my favorite part of town and it could be a bit more clean, I do really enjoy the food. 
They offer a vegetarian Pho with veggie broth (yes you have to specify both) that I really enjoy getting when the weather is gloomy or moist. They also have a few other vegetarian options, making it a bit of a standout if you don't eat meat.
If you can make it in a bit before or after the lunch rush you can save yourself a wait. Sometimes the line is out the door.
Prices are very affordable and portion sizes are generous.
author: Olivia D.

description:
It was so disappointing - this place was highly recommended by a friend and clearly I ordered the wrong thing.  #22 Bun Chai - vermicelli with tofu for take out.  What I got was a huge pile of noodles atop some chopped lettuce and with a few pieces of fried tofu and sautéed onions/cabbage? on top.  Flavorless and barely warm. Not good.  
Sometimes getting take-out is not as good as ordering in...
Anyhow last week I had a similar dish next door at Lotus and it was excellent.  Know where I will be going next time :-(
author: Pascale S.

description:
This place is pretty good for its cheap prices. We've been back twice already and bf always goes there when I am out of town. I got the Bun Rieu and flavorful, huge portions and yummy. He gets the usual combination and always comes out of the restaurant with a smile.

Cash only, don't worry about how clean they are, and just enjoy your Vietnamese foods!
author: Vanessa K.

description: Wow! Love this hole in the wall! Came here with Sarah on our monthly mother- daughter adventure date, and found it to be quite pleasant! We felt like we were actually in Vietnam! While I definitely plan on telling my girlfriends all about this place I'm hesitant to give it five stars as it did not take cash. Walking around in SF is already plenty dangerous, considering all the wild youth and merciless gangs, but factor in carrying cash and you've got a recipe for disaster. When you come here make sure to hide your cash in your shoe or some other place where no one can see it!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Amazing beef pho! Quite possibly the best pho in SF. And it's $7.50 for a small (which is plenty big, basically a medium) or $8.50 for a large (which is HUGE). You know to get the beef because when you walk in, you see a huge 5 foot tall vat of pure beef stock simmered for probably a day to get that true beef broth flavor.

The #1 to #9 on the menu is great. Pick anything really. The meatballs are definitely made in-house and you can taste it. 

It's in the TL district, so take Bart or walk there from downtown, you won't regret it for the pho quality. They move the lines (during rush hour) quickly as well and service is fast.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Errrr...so...we stayed past 28 mins of their closing time and they shut the lights on us. My friend was slurping noodles in the dark. No joke. I mean, they were still cleaning up. The kitchen guy had just finished his plate of rice. Why would you do that unless you are a complete dick?

After we left, my friend and I debated if we will go back again. I mean, the imperial rolls were the best...not in the city but pretty good. The bun rieu was decent...a bit on the sweet side I think. And the beef pho definitely was A-OK - broth didn't have enough beef taste...a little heavy on the herbs side. Portions are generous, service was fine but with this crap treatment we got at the end and the abundance of good Vietnamese restaurants in the city, we definitely won't be going back for a while.
author: J B.

description:
Cheap, local, authentic, large portions, good service.

I've been coming here for years. It's a hole in the wall on Larkin street among other holes in the wall. They are always super enthusiastic, and I typically pick up a pork and imperial roll vermicelli bowl as my standard, but recently also had the Pho and a rice plate and both were great too. Seriously cheap, dinner for two was $17.00 + tip.
author: Jordan C.

description:
This is hands down on of the best places for pho in San Francisco, in my opinion!!

You can't go wrong with any of the combinations and most recently, I was introduced to the bun rieu here. OMG SOOO AMAZING!! I am such a bun rieu addict now, its pretty unbelievable. 

It's right near Chambers and that street of Vietnamese restos in the Tenderloin.. not exactly the best place to be at night, but at least parking isn't usually too bad. It definitely gets packed on Sundays when people are in desparate search of a hangover cure..so sometimes it might be worth it to order it to-go and bring it home instead of having to wait.

Fast service and I have friends that come here at LEAST once a week. I would totally come here more if it weren't in the TL (which would probably be a bad thing for my waist line..)!
author: Jennifer S.

description: I love this place. It's got kick ass bun rieu and bun bo hue. That already is enough of a reason to come here. But here are some more: Service is quick and to the point. Prices are reasonable. High turnover of tables. Always packed during lunch, yet quick to get a seat. Turtle Tower (which is a few storefronts away) is nice and all, but if you just want a quick, sit-down lunch that won't empty your wallet, then this it! The pho is good too. I've never found the rare steak to be an unhealthy color. The spring rolls a little on the small side, but the vermicelli bowls are huge. Complimentary tea.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Extremely rude staff, did not give us the light of day. 
They pointed at a table and threw menus at the table and then walked away. Then we realized it's a CASH ONLY place. We walked out.
author: Marko C.

description: Great place. Delicious food and wonderful atmosphere where you can shout and not feel rude. Always makes for a fun, lively time with friends. Before you go, make sure you have cash though, because they don't take card.
author: Seth G.

description: Didn't know I loved pho until I finally ate here. Highly recommend the vegetarian pho.
author: Jen H.

description:
Oh hey #phomonday, lovely for you to bring us to this amazing spot! 

I've heard from coworkers that this place is amazing so I went in with some expectations, and honestly I left feeling happy with delicious pho in my belly. The broth is quite flavorful. The pho was a little more on the oilier side compared to other places I've been but I'm not complaining, that's for sure. You could tell the meat cuts were good ones, not just flimsy fatty ones you get from other places. Their ratio of meat to noodles is also perfect. I love that they had larger slices of onions and green onions for me to munch on with every ladle of soup/ pho I'd slurp down. I ordered the small #12 (rare beef + brisket) and asked for their flat noodles. I'm SO glad I did, you can tell the noodles are hand pulled making it more delicious. Everything about that bowl seemed handcrafted and personalized like a work of art, and not just a rushed bowl of soupy noodles and meat. 

The raves about this place were right on the money! Definitely in my top 5 fave pho spots in the bay so far.
author: Rehana K.

description: Pho 2000 is my to go pho place nowadays.  I like the broth, nice and beefy, but not all fatty.  The noodles are perfectly chewy.  The fried imperial rolls are a great and tasty appetizer to share.  Take it from a pho snob, this place is good!
author: Wendy S.

description:
Solid Vietnamese food! Food comes out quickly (I find this to be true of most Vietnamese noodle shops).

The beef shank pho was really good - my friend, who normally eats very little, devoured the entire bowl without pausing! The dry vermicelli with barbecue pork and egg rolls was pretty good as well - the egg rolls were AMAZING! The pork was a bit tough/fatty but still okay.

About $16 for two people, which is a really good deal. Not the cleanest or classiest restaurant, but not any worse than I expected. It's located in one of the sketchier areas of San Francisco though, but just be alert and you'll be fine. Otherwise, great place for a quick lunch!
author: Ivonnie S.

description:
When you're rolling through the Tenderloin and notice a ton of pho and vietnamese restaurants and don't know what you're craving, go with Pho 2000.

No frills place. Large soup bowls are rather large and relatively cheap ($8.10?). I got the Pho dac biet...essentially a mish mash of all the meats with pho broth and noodles. 

Imperial Rolls are $6.75ish and very satisfyingly delicious. Spring rolls, on the other hand, were a miss and also $6.75.

Broth is delicious here and they actually have tables available for larger groups!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I spent 2 weeks in Vietnam, so I'm basically in expert in what Vietnamese food should taste like.

You know that scene in Ratatouille, when Anton Ego takes his first bite and gets transported back to his childhood? Well upon my first bite of the Bun Cha that I ordered, I was transported back to Hanoi, surrounded by small children and chickens.  It's so good.

Eat here.
author: Will H.

description:
Either I keep having one of the greatest pho runs of all time and keep ducking all the crappy pho places, or it's just that pho is really hard to screw up unless you're THAT incompetent person.  Any self-respecting Asian knows that screwing up pho is cardinal sin.  Thankfully, these guys know how to make some pho.  Not really sure about the name, but that's not really all that important to me.

Anyways, same order as always: Combo special, large bowl.  I have no complaints about the pho, it was tasty and the broth was on point.  And for $7, it's pretty much in that price range where I won't complain about it.  Spring rolls were fresh, Imperial rolls (it's just a fancy name for fried egg rolls) were perfectly crispy and had great flavor to them. 

It seems smaller than it is, but there's an upstairs part so there's actually plenty of seats available.  Customer services was great, had no complains there either.  Cash only, as others have said.  Only gripe is that...well, it's not exactly in the safest of locations in SF, but it is what it is.  Sometimes you just have to make that journey for the pho.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
Second time here! I couldn't stop thinking about this place since the last time I was here. Just drove up from LA the night before so I needed some good food. 

I brought my mom and she is really really picky. She loved the food and the prices. Seriously she's a hard person to please. If she can make the food better, she will hate the place lol 

Soup is hot and perfect. Flavor is so on point and it is not super greasy. Good quality meats and veggies. 

I grew up in the TL but hate the neighborhood now. No parking and dirty and sketchy...but the noodles here are worth it. Best pho I've tasted in awhile. So I guess I'll be back. Parking sucks!!!!
author: Chrissy S.

description: Quick service. Great food. Pho is fresh and the broth great. Gotta get in early for fresh & plentiful herbs.
author: Girl on the Bike s.

description:
Pho 2000 is THE Vietnamese restaurant. Everything from the food to the staff, to the decor reminds you of traditional Vietnam. Even the narrow long building is what you would see there. I tried sooo many in the bay. But this is by far my #1. You'll find everything on the menu that you would expect from Vietnamese cuisine. 
The price is amazing. You'll be so full with $10. I can see you holding your belly out of the door. ;-)
Anyway. It's one of those little hidden diamond in town. Don't look at the appearance but just go for the full experience.
author: Elsa T.

description: Some of my favorite beef broth flavor in town. Especially enjoy getting their tendon. Imperial rolls and spring rolls are great here, too. This is my #1 pick for pho in SF.
author: Kyle T.

description:
The best pho in Little Saigon - and that's saying something!

We go almost once a week, so we get to try out plenty of menu items. 

If you're looking for an authentic and unique pho, get the tomato-based broth pho, number 15. It's brilliantly flavored, not spicy at all, and so satisfying. 

Overall we keep coming back because it's just that good (and reasonable). The servers are very attentive and the service is very efficient. We bring our friends from out of town (or from out of the neighborhood) every chance we get. 

Try it! You won't regret it.
author: Christian P.

description:
Was craving Vietnamese food. The good news is that in San Francisco, there are lots of yummy options! The bad news? There isn't any. Maybe the area as it's not the prettiest? 

We stumbled upon Pho 2000 before going to the movies nearby, we wanted to eat fast. 
Appreciated the tea served as we sat down. 

The food came very quickly. We had Pork and Imperial Rolls over Vermicelli and Salad. The price was excellent: it was around 8 dollars! 
The size was huge, I could not finish all the Vermicelli. 
The 2 big cut-up imperial rolls were fresh and tasty. 

We were able to order, eat and pay in about 20 minutes, which was what we wanted as we were in a rush.... Perfect!
Next time, and there will be a next time, I will try this same bowl with beef.
author: Leslie S.

description: We happened to be in SF and we're looking for a parking spot so we could have a meal at House of Thai.  We literally parked right in front of Pho 2000.  Decided to try a bowl because you never know when you are going to find something great!  The 400 + Yelp reviews were encouraging and even though the place was small and busy but we got a table right away.   Just be warned, the Large size is a huge portion!   A regular size is what is more the norm.  Also very generous with the amount of meat that comes with the soup.  Pho was delicious although my husband prefers less of an Anise flavor.  All the great reviews speak for themselves.  A good place for a great bowl of Pho.
author: Brenda M.

description:
I just got back from Vietnam and had been craving spring rolls...I think I shed a couple of tears when our server brought out the imperial rolls... They tasted like I was back in Vietnam!! Ugh, my soul is happy. This place also has awesome pho. The small was massive (and only $7)... I can't imagine how big a portion the large is! 

I will now forever be a customer at this place.
author: Danielle J.

description:
Not Pho 2001, not Pho 1999... It's Pho 2000!! This is the go-to Pho spot in San Francisco.  It sits in the heart of Little Saigon and the Tenderloin.  The restaurant isn't huge, but I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes to get seated.  The bowls of noodles are big; prices relatively low.  I don't know where else in San Francisco you can get a full meal under $10.  

Quick tip... I love Pho Tai more than anyone else, but try their Pho Ga some time!  This is made with a chicken broth instead of beef.  I also sometimes like to switch it up by asking for thick noodles.

P.S. CASH ONLY!!!
author: Candace C.

description:
Was insanely hungover one Sunday morning and this was one of the only place open that had veggie pho with veggie broth. SO glad I came here!

The veggie pho is super flavorful here and doesn't leave you with that non-stop thirst from MSG overload. Spring rolls are equally as good and it seems they don't have it pre-made like most other pho joints.

Service is a bit slow, but that might've been because I was hungover and my brain was a little behind that day... heh.

CASH ONLY! They have a supermarket-ish place across the street with an ATM if you forget.
author: Anna M.

description: Great tasting broth. Loved the small #6 with rare steak. The chicken broth was great too - lots of garlic flavor.
author: Amin S.

description:
Why is it called Pho 2000? Couldn't they think ahead and rename it 2020, or go balls-to-the-wall and call it Pho 3000? Pho 2000 makes it seem, well, so Y2K, doesn't it? Like they forgot to switch the clocks back on. Or maybe they just realize a lot of their business is simply spillover from the more impatient diners who were hoping to eat at Turtle Tower next door. To be brutally honest, that was the reason I came here. I was in the mood for pho but not for a queue, especially since I was a solitary diner on a Sunday evening in Little Saigon.

Sure enough, there was a sea of formica at Pho 2000 ready for me to take a table for four all by myself here. Hoping naively for a small appetizer, I ordered the $6.99 Bánh Xèo, which was a huge, greasy Vietnamese crepe that looked more like a deep-fried omelette (see photo). It contained bits of shrimp and pork plus bean sprouts, but it was so greasy that I just scraped the meat and the sprouts off the crepe and left the sad carcass of the crepe in a pool of oil on the plate. I tried to make a salad out of the romaine lettuce leaves that were meant to scoop the crepe but to no avail.

Just in the nick of time, the $6.25 small bowl of Pho Tai Chin arrived. It was satisfying with a hearty broth that wasn't too oily and enough slices of rare steak and brisket to satisfy me (see photo). It's not Turtle Tower when it comes to flavor, but it's a decent enough back-up if you're hankering for pho but not willing to wait for it next door. I may come back for the Bun Rieu (Crab & Tomato Vermicelli Soup) since it's not that common, and I can compare it to the stellar one they serve at Soup Junkies on Market. Or maybe the Pho Chay (Vegetarian Rice Noodle Soup). But not that crepe. Definitely not.

FOOD - 3 stars...decent pho, greasy crepe
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...Formica-ville
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...cordial and prompt
TOTAL - 3 stars...is there a line at Turtle Tower?
author: Ed U.

description:
After moving to the Bay Area I've been in search for a decent bowl of pho. I've mostly had misses but went to Pho 2000 after a recommendation from a friend living in the Tenderloin. Even though I'm sure no restaurant will compare to my mothers home made, Pho 2000 is the best I've had yet around these parts so far. 

Their small is a very decently sized portion and really well priced - under $10. The brother is solid, has a good flavor and best yet is not too oily. A signature of pho is the star anise scent, which isn't too strong in the broth. I got the bo tai and really wish that it came uncooked. I prefer my meat rare and the cut different, but that's just personal preference. 

The restaurant is small and has that family owned vibe. There aren't a ton of tables downstairs, but they have a upstairs loft with additional seating which in nice. When you enter you're basically in the kitchen, so it's cool seeing your food actually being made and that huge pot of pho in the stove. 

Overall I'll probably be back until I can explore more. But I definitely give this place a solid rating. Lots of little treasures in the Tenderloin.
author: Jen V.

description: They have a vermicelli soup dish called bun rieu which is really amazing. It's tomato broth topped with shrimp. It looks spicy but it isn't at all. It has a very comforting and delicious broth. Their pho is pretty good, almost on par with Miss Saigon on 6th. I've only sat at the top before, which seems nicer than their first floor area. I've never had to wait for a seat, either. If you are deciding between here and Turtle Tower, definitely come here.
author: Elisa L.

description:
SOOOOO GOOD! 

The pho had a phenomenal broth and the meat was tender and good. I can't recall the number I had but it mostly consisted of beef and beef balls. Definitely recommend this place to pho lovers out there.
author: Kimdracula A.

description:
Good: Delicious broth, generous portions, and great prices.

Bad: Debatable cleanliness, cash only, 10-15 minute wait for lunch. 

I always get the #11 large for lunch and take home what I don't finish. It's always enough for dinner and for some reason, is more delicious when I reheat it at night. Pretty good choice for pho but there are a lot of places that serve pho in the Tenderloin so if this doesn't float your boat, the place next door might.
author: Yanni L.

description: Ordered number 1 combination pho large. It came in a HUGE ASS bowl, for around $9. Recommended!
author: Jeff G.

description: So far, this might be my favorite pho spot in the city. It's a small spot in the middle of a very ghetto area. However, none of that matters once you walk in and smell the aroma and once they place a hot bowl of delicious goodness in front of you. I've been there twice and both times, I had a consistently good experience. I've tried both the fresh (wide noodles) as well as the regular thinner noodles and both are good. Their broth is very tasty and they give you a good amount of meat. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jenn N.

description:
The open kitchen is breath of fresh air for a vietnamese restaurant.  I love that you can see all the action from the pot of soup to the kitchen staff using latex gloves.  That deserves a 4.

A great vietnamese is based on the broth.  This restaurant definitely has all the proper elements from mint leaves to basil and sprouts.  The problem is the broth here is msg overload.  After I finished my dinner, I needed water badly.  The Pho Ga noodle soup was tasty at first sip but clearly the msg helped enhance the taste.  The Bun Bo Hue had a little too shrimp paste.  The Bun Rieu was also a little on the sweet side.

Parking is definitely a challenge.  The restroom was not the cleanest.

With the number of vietnamese restaurants in the tenderloin, I will probably not go there again.

If you want authentic vietnamese, go up the street to Anh Hong.  Bon appetite.  Until next time, ciao!
author: Dee Dee L.

description:
Pho 2000 makes the best pho that I've had. The broth has been consistent every visit over the last six months - mostly clear with a nice amount of oils for flavor and texture. I don't think they're using MSG, as my mouth has never been irritated after eating a bowl. My usuals: a large number six (rare beef) and some imperial rolls.

Service is fast. Price is great. You're getting what you paid for and not much more. I'd give Pho 2000 five stars if their place was renovated and their health score was higher.
author: Nick R.

description: Such a wonderful pho place!! I live in Nob Hill and have already been wanting to come to little Saigon to try Vietnamese restaurants. Every time I walked by, Pho 2000 is always full of customers. So I decided to pick this one to go. I was not disappointed! The soup and beef are simply amazing.
author: Yawen H.

description: We stopped by this place on our last trip to San Francisco and we were not disappointed. My sweetheart got the combo pho and I got the pho tai.  The noodles were cooked perfectly, the meat was lean and fresh, and the broth was light and fragrant.  This was the real deal.  This is a very small restaurant with limited seating, but the wait staff move very quickly and ensure you get what you need.  I would recommend this place to others trying to find a great bowl of pho in the tenderloin.
author: Bob P.

description:
Sunday night wandering around Tenderloin/Little Saigon trying to find a Vietnamese place.  Must've been late b/c tons of places were closed.  Got lucky and came in here.

Biggest pho I've ever seen in my life!!!!!!

Already, regular phos are way too big to finish.  Here they are just insane!  Very nice hole in the wall.  Cheap and good.  One of us had a beef pho, the other had bun vermicelli with bbq pork.

two thumbs up.
author: Anita S.

description:
Solid place worth returning to, but not the best in the world.

Environment: 3/5
There's a good amount of seating downstairs and upstairs. I've been here with groups of 8-12 and we've been seated pretty close together and rather quickly. It's a Vietnamese place in the Tenderloin, so it's a little dirty and old. The kitchen area is at the front of the store, and groups seated closest can watch as they put meat and bones into the pots.

Neighborhood is shady, but there's a lot of street parking, although it's metered. Remember to keep valuables hidden away in the trunk and to lock up!

Food: 4/5
Prices are okay. $7.75 for the #1 combo, and $1 for extra noodles. I'm not sure they gave me much extra noodles though. (Tip: When asking for extra noodles, ask from them on the side and add it to your bowl yourself to make sure they give a good amount! I forgot to do that today!)

The soup is pretty good. You can taste that they cook an honest amount of beef and bones into the broth. The chicken broth was a bit sweet though--yes, like sugary sweet. Meat is generous enough and noodles are a perfect texture.

Service: 4/5
Fast and friendly enough. Nothing fancy. No complaints.
author: Joseph T.

description:
Had my usual pho tai after a night of drinking.  I remember one time in san jose at pho y 1 and how that hit the spot so well in this same situation.  But not so at pho 2000 this time for me.  The broth was very clean and thin, but a bit oily and lacked depth of beef flavors.  The meat and noodles were fine, both good portions and meat was sliced thin and nice to have on side to dip in for a only a few seconds.  The broth was very hot, used some mung bean sprouts to cool it down but it still stayed very hot to the end, which is a plus.  

BBQ Pork, Eggroll with rice #31.  Had regular long grain, jasmine rice, wish they would have broken rice but I didn't expect it anyway.  It would have been a nice surprise.  Rice dish was on dry side for both rice and meat.

Restaurant was packed on a Sunday afternoon.  Service a bit slower than normal for a pho spot.
author: Kevin L.

description: As authentic as it gets! Their pho is the best thing one can come across in SF and worth the buck. Only bad thing is that they could have more meat in their pho, but it's still a good portion and quality is good
author: Alexandra T.

description: The food was great! Unfortunately, that's the only good thing I can say about this. The service wasn't great. The wait time was short, but halfway into waiting for our food, we were asked to move tables for no reason. We asked for separate drinks and never received them. We waited about 15 minutes for our check after having to ask, before being told to go downstairs to pay. And after I was finished eating, we noticed bugs flying around our food!!
author: Camyryn T.

description: I discovered this place only because I was too impatient to wait on Turtle Tower and refused to share a table with a stranger at TT so I hopped on next door to Pho2000 by default.  I actually like Pho2000 better than TT because it has a wider variety of Vietnamese compared to TT's main staple, the Pho dish.  I recommend the grilled pork vermicelli noodles and Vietnamese crepe.  It's really cheap considering the amount of food you get and it doesn't fall short on flavor either.
author: Bailey N.

description: Good value Pho with the big bowl!! I ordered #6 in small size but it came pretty big (lol). The broth is pretty sweet. The first touch was ok but felt sweet in my throst. I thought it was from MSG. Anyway I finished my bowl and I like it.
author: Orange S.

description: We got the beef cut and brisket pho and vermicelli pork noodle. Both dishes were good. Service is quick, the place is pretty run down and not super clean. Dishes are fairly priced at $8-9. They only take cash- no card!
author: Susannah H.

description:
A great find for an adventurous bowl of pho. 

Actually, I was originally headed to Turtle Tower, but they close after 5PM. Thankfully, Pho 2000 opens for dinner and it was a splendid substitute.

Although most opt for the noodle soup, I got the BBQ Pork and Egg Roll over rice. It also comes with a side bowl of chicken soup, which was a pleasant surprise. For an $8 plate, you truly cannot get a better deal for the tasty vietnamese food you get. 

Service was also prompt and efficient as is expected with most vietnamese restaurants.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
I honestly don't know how the pho restaurants that line the streets nearby stay in business. I tried three of them, before making it to Pho 2000, and I will never be going back to those other three again! 

This review is really only for their pho (tai), because I didn't get anything else. I typically don't get anything else at Vietnamese restaurants. I wish I had more friends -- or SOME friends. I always have to eat alone, thus I'm only able to get one dish. On another note, tears can really enhance the flavor of your pho broth.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Seems like all the good reviews about this place were written by friends and family, especially because they all sound alike concerning flavor, portions and service. 
If you read the less favorable reviews, you'll get a much better picture about this place - not too clean, chinzy on protein and veges, mediocre flavors at best.
author: Kay L.

description:
CASH ONLY.  Tried out Pho 2000 during the Tet Festival Sun 2/3/13.  They have 2 dining rooms, and they sent me upstairs.  I thought the two-top table they wanted me to sit at was too dark, & they turned on the lights for me, nice.

FREE hot tea brought to me without asking.

I asked for water, then Vietnamese Iced Coffee on menu was $2.99, but on my bill it was $3.25.

Dish I got was #1 Pho Dac Biet, Small with Hofun which is extra .75c!  The noodles were not the fat kind I like at Chinese restaurants, I read it's homemade, not sure.  Small is HUGE here!  It had some beef balls, tripe, rare & cooked sliced beef, & lots of noodles & soup.  I liked it ok.  On my bill was $7.50 (is that with tax?)

The iced coffee was brought out in the Slow-drip way which is good, not enough condensed milk for me, was really strong coffee.  I diluted it with my water.

CASH ONLY!  Restroom on bottom dining room back had an "out of order" sign, but the guy said it was working.  I guess they do that for strangers that walk in & want to use it.
author: Ann L.

description: This is usually my first place I go to, to get pho in the Tenderloin. I usually don't have to wait that long for a table and it's cheap. A lot of young tourists come here, I think they are staying at near by hostels.  The pho is good. Their banh xeo, Vietnamese pancake is very oily, but crispy. They have really ugly table cloths but reminds me of being in Vietnam. If you're a regular like me, get a stamp card. When you reach 10 pho bowls, you get a free pho or imperial rolls. I'm 4 bowls away!
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description: Delicious pho!!! The best broth.. I don't even have to add any sauces.. this is my go to spot for pho in SF, perfect on a cool day
author: Natalia M.

description: Had the worst post-holiday hangover a yr ago and my insides were burning with rage and regret.. my ex roommate suggested to find solace in a bowl of pho and I walked all over the loin to find this spot.. long story short, this place had the best pho I've ever tasted in SF not lying ladies and gents, it was delicious. The serving was huge and the imperial rolls sealed the deal for me. Cash only and make sure to leave a decent tip.
author: Marie P.

description:
Not exactly a fan of pho, I tried to accommodate my parents' appetite while visiting San Francisco and staying in Nob Hill, which is quite near Little Saigon if I recall correctly.

For early dinner, this place is clearly more crowded than other gems in the area. While the portion size is very generous like in expectation, I guess what impresses me has been the condiment.

Biased or not, the servers in the city seem rather nonchalant, or is it the weather? LOL
author: Fangfei S.

description:
My go to spot for Pho in San Francisco.  I prefer to come to Pho 2000 over the nearby Turtle Tower.  The portions are very generous, flavor is good, and they are cheap.  I usually order the small size and that fills me up.  

Remember that this is a cash only restaurant, so bring cash.  Otherwise there is a mini mart nearby, but you'll have to pay the fee.
author: Justin Y.

description: I haven't had a nice "Hot" pho for awhile! The soup has real beef bone taste! The open kitchen let you see how they prepare their excellent pho! Hands down one of the best in the city! Remember is Cash only!
author: Lori T.

description: Yas! A great place to get authentic pho for a reasonable price. For $9, you can get a large bowl of delicious pho, or around $8 for a smaller bowl which still looks filling. CASH ONLY!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I had high hopes of taking my mom to Turtle Tower before we went to the Symphony last Friday night for her birthday, but alas the TL location closes at 5PM. She had her hopes up for Pho, so we settled for Pho 2000. 

I haven't always been a picky pho-eater: back in the day, you could give me a big bowl of noodles, spicy broth, any kind of meat, and a ton of jalepenos, and I'd be good to go. I have to admit I've become more specific about my pho since I've had some of the best *cough, Turtle Tower*. But my madre was just happy to be out of the house and in a restaurant, away from the screaming little brothers of mine. She said the only pho she had ever eaten was from Fresh Choice, some six years ago, so it was a no-brainer on where to take her for dinner.

She doesn't eat meat but doesn't mind if it's been used in the broth she sips, so she ordered the Rare Steak, and I ordered the Rare Steak with Brisket and she gave me all of the meat from her soup, which proved to be entirely too much meat. Also, the noodles were thin rice noodles, rather than the *superior* large flat noodles. My bad for not asking for a substitute. The broth was rich, savory, and comforting, but no doubt swimming with MSG.

The restaurant is pretty dirty, and the restroom had no paper towels and a hand dryer that was not in a hurry.

I did appreciate that they had both Fish Sauce and Hoisen, which is not always the case. My mom was very happy with her soup, but she is a perma-optimist; I was full by the time we were shuffling out the door to the symphony, but I wasn't too thrilled with my dish. Cash only, and very inexpensive. Our bill was $15. If I do go back, I'll just make better choices for ultimate enjoyment. Or I'll just go to Turtle Tower.
author: Crystal C.

description: I go here with my coworkers at least once a week and I can say that it's pretty good. The only thing that bothers me is that it's cash only but during my time in SF I learned that it's to be expected (most places that I've been to around this area are cash only). The service is pretty fast considering I usually go with about a party of 10 and this is during the lunch rush. It's also pretty cheap and it's huge for the price!
author: Randell Kenneth R.

description:
My favorite Pho in the city!

Service is super fast and everything is delicious. I almost always get the chicken pho, it has a fresh, delicate flavor that I'm obsessed with. Everything else I've had there is equally as delicious, especially the imperial rolls!

Cash only though, so make sure to stop at the ATM on your way!
author: Anne M.

description:
Solid food consistently has the best bun bo hue I've had anywhere. Service is always very polite and quick.  They will bring you tea as soon as you sit down, which is nice.

The cleanliness is on par for somewhere in the TL.  The bathroom always has soap and paper towels, though they also use it for some limited storage.
author: Cilla T.

description:
The deep fried spring rolls here are good, but what isn't after it's been deep-fried? My issue with the food here is that the noodles are not as flavorful as I would have hoped. I've tried the Bun Rieu (Crab Noodle Soup) and the Grilled Pork Vermicelli here and thought they were both decent but nothing to get excited about. 

Needless to say, I won't be back since there are many other delicious Vietnamese food in the area, like Ngoc Mai and Ha Nam Ninh. Turtle Tower next door is a crowd-favorite as well, but I wasn't very impressed by their renowned Pho Ga (Chicken Noodle Soup - IMO very bland chicken stock.).
author: Catherine C.

description: Small place but pho was amazing! Didn't need any seasoning. Recommend and will definitely return. Service was average.
author: Kaitlin L.

description:
Came here for the first time last week and was surprised to see it right next door to turtle tower, but I guess that doesn't hurt business since each specializes in their own category. 

Pho 2000 has a wide selection of different dishes. We started off with the rolls which were really good. As usual spring rolls don't come cheap.. a plate of 6 small pieces ran at about $7. 

My friends had a regular pho dac biet and a bun bo hue. I was able to taste test each of their soups since that is what I am most pickiest about.. and the pho dac biet tasted pretty good, but something was off... I can't pin point it but it wasn't as beefy as I usually have. The bun bo hue also was a bit off... it wasn't spicy like other places that I've tasted but the flavoring was pretty tasty.

I had a bowl of bun rieu. This is by far my favorite noodle soup so I had to try it here at pho 2000 and I wasn't disappointed. It tasted really home cooked but was a bit boring but was easily fixed with some fish sauce and shrimp paste. 

Everything is pretty tasty here and I'd come back again.. but parking is a bit of a pain in this area, so be prepared to look around and pay for metered parking.
author: Tiff C.

description:
Perfect for a cold SF day. Immediately served some tea. Got the #2 (Pho with rare beef slices and beef meatballs) and finished off the whole bowl even though I wasn't even that hungry. Also shared the vegetable rolls (fresh) with my friends. They add in sauteed vegetables too and its delish. 

Super casual, friendly service. Clean. Cheap. $30 for 3 meals and a starter. Definitely coming back.
author: Amy C.

description:
My friends and I were in the city after a night of partying (shout out to Soulection) and wanted something to help us with our headaches (light hangover) before hitting the road back to Sacramento. I looked up places in the area on Yelp (of course) and there were so many restaurants in just a two block radius, so I had to read some of the reviews to get an idea of what would be our best bang for our buck. I stumbled upon Pho 2000 and the reviews said this place was legit. Ok, let's see for ourselves. Pho 2000 was literally a block away from the hotel we were staying at so we walked over.

The service was fast and friendly. And OMG the Pho was on point! I got the House Special (Combo) with Meat ball, Rare steak, Brisket, Tendon, Tripe, Onion, Cilantro, Green onion. I also threw in the basil, Jalapeño with sriracha sauce. BOMB.COM it was so good and just what we needed after a long night of dancing and party. It literally brought us back to life. The flavor of the broth was perfect! There was no need to add anything to the broth like most places I've been to in the past. 

If you're ever in this area of San Francisco and want some amazing Pho, then definitely stop by Pho 2000 and get you PHO ON!
author: Jovon T.

description: Came here before the opera.  Got the #14. it's a really tasty broth with a little bit of heat.  I like the combination of meats they add.  next time i might switch it up, but this one is great
author: J J W.

description:
Had a craving for pho yesterday, and Pho 2000 was close by. Ordered the large special pho, and it didn't take too long for it to arrive.

I usually like to have my pho without any additional sauce, and as much bean sprout and basil as possible. Pho 2000's vegetable plate also came with what looks like sliced fresh jalapeño, which is something new for me.

First tasting of the broth did not impress me. It was a bit too salty for my taste, and strangely, the broth had strong hints (stronger than every pho I've tasted so far) of both sweetness and sourness, despite my choice to not add any sauce or lime juice. I ended up not finishing the broth.

The texture of the rice noodle was OK, but not the best I've had. The amount of meat (and other products usually found in a bowl of pho) served was a somewhat small, but otherwise tasty.
author: Da W.

description:
The bf and I decided to try a new pho place and so we came here today and I really enjoyed what I had. The bf on the other hand, not so much...

We came around lunch time so it was starting to get crowded. We ended up sitting upstairs. The place is a decent size and I really like that they have an upstairs area although it's quite small, I didn't feel cramped at all. 

I ordered a small #13, which was the pho ga (chicken) noodle soup and the bf ordered the veggie pho because they didn't have the beef one that he gets everywhere else. He also ordered the BBQ pork rice plate that came with an imperial roll. 

Our food came out pretty fast. So, I was happy about that. This was the first time I tasted the actual broth before I added the hoisin and sriracha and I must say that the broth alone was really flavorful. It wasn't salty or anything. The chicken was predominantly white meat with about 2-3 dark pieces. The noodles were cooked nicely. 

The bf had to add about 4 lemons into his veggie pho because he said the broth was bland and I thought the same thing when he asked me to try it. There wasn't much flavor in it at all. But, besides that, he did like his rice plate. He said the pork wasn't overcooked, the rice was good, and the imperial roll was perfectly fried.  

Service was good. Great portions! I also liked how there's complimentary hot tea. The only thing that I found odd was that our waiter didn't ask if we wanted anything else to drink. He was good about bringing us extra lemons for the bf's soup though. Anyway, our total was $20.90 before tip and that was for 2 bowls of pho and a rice plate. Good deal!
author: Fallon P.

description:
Every time I visit SF, this my go to Pho spot!  
its in a shifty neighborhood so go during the day with people.

Thumbs up:
-good C.S. for asian restaurant
-good pho and egg rolls
-you get what you pay for
-pretty clean for hole in wall and location

Thumbs down:
-Location, not for the faint at heart in Tenderloin district


Will be back when in SF.
author: Myly F.

description:
OK so the only reason I give it a 4 star is because of the slummy neighborhood where the restaurant is located.  

However, I absolutely enjoyed my lunch. I had a  large pho Tai which was extremely tasty. I would mention the portion size was very average for a large. We also had the shrimp and pork rolls- they were good but nothing abnormally special. 

Definitely a great bowl of pho, clean interior, and nice staff. I'll be back for sure.
author: Brutus G.

description: One of the best pho places we tried during our trip to the US. We had pho bo and pho ga. The soup was very fragrant and tasted just right. Must try if you are a pho lover!
author: Lum Kit L.

description:
I've tried countless pho in San Francisco, and I have to say that Pho 2000 has the best pho in the city. The beef melts in your mouth, and the broth is perfectly salty and flavored. Good service and plenty of seating. 

Cash only!
author: Lin C.

description:
Exactly the way pho should be! The broth was meaty, packed with tons of flavor and talk about a generous serving for a small bowl- I could barely finish it. Definitely the come to spot for pho. 

However, don't expect it to have freshly squeezed orange juice, yep, that's what our neighbors tried to order- along with asking "what is your best dish here- the rice or the pho?" #rollseyes 

Otherwise, service is quick but attentive and you can expect to get in and out in less than half an hour. I think just found my new post-hangover spot!
author: Sherina Y.

description:
My favorite pho place in the city. Food is always delicious, portions are massive, and prices are fair. Not in the best neighborhood, but the trek out here is worth it. 

I usually get the large #1 special combination pho with steak, beef balls, and tripe. It always comes out fast and piping hot accompanied by the usual plate of garnishes which include bean sprouts, jalapeños, basil, and lemon or lime wedges. Tear the sweet basil into the hot broth and it becomes even more fragrant. Add the bean sprouts for a nice crunch, jalapeños for a spicy kick, and a squeeze of lemon or lime juice. 

The bun bo hue is my second go-to and also one of the better versions that I've had. A mildly spicy beef soup with large chunks of beef, blood sausage, and vermicelli noodle. The broth is rich and beefy. I like to add their house-made garlic chili sauce and an extra squeeze of lime to make it extra spicy and sour. The pork chop rice plate with fried egg on top is also excellent - comes with 2 large pork chops, rice, egg cake, and a side of soup.
author: Elaine L.

description: So this review is from the 2nd back to back visit in the same week..oct29 and nov1, 2016.. i came in around the lunch time rush and was quickly seated and given a menu and hot tea upon being seated. Side note: real estate is premium and because i was solo, i was seated in a table for 4 with one other elderly gent..after looking over the menu, the #1  soup bowl seemed to cover what i was looking for, all the meats possible..about 2 minutes later the same guy whom seated me probably seated and served like 10 people and saw that i had those "im ready to order eyes" and came in for the order and was back before i could eveb get my setup of utensils and such..realistically it was 2min tops but it was fast! Overall, I was impressed with clarity, broth flavor and lastly the variety of the meats. I checked them out being new to the area while lyft driving and i had to give them 5 stars.. Small, quaint, and it smells great!
author: Juan B.

description:
Bottom line: Decent Vietnamese food. Would go back but wouldn't suggest to others. 

Maybe it's blasphemy that I didn't get pho since pho is in their name but I was hankering for some rice. Happens to us all, right...? I ordered the Com Cha Gio Thit Nuong (BBQ pork with egg roll over rice). The egg roll was the highlight. It was crunchy and very delicious mmmm. I wish I just ordered the imperial rolls after eating them. The BBQ pork was, meh. Finally the rice was decent not excellent but fine. They are not trying to be a culinary leader and that's fine. I'll be back because the portion was large, inexpensive and arrived quick. I will try the beef pho next time. 

Random note: This place has an upstairs and if you sit near banister it makes for some good people watching. Creepy? Hopefully not too much :X
author: Matthew T.

description: My new fave cha gio spot! Got the bbq pork bun w egg rolls. Bbq pork had a nice grill and lemongrassy flavor. Egg rolls - deep fried to perfection, had just the right of used oil taste, not overfilled with taro but had a great balance of clear vermicelli noodle, pork and black fungus. I wish they had a little more grilled pork but other than that, big thumbs up!
author: dianne l.

description: Just finish a bus tour and came to this spot for some grub. Perfect food for a cold day!!! Don't let the outside appearance fool you..great service with great pho..perfect combo. The portion are high too. Will definitely be hitting this joint again before heading back to Dallas!
author: J L.

description: We go here pretty regularly for their pho. It's not the best, but it's totally good enough if you are craving for Pho and don't want to drive an hour to San Jose to get the best. I always get broiled bean sprouts so the soup doesn't cool down when I put the sprouts in my soup. The vegetable plates always look fresh when they come out, which is very important to me. Tried the fish claypot just recently and it was pretty good as well. You do have to order the rice separately though. The service is efficient. The restaurant is also pretty clean, considering it's in the TL. We will continue coming here as long as we live in the city.
author: N N.

description:
Got pho dac biet small and it was so fulfilling I was ready to crawl in my bed and K.O. Nothing beats pho from Little Saigon in the OC but this was pretty good. My only complaint: I wish there was more tripe or bigger pieces of it in my bowl. 

Also tried the imperial rolls, the kind made with rice paper. Fried deliciousness!
author: Krystal L.

description:
The gist: Yeah, 4 stars average is about right. The Pho is pretty darn good, cheap (get a small. I have a hearty appetite and a small did me just fine). I'd love to try the Imperial Rolls. That sounds way better than "egg" roll. Imperial? Shit, that sounds awesome.

I like the double-decker thing going on with some skylight. That gave it a nice feel that a lot of other restaurants in the area are lacking. I really like Lers Ros' food, but I always feel a little uncomfortable in that big never-ending space. It's like eating in a Best Buy.

But Pho 2000 is tasty, even if you're a vegetarian - that's what I ordered. 3 different green veggies, all pretty tasty. I'd go back probably.
author: Ari F.

description:
Ever wake up early the morning after a night out, but no pho place is open until hours later? Yeah, that happens to me all the time. But you won't have that problem here because the hours are great yay.

The pho here is so good and I really couldn't ask for more, figuratively and literally (the portions are big). I like that you can see them cooking the pho because who doesn't like seeing that they are willing to let you see how they cook the food? Anyway, the broth, noodles, and meat were all amazing. All this for a good price too. I can't wait to be back!

CASH ONLY!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I haven't had Vietnamese food in ages and this was a reminder of what I've been missing out on all these years. My brother and I came here after a workout and were feeling ravenous. We started out with the imperial rolls that were crisp and steaming hot. It was a colorful dish and was meaty and filling. Wrapped with lettuce, it was a fresh starter.

Next we had the ban xeoh (the crispy egg crepe) This is a classic dish I remember eating all the time when I was younger. It was filled with pork while having a few shrimps. It wasn't as large as I would have hoped but delivered some clean and light flavor when accompanied with fish sauce. 

I got the mint chicken as my main course. It was hoping for something more salty because the sweetness of the dish was a bit overpowering. The mint flavor also didn't come through the dish as well as I liked. Of course, I still consumed it all.

My brother greatly enjoyed his pho with extra noodles. It was massive!!! And the broth without MSG still tasted pretty good.
author: Michael C.

description: When life gives u the tenderloin, make it a priority to grab a steaming hot bowl of magic from this place. Good lord is this broth heaven! They are fast, to the point and really delivered exactly what I hoped for. Authentic soul in a bowl. Had the eggrolls and pho ga on a rainy day here and was not disappointed. Totally reasonable and easy to find!
author: Crys M.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets!

No other way to put it. Broth? Flavorful and is literally crack - I never leave a drop of it behind even after getting the large bowl. Meat? Plentiful and .... meaty. Noodles? Perfect bounciness and consistency. Service? Not bad but who cares about service when they have pho as good as this. My mouth is watering as I'm writing this review. I'm going to have high blood pressure soon from all the sodium I've ingested due to coming here multiple times a week...
author: Vincent L.

description: Great pho. High quality, plenty of goodies, and large, which is rare in the city. Worth the trip, altho open hours can be suspect. Cash only
author: Linn K.

description:
Pretty darn delicious. The broth is very tasty without being salty or oily. The meat is absolutely fantastic--especially for pho. It's tender without being ultra fatty or gross looking. I actually really loved my meal here and I only put in a couple drops of sirracha instead of the half cup I normally use, because it just didn't need it.

The people who work here are really friendly. But be prepared to make friends with strangers! All of the tables are four seats or more and they will seat you with people you don't know. I actually think that's really cool, but I know it might be a turn off for some.
author: Cori N.

description: Not the four stars I have expected. I have tried many pho restaurants across the state, and this one was very basic. The service was that great, you pack you own food and menu wasn't given to me
author: Mandy Z.

description:
Note they only accept cash!
I went to the Asian Art Museum nearby  with my fiancee and yelped to find a good place to get lunch. Pho 2000 was packed but the wait time was only a few minutes. He got beef pho which he said was yummy and I had a noodle bowl with beef. I loved the sauce and flavor combo and highly recoomend it. Also the lemon soda is great you get lemon juice with sugar in a glass with club soda to mix into it.
author: Lillian P.

description:
Firat if all, the portions are excellent. The fried egg rolls were crispy and well worth the price. The pho taste like, really, any other pho to me. I ordered the combination large and there were plenty of ingredients. I was stuffed.

Service was great, too. 

However, I had the unfortunate seat facing the kitchen. I was able to see the guy washing dishes, and let's just say...not the most sanitary.

But then again, which pho place is ever considered "clean"?
author: Justin L.

description: Great pho, I got the #3. Great prices. The location leaves a lot to be desired considering its proximity to the TL but that adds to the charm of finding that delicious, hole-in-the-wall restaurant.
author: Wes H.

description: This was pretty average. Nothing too special about this place. I had the rare steak pho and it was just ok. Got a rice plate for my daughter, the pork chops and rice with shredded pork, there was a lot of rice, but the pork chop was super small. It looked like a bone with few pieces of meat hanging off it. It tasted good though lol.I don't think I'll be coming by here anytime soon, maybe I'll try that turtle place next door.
author: Jamie B.

description: Good pho.  Ordered number 1.  Big bowl and came with good portion of Bean sprouts/basils.  You get the regular service and decor like most of the other yummy pho places.
author: Will C.

description: Get the veggie pho. So good! You won't miss the meat. Although their beef Phos are awesome too. Open kitchen layout is nice too. Service is quick too. One of my favorite pho joints in the city!
author: Shannon L.

description:
I was looking for a quick fix of pho on a cold day and their next door North Vietnamese style pho neighbor was being remodeled. Consensus? It'll do for the usual pho tai but it's nothing to write home about.

Broth was kind of light, not bland, yet neither packed with flavor. Having had murky yet flavorful pho being the standard in San Jose or in Westminster, this place was the definition of okay. It's somewhat light on the msg, perhaps that's why I wasn't slurping water down like a dog or impressed with it's flavor. The beef was notably tender, soup came hot, and the large portion was bigger than the status quo. Quick service, decently clean restaurant.

Running around $8 for a large pho, it's okay for a SF pho store, I just wouldn't ever go out of my way to eat here.
author: Steven C.

description:
This place is one of our house's go-to hangover spots. Decently priced and it's got veggie soup base so all you vegetarians can go wild. 

It's got all the standard Vietnamese noodle house fare. I usually get the special combo large. It's exactly as you would expect. 

The vermicelli fish sauce bowls are pretty good too.  (Bun?) am I spelling that correctly? Man I could go for some right now actually.
author: Calvin L.

description:
Great alternative to Turtle Tower right next to them.  Who would have thought? A hole in the wall.  You walk in and the kitchen is on your left hand side.  There you can see the HUGE pot brewing the pho broth.  Downstairs seats about 20 people and they have an upstairs which seats 15 people.  

This place offers pho, bun rieu, and rice plates.  A size Small is like a size Large.  Great price and fast service.  The rice plates look yummy too, they sure don't skimp with the rice.
 
Wish I knew this place existed.  I guess I'm so Pho 2000 and late!
author: Elliot Y.

description:
No frills but the food is good.    I ate here and tried the basics #1 combo pho.  It was a little greasier than most pho I've had but the flavor was really good and the meat was very tender.  I love my pho and I enjoyed this one.  I came here for dinner right before a movie at AMC, which is a block away.

Pros:
1.  Tasty Pho
2.  Reasonably priced
3.  Food came out really fast.  That's good because when you need pho... you need pho.
4,  Vietnamese coffee was really strong but I really enjoyed it.
5.  Can't really go wrong with this place.

Cons:
1.  Soup could have been ever so slightly hotter but it was still really good.  This is me just being picky.
author: Jensen L.

description: It's tiny, there's only one unisex restroom, but the food is amazing. A "small" bowl  of pho is big enough to satisfy most people's hunger. If you're in Tenderloin aka Little Saigon, you should go to this place for a noodles and meat in a war
author: Andrew J.

description: Wow excellent Pho!! Best ever. I don't want to write a good review cause I want to keep this a hidden gem (albeit it is not in the prettiest neighborhood! Lock your doors and hide your valuables lol) but it is worth going there ! Price point is one you can not complain about and the service is quick and amazing although you may have to share a table it's worth it!
author: Rodney C.

description:
After attending the historical SF Giants victory parade, my friends and I were famished! We had only been snacking of PB&J sandwiches since 6am. I was also craving some pho from the gloomy start of the early morning.

***WARNING*** This place doesn't have that much seating room. Our party of six was seated upstairs. It was a very tight fit up there. I ordered a large #10, rice noodle with beef ball pho. Five minutes later after ordering, my order comes out. That was very impressively quick. The broth was piping hot. The noodles were soft and chewy. The beef balls were tasty. PAUSE! Other than that everyone enjoyed their meals.

I'm glad I didn't have to call in sick this day. I caught a couple of glimpses of myself and friends on the parade rerun.
author: Jay G.
