description: Amazing soup. We got the seafood and rare steak pho. My husband does not like soup but he loved the pho flavors and his soup. Service is fast too. The shrimp and pork rolls are delicious!
author: Rena L.

description: Good price, food and services. My favorite is Pho (#2) and #28 and others random dishes. Don't forget to bring cash! Unique kitchen in the front and no odor smell. Got table on 1st floor and upstair.
author: Minhnistah M.

description: Got their small combination pho. This came with tons of noodles and good amount of meat. The price was super cheap. Maybe 7 or 6 bucks. Service is fast. It's located in the Tenderloin area and if you're not familiar with San Francisco this is the hood. Their pho was good.  have no complaint. I just wish it looked nice inside but I'm giving this a 5 star because soup and price were great.
author: Samantha P.

description: I tried this place out because I love the Pho 2000 in Los Angeles and when I was visiting SF I saw there was one there so I had to try it. The service was really fast just like in most Pho restaurants. The food tho, not as good as I expected. The soup is really strongly seasoned and the noodles were paste-ish. Ill stick to Pho 2000 in LA.
author: Edy R.

description:
Man... if this was closer to my work, I might have it every other day (being realistic here...) for lunch.  Cheap, FAST, and deliciously filling.

Walked in.. glanced at the menu.. ordered a #12.. and within minutes, a hot, savory, soothing bowl of pho with rare steak and brisket magically appeared before me.  The steam hit my face and made me love-stoned and light-headed.  Threw in the entire plate of bean sprouts, jalapeno peppers, sriracha and hoisin into the rich broth and gently stirred to perfection.  READY FOR NOMSIN!

.........................
................
........
...

The sadness seeps in when I find myself fishing for the final bits of noodle and bean sprouts in the pool of sodium-enriched soup.  So I was a bit thirsty afterwards... ok...really thirsty... just balanced it out by drinking more water!  Pwn.  The meat is soooo tender and soft.  *melt

Pho 2000.. you have bewitched me.
author: Kat C.

description: This is one of the b st pho joints in the area yeah it's in the TL but don't let that stop you. Food is great and service is good. It's great on a cold foggy day or if you aren't feeling well. This pho wil put you back on track
author: Terry L.

description:
This is our new go-to pho place.  I like their egg rolls and grilled pork bun (no mint or bean sprouts!).  They are fast.

Make sure you get your frequency card--buy 10 bowls of pho and you get a free dish of egg rolls!
author: C L.

description:
You have many choices for pho and Vietnamese cuisine in the Little Saigon community next to the SF Civic Center.

For pho, I've tried several restaurants in the area.  But my favorite is Pho2000.  They have an open kitchen which is very transparent to the diners.  You can see that it is very clean as is the dining room and the utensils on the table.

I always get the large #1 special pho with the rare beef on the side.  It is a truly large bowl with lots of noodles, flank beef, beef balls, tripe and tendons.  The broth is very flavorful and not bland like some other places.  At $6.99, the price is very reasonable for the quality and the amount of beef and noodles you get.  If you're not that hungry, you can get the smaller bowl at $6.25.  

The service is efficient and friendly too.  

Overall, a great place for a great bowl of pho,
author: Al L.

description:
Came here on a Thursday afternoon as Turtle Tower right next door doesn't open on Thursdays. Had a bowl of beef noodle soup and I'd say there was nothing special about it. I appreciated the photos displayed on the restaurant window though, and their rice plates did look quite delicious, so I wouldn't mind trying that next time. 

There was a table next to mine that asked for a correction to their dish as they were vegetarian and had gotten a veggie noodle soup but with beef broth I think...and the staff was OK accommodating their request  even though they already served what the customers had initially ordered. So even though this place is just average, I would give them 4 stars.

The real must-try in the city (I've heard) is still Turtle Tower though.
author: Jackie C.

description: Love this Pho. Great portions (go for the large), inexpensive, and pretty good appetizers as well.
author: Hank K.

description:
I've eaten Pho all over the world. Literally 50+ places. This is the best. Hands down. All of the neighboring places are garbage by comparison.

I've been here 20+ times. I've only ordered Pho Ga.  I'm ashamed that I'm just now writing a review.

Eat here. Thank me later
author: Saht H.

description:
I was craving for Pho on a cold day and didn't know where to go so I went on Yelp and did some searching.  I was skeptical to try it, but took my chances.  The place is small and have another section on second floor.  

Upon entering in you see chef lady carefully cooking up orders and you can smell the rich flavor of the Pho broth cooking.  They use some humongous pots to boil the soups.  The server / waiter escorted me to my table and handed me a menu.

I was ready, i just skimmed through the menu and in my mind I already knew i wanted Pho so i got the Pho Dac Biet , Combination rice noodle soup.  It comes with thin raw steak, meatballs, brisket, and tripe.  You will also get a side of raw bean sprouts, Thai basil, jalapenos, and either lemon or lime.  On the table their is Hoisin Sauce and Sirachai sauce to eat along with your noodle soup.  Don't worry about the raw steak, once they add the soup it will literally cook it   It will also be garnish with chopped onions, cilantro and thinly sliced onions on top of the soup.

The soup is blazing hot and delicious.  It is not too salty nor oily it is just perfect.  A sip of this soup and you are addicted.  I like how this place gives you a option to use in house chopsticks or disposable wooden ones.

Overall this is the spot, One of my favorites place that i go to for Pho and only Pho.  Cash only and if you plan to come back ask for a stamp card so you can collect stamps and receive a free bowl of pho or appetizer.  

Cash only

Parking is only street and meter.  Be careful where you park and make sure you feed the meter or get ticketed.  Plenty of crack heads and don't leave valuables are anything visible.  This is in the Tenderloin, not the best place.
author: Kenneth Y.

description:
Pho 2000...got me feelin' like it's OVAHHHHH 9000!!!!! (get it? if not, just move on to review)

Was brought here by friends on a Wednesday night around 6:30PM. Not too crowded, the restaurant was pretty spacious. Ordered a small Seafood rice noodle soup for around $8. Soup was BOMB because it wasn't too oily and portion size was relatively big. Came with lots of seafood including shrimp, squid, crab, and fish balls. To be honest why I rated this place so high is because everything else everyone ordered was BOMB too. Pho 2000 can't do no wrong.

Great service, fast service, but CASH ONLY. Great thing is, you can pay separate. And don't forget to grab some guava candy on your way out. The area can get a little sketch at night but warm yourself up with some noodle soup and Imperial rolls to feel suddenly courageous.
author: Ting Jung L.

description: This place is amazing. Traditional, simple, great people, great ambience, awesome service, fast and efficient! Authentic vietnamese
author: Alejandro M.

description: Best lunch spot in this area! Super tasty soup base for all of their noodle soups. #1 and #14 is absolutely amazing. This place is quick too, in and out within 30 min if you eat fast like me :).
author: Raymond L.

description: Really good pho. I live in the neighborhood and have eaten at a lot of Vietnamese restaurants. Hands down the best pho in town.
author: Maya S.

description: Personally think either Pho 2000 or Yummy Yummy hold the top spot as far as pho goes in SF. Turtle tower's broth is really fatty and I like to do veggies with chicken broth. I usually order from YY when I'm too lazy to lift my butt off my couch cause they deliver, but if Im out on the prowl its Pho 2k all the way. I think the pho ga is awesome, but like I said, you know my order. The veggie pho comes with a lot of fixins - zucchini, carrot, boc choy, onions, broccoli... and their chicken broth has some kind of sweet 5-spice flavor that makes it unreal. Noods cooked perfect too. 10/10! But they close at 8PM FYI.
author: Robbie S.

description: I come here maybe once a month. Best pho I've had so far. Also I get the h. Appetizer and add it to my steak pho soooo good. And it's a pho place open late! Who can compete with this!
author: Fatima H.

description: My favorite pho place in the Bay Area.  I travel past 5-10 other good pho places on the way to get here.  Still worth it
author: Harlan C.

description:
Came here on one of those mornings when you wake up thinking ugh... I need brothy noodles. Yep. I'm hungover.

I've had this place bookmarked for the long time since the reviews are pretty awesome but I was really disappointed. 

I ordered the bun rieu and it left something more to be desired. There was only shredded crab and tomatoes in the soup. The side of vegetables only came with a little shredded cabbage,
a little bit of mint leaves, and some bean sprouts. There was also less than average amount of noodles. What was lacking was the pate and more vegetables. 

I do appreciate a pho place that opens early mornings for those hungover mornings and you can't wait until 10 or 11. Maybe their pho is better? :T I'll readjust the review once i try their pho.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Decent pho for a weekend hangover... Place is small and def in the ghetto. But that's why I love it.  Doesn't compare to San Jose, but it'll do for me in SF.  

Got the Pho (decent), BBH - short for Bun Bo Hue for all my white friends (not good to me since I'm super picky with BBH, but my non viet friend liked it), and Cha Goi (fried imperial rolls) - came with the fixings - good.  

The viet ice coffee was decent also.
author: Vicky T.

description: Big portions, fresh veggies, delectable and tasty broth, quick and friendly service and cheap price. Um, how can you not love this place? Cash only.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Nice little cheapy Pho place in the 'Loin. $7 for a bowl of will-stuff-you-full-o-pho pho and all the fixins. So far it's the best pho I've tried in the neighborhood. 

We also tried spring rolls and another type of soup with pig's blood and beef. Both good as well. The place was clean and fairly busy on a saturday afternoon. Staff were friendly and attentive. 

They don't deliver, and they're not open late, so this place strikes me as more of a lunch or early dinner spot. 

The open kitchen is neat -- there was a gigantor pot of pho brewing on the stove. Seriously massive. I had to take a picture.
author: Rob R.

description: Good food and service. I only tried pho but they seem to have a lot of other good items. Like all places in tenderloin, the real question is how stab worthy is this place? I'll give it two knifes.
author: K T.

description:
I chose Pho 2000, not wanting to bear the wait at Turtle Tower next door. 

Hungry, I ordered their vermicelli cold salad with imperial rolls. It was tasty, although not as tasty as the #47 at Golden Star (GS) in Chinatown. (Note to Self: Stop ordering this dish at other places and order something new).

Service was prompt and kind. The restaurant had a high ceiling and was comfortable except for the ambient clang of dish washing from the back kitchen. Perhaps it would help to put a door back there to allow diners to eat in peace.
author: Cathy K.

description:
* CHICKEN PHO (~$8):
Better at Turtle Tower, traditional pho flavors. Chicken broth on the sweet side.

* Bun is just OK....

* PORKCHOP OVER RICE (~$8.50) - 4 STARS:
I like that they have a generous portion of porkchop served over rice and with a side of steamed sweetened/soy/noodle egg thing. 

* BUN BO HUE (~$8.50) - 3.5 STARS:
A good alternative to Tin, with a thinner beef-heavy broth. Tin's broth is a little more tomatoy and chock full of ingredients, while this version tastes cleaner. Large size only.

* BEEF PHO ($7.40) - 3.5 STARS:
Good, standard beef pho. Nice and salty, and a little light on the toppings (tendon, tripe, beef ball, rare steak). Still prefer Bodega and Tin but this is a cheap convenient option in the TL.
author: Jess C.

description: Good pho, good services, everything's good but Cash Only, so 4 stars from me. will be back for sure.
author: Sloan L.

description:
Pho 2000 is a decent alternative when other iconic places in the Tenderloin are fully packed. With its clean and humble ambiance, there is an open kitchen upon entering where Southeast Asian spices and humongous pots of simmering broths can be seen on display. The upper floor is hardly used and the interior is eye-pleasing with a soft yellow and dark brown décor nicely strung together. At times they would put sports on TV but otherwise the background Vietnamese music is filled with love tales that can get pretty nostalgic regardless one speaks the language or not. 

I came on two occasions to try their noodle soup. My order of bun bo hue (6.75) came with a huge bowl of thick vermicelli with plenty of beef, beef briskets, steam pork, pig's blood, and a side dish of fresh cabbage, bean sprouts and other types of veggies. I thought the meat combination was decent with pig's blood nicely cubed to ignite an element of street authenticity. The soup however was bland and needed an identity for it to impress. My follow up visit further confirmed this perception as my huge bowl of pho ga ($6.25) had a generous set of rice noodles that had great texture with decent amount of hand pulled chicken. This time the soup was nicely flavored by spices and fish sauce but the deep essences of a good chicken broth was missing from the equation. My side dish of basil and bean sprouts was not super fresh but still manageable. 

Both visits have rendered similar experiences as their large portions, decent prices and Southern authenticity were noticeable but these contributions were also overshadowed by a doubtful broth--or what I would call it a "noodles in need of a soul" experience. Service is never chatty but efficient. This place is not going to be my top choices in the Tenderloin but it was still good to know what I can expect from them. 3 stars for the two legit but decent experiences with the surrounding competition still much preferred.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Giving up land meat for lent has been an interesting process in terms of eating ethnic food. I looked high and low for a pho joint that served veggie or seafood options AND meat for my meaty friends. 

Little Siagon has many a meat lovers delight but in all of SF this is the only veggie option and meat eaters option. ::cough cough:: although I wouldn't clutch my pearls if I found out that the broth was boiled with pork or beef bones. Hey I'm just a lent-atarian. 

Anyways the veggie imperial rolls were plentiful and served authentically with lettuce, noodles and cilantro/mint combo. And perfectly deep fried. 

My seafood pho was exactly what I had been craving for quite a while. Flavorful broth, noodles, shrimp, squeaky fish balls, squid and fish cake - all topped with veggies and enough saraicha to burn down a house. All for under $7 - got the small no need to overeat.

My friends beef pho looked perfect, beef slightly raw and still cooking in her bowl. 

I noticed some gentlemen smartly order a small plate of thinly sliced raw beef to dip into their pho themselves. Mental note. 

The restaurant has an open kitchen, parking was pretty easy in the area, far away from crack central and I liked the upstairs portion - very smart to use that space to sit more. 

Overall- loved the food and prices were great and I will be back.
author: Jade W.

description:
Having been to the Original Pho 2000 in Ho Chi Minh City (Formerly known as Saigon), Vietnam......I was a bit skeptical about this place. Because......they are playing off of the name of the original, even they are not affiliated. I have no plans to visit this place, but I saw it as I was driving by. I thought to myself....why not? At a minimum.....I can try it and walk away laughing as I compare it to the original.

Well.......I entered the store......and it was nice, and even had upstairs seating. Without looking at the menu......I requested a large bowl of Pho Dac Biet. The guy looked surprised and so I had to repeat it. 

The Pho came out......a huge bowl. First thing I did......is taste the broth......before I contaminated it with my condiments.

The brother.......was somewhat sweet...salty......beefy.....and had a very good balance. It had a deep taste to it, which seemed to have cooked slowly for many hours. It was not over powered by anise or cinnamon like many other poor quality Pho shops.

I hated to admit it......but it was damn good. Best I have had in a long while.

I live in Japan, and honestly.......finding decent Pho there......is like winning the lotto......sure its possible.......lol

Bottom line...........I wish they'd change the name........but I do recommend this shop to anyone in the San Fran area looking for solid Pho! This Pho is good. After you are done eating.....there are some Vietnamese shops around the area to look, taste, and purchase some other goodies as well.

PS......this shop is good.......but I still think Pho 2000 in HCMC is better. But thats just my opinion.
author: Food P.

description: Tried and true. Traveled all over town to find a decent bowl of pho and I've found it here.
author: Michael L.

description:
I had a craving for Bun following Ting A's ROTD and so we trekked over to Little Saigon. Pho 2000 looked cute from the outside and so we thought, why not. The name should have given it away, but pho is probably their specialty so come for that, not bun. 

My friend and I both ordered the same dish - bun with barbecued pork and imperial rolls. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bLa9Jm04dPersyUN7LFrvw?select=d4JMfqkDgDRzq1YbzCOYdA] It's a nice sized serving of rice vermicelli and the imperial rolls were delicious. The pork was a slight disappointment - tough and over-seasoned. All in all, it satisfied our bun craving though.  

Then we looked around us. Not one, and I mean NOBODY ELSE, had ordered anything but pho. Again perhaps the name of the place should have tipped us off, but we enviously looked at all the diners. They seemed happy... so next time, come to Pho 2000 for pho.
author: Jon L.

description:
Came here on a Monday around 1:15pm got seated right away it was pretty full.

When I walked in I saw people eating the rice dishes they looked good but I wanted to see what the pho was about

Ordered a #1 pho small, the serving size was decent and the meat tasted pretty good, but the broth was too oily and had a tangy taste I'm not used to. When I lifted up my soup spoon the bottom of it had droplets of oil stuck to the spoon, it's the first I've ever seen something like that.

Ordered a number 16 and got it with a couple pieces of hair in it, we returned it and it was better than the first one :) the waiters were apologetic so it was cool.

Waiter forgot our water but didn't feel like asking for it again because we were sitting upstairs .

This pho place is definitely one of the more affordable places in tl.



I probably would not come back for the pho , unless my friends recommended something better here.
author: DOM d.

description:
Probably one of my favorite SF spots for some salty, soupy, noodle-slurpin' goodness.  It's a small, cash-only hole in the wall, with a bunch of other miscellaneous details that I find quirky/endearing and typical of places that I like to frequent (e.g. sensual Vietnamese covers of 90s American pop songs, strange and distracting soap operas, servers who wear funny shirts).  

The pho here surpasses excellence.  The broth is deep and flavorful, and the noodles just the right degree of al dente.  I am also a fan of their bun (noodle salads), summer rolls, and catfish clay pot.  You know, all of the standard trimmings.

Another major plus is that both Lee's and Saigon Sandwich is right down the block, so you can easily meander over afterwards for some super fly post-meal snacks and pick up some dinner while you're at it too.
author: Anna C.

description:
Just a quick review~

I come here frequently and get the same thing each time, and that is the #6 soup with rare steak on the side.  The prime reason as to why I request the steak on the side is because when you're able to cook it yourself the meat is much more tender and juicy, as opposed to it being chewy and overcooked.

I also get the imperial rolls and I can truly say they are the best imperial rolls I have ever had.. So you might wanna order them!  

Service is astounding, they workers are so kind.  Prices are reasonable, I love it here!
author: Jorel C.

description: Best imperial rolls I ever had!! So licking finger good! Crisp is absolutely perfect! The pho here is also very tasty! One of my top favorite Vietnamese restaurants!! Thank you!!!!
author: anna w.

description: The pho was delicious. The service was excellent. The price was reasonable. The hot tea was free (if you eat in). And the location is motivating. Go try this place but it does get crowded during lunch time. I had the bun rui pho( sorry if I spelled it wrong) but its vermicelli noodles with ground meat and kinda like tomato soup-I went for the picture in choosing this but I'm glad I did.
author: Nixon L.

description:
Gray Boiled Beef or Gray Boiled Chicken? The Watery Oily Broth is NOT Pho-nomenal! Add a few spoons of Lemon-seeds & you've got Pho 2000!

Defenitely NOT the best Pho in SF. After my first visit I thought of giving this place 3 stars but I had to knock off a star and heres why...

Both times I ordered pho and I noticed that the rice noodles at the bottom were quite hard... perhaps dry noodles until they hit the boiling soup water? The second time I figured... alrite this has got to be something similar to them dry soups you buy in the shops... so do a bit of waiting and the hot soup covering the noodles will make them soft and edible. 

Then, its a bit of a wait before you can begin eating the noodles as you have to let them seep in the hot soup so that they can get soft. Meanwhile eat the rare steak or similar portion of meat that seems to have been boiled... which after seeing turned me off to the meat here... Not much of a fan of boiled meat. The broth was oily and lacked flavour so you really have to add sauces and get as much flavour out of the veg side but..................

The basil and bean sprouts are also not very fresh, & certainly not plentiful, dare ask for a bit more. They seemed a bit wilted the second time round and sort of set a standard. The peppers were nice and spicy and the lemon wedge was filled with seeds. Who wants Pho with Lemon Seeds?

Ive gone to pho restaurants all around Berkleey and San Francisco and this particular pho is perhaps right in the middle of both sides of the spectrum... just average. the staff here move quick and quite attentive but really the pho is just Average Pho. Pho Vietnam on Polk Street is quite better and relatively close by...
author: Julian I.

description: Got the seafood soup and it had a third of the items that are presented outside on their windows.  When I asked the waiter if they can put more because it's basically hot water with a couple of shrimps he said they can't.  So I took a picture of the photo they have outside that shows a beautiful dish and told him that those two don't match by a huge margin and he said:  "so what, that's just the advertisment".  His totally did not give a fuck what I thought probably because of all the 5 stars reviews they got.
author: josh d.

description: Friendly, cheap and affordable! My wife and I only had room in our stomachs to try the Pho but it was well worth the walk through the Tenderloin.
author: Justin R.

description:
Good food. Possibly the best viet rice plates. 
Pho soup smells good too. 

Small space even though has 2 floors. 
Weekends are THAT busy. Tight seating. 

Good service. I understand theyre in a rush but they do their best.

Good price!
author: Veranna N.

description:
Cash only, pretty fatty broth.

Overall a pretty solid spot, 7 dollars + tip for my meal. Kitchen area is pretty hustling, you can see it as you walk in.

Besides the traditional thin rice noodles, they offer flat wide noodles. Don't get them. They are pretty frail and break off easily.
author: Christophe C.

description:
The pho here is bangin'! 

Came in around 6:30 last night and was seated immediately. I ordered the Special Combination Beef Pho. It came out less than 5 minutes later!

The broth is soooooo flavorful, I hardly used any of the sauces at the table. The meat was high quality. They give you a ton of veggies, but all on the side so you can decide how much goes in. 

It's great that they're open until 8:30pm, much later than Turtle Tower Next door. It definitely is located in a sketchy part of town but the great pho, huge portions, and cheap prices make coming here entirely worth it.
author: Casey M.

description: I am upgrading my review to 5 stars. Their pho ga chicken broth is just some of the best I've ever had. Wow. Really great service and prices. One of the better spots i Little Saigon. I know they put sugar in their 5 hour broth, I've talked to female cook who makes it. I'm not sure about MSG, but if so, I like it!
author: casey c.

description: In a sketchy part of town but great authentic pho. Cheap and cheerful. No big sign, no fancy dining area. Just your typical (what seems to be) family-run hole in wall restaurant. I came here based on the reviews, 4 stars with over 300 reviews, not a bad ratio. I came back in Nov and returned in Jan. Consistent good food, friendly, fast service. Remember cash only! I will return next time Im in San Fran. Thanks for yet another great, hot meal!
author: B T.

description:
Ordered a large Bun Rieu and Coconut Juice here. Affordable, yummy and there is upstairs seating! No wonder this place is pretty packed during the weekends! 

This place is a CASH ONLY type joint, so its pretty typical for Asian cuisines. Service isn't bad and the food portions aren't sketchy either, they give you generous sized portions.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
I know this place specializes in Pho, but unfortunately (or fortunately?) I only had the pleasure of trying their rainbow drink. If you are thinking of trying this drink-- DON'T. It's not very good. The restaurant I went to in NYC has much bigger and much more flavorful versions of this ice drink. I guess I'll just have to keep looking for a restaurant that does this drink well. 

Also, if you are just getting a small item, don't sit down. They will hit you with a service charge that is going to double the bill.
author: Sherry Z.

description: Yum...cheap prices and large portions...staff were attentive... Vietnamese drip coffee is yum..Cash only!!
author: Sandra S.

description: I don't eat pho as much as I used to, but when I do this is my go to place in SF. The broth is clean, well balanced, with a hint of clove.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Shit is good.  Not just the Pho, but 85% of the menu.

Turtle Tower is great and all, but fuck waiting in line when Pho 2000 is literally two doors down.  

Here in The CIty, there are so many Vietnamese Restaurants that specialize in Pho.  In the restaurant industry, you can't survive with that much competition in such a small radius unless your shit is legit.  As a result, you end up with two quality Vietnamese restaurants that are literally 30 feet apart from each other in the TENDERLOIN, and both establishments have managed to stay in business (and expand) for more than I can recall.  

Unfortunately, because of the side by side competition they endure, Pho 2000 has been hit by the "Tapioca" effect.  For those who aren't familiar, the "Tapioca" effect is a phenomenon where the target demographic (e.g.12-25 year olds for Tapioca) for the cuisine or product in question is presented with 8 different business's that all offer the same items on their menu.  For some reason, despite all 8 places have more or less the same quality of food, a social trend will suddenly infiltrate the entire customer base, and you end up with hundreds of people lining up and waiting for hours to get a menu item that is available from 7 other places and is overall identical to what they'll get at the popular joint.  Confused?  I don't get it either.

Anyways, the only thing that sucks about this place is when you're seated on the first floor and they're a cash only establishment.
author: Alex S.

description: Like many others before me, I came here as a plan B to turtle tower being closed. The soup was very good and comparable to the soup base used at turtle tower. Good pho, would come again, maybe even over turtle tower.
author: Kent Z.

description:
My boyfriend and I go every week!! It's the best pho I've found in the city!  Amazing Imperial Rolls and Pho Ga.

It isn't the cleanest place but hey I'll take good food over that flaw.  The chefs are cooking in an exposed area so you know the food is fresh.

Tip: they're closed on Tuesdays
author: Kat H.

description:
This is my go-to pho restaurant in San Francisco. The food comes out quickly and the staff always takes care of my idiosyncratic needs no matter how much of a jerk I am being. The only thing holding this place back for me is that it is cash only. I guess I should expect all restaurants in this god-forsaken city to be cash only by now but I guess I'm just not smart enough to carry a bunch of cash with me all the time. I'm not trying to get mugged.

I typically order the bun thit nuong cha gio whenever I eat at Vietnamese noodle shops. It comes in a gigantic bowl here. The portions at this place are enormous. The woman ordered a bun rieu. The soup was amazing. I might have to get the bun rieu for myself next time. I like how the broth here doesn't taste like it has magic powder added to it, even though I know there's some magic powder in there somewhere.
author: Brian E.

description:
CASH ONLY!!

How have i NOT written a review of this place, which is WAY preferable to the super crowded (and uber over-rated) Turtle Tower which is sorta next door, tho it moved a few more doors down.  

When Tu Lan closed for, well about a year, we needed something a little broader than the local places.  I have lived in this area for 23 years.  

Real deal, but its also a place you could take someone new to the food and everybody can be happy.  Photos of the food for newbies as well.  

Ground chicken with wide noodles - great for a newbie or kids, but I still order it all the time.  

Bun Rieu - this is crab, egg and tomato soup and it is my favorite soup and not nearly as common as all the others, and they do it DAMN near perf. 

Cold shrimp rolls with peanut sauce - just don't argue with me

Those are my three standouts but we haven't even made it halfway through the menu.     I saw but have not tried the duck eggs and hope to try them soon, but its amazing how authentically they are able to prepare SO many dishes in so small a space.
author: Enzo L.

description: Best Pho I've found in San Francisco and the globe.  The broth is amazing and the salad rolls are spot on with the perfect peanut sauce.  Out of the hundreds of pho restaurants I've been to in North America and Vietnam the past decade...this in all honesty is definitely my number 1.  I have a mental top 10 list and I was extremely surprised at how good this Pho was and it blew all my expectations out of the water.  6/5 rating.
author: Kenton V.

description: Service is good, fast! Stopped in during lunch time (1pm on a Thursday) and served promptly. Didn't get the staple Vietnamese items on the menu, so can't judge based on that. I don't care for fish sauce that's on the sweeter side, or egg rolls that are soaked in old, dark oil, so those were turn offs for me. Plus, my lemongrass tofu wasn't very lemongrassy. That doesn't mean I wouldn't go back to try the pho!
author: Tea Lyves ..

description:
I come here way too often.

- Lots of seating, upstairs and downstairs. 
- Love how fast the food comes out, perfect for when I'm absolutely super hungry.
- Cheap!
- The people are friendly!
- Food portions are pretty big. I always get the small but my friends get the larger size and its just huuuuge.
- Apparently the beef ball is good according to my friends because they always get the combination, but during the first couple times I came, I ordered it and I really disliked it. I've been too scared to try it again but maybe someday in the future... 
For now I'll just keep ordering the beef, which is pretty good too.
author: Samantha Y.

description: meh - the shaking beef (bo luc lac) here was disappointing. nothing like in san jose. it was just white rice with stir fried beef cubes, garlic and green peppers. i could make the same at home. i like to order things that i'd have a hard time getting right at home, so i was disappointed by this dish. the flavor isn't the same as what you'd expect from classic bo luc lac. portions of beef and rice were decent though.
author: Ai N.

description: Deeeelish! Staff is cool, price is right and pho is great.
author: beverly l.

description: My favorite Pho spot in the city, never disappoints! Friendly staff, consistently great soup and attentive service. Nothing better on a cold day! Cash only.
author: Ronaldo A.

description: If you're not in San Jose, the second best place to get pho is the tenderloin and Pho 2000 exemplifies a good, warm bowl of yummy pho. I have to say that I prefer Pho 2000 over Turtle Tower simply because Pho 2000's egg rolls are top notch and absolutely delicious! I'm not really a fan of wide noodles, but the noodles at Pho 2000 aren't too wide and are just right. They also give you a good amount of beef slices in your Pho Tai! Go upstairs if you want to keep it intimate and remember, cash only!
author: Joyce E.

description:
Great place to grab Pho togo - I have only had the phoga (chicken noodle soup) and it's amazing!

Pluses:
- Big portions
- Delicious chicken broth 
- Lots of basil and jalapeno

Minuses:
- The ambience of the restaurant isn't great
- Fresh spring rolls are on the pricy side and you don't get very much

Good alternative when Turtle Tower (next door) is closed.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Excellent,  best pho I ever had, much better than turtle tower.

I got the small beef combination, which is actually huge.
Spring rolls, amazing,
Great thai tea.

I went there at the opening for breakfast and everything was divine.
The noodles are fresh made in house, the broth is the tastiest I ever had,
Plenty of toppings, friendly service. 

Even the side items and apetizers are delicious. 

Will be back soon!
author: Tia D.

description: My goto pho destination in San Francisco. Have only eaten one dish (combination beef noodle soup) and it does not disappoint. Excellent broth, great ingredients, always delicious. Definitely the best beef pho spot in the city (chicken pho would be Turtle Tower).
author: Anthony D.

description:
Good pho restaurant in a not so good neighborhood.  My office is a couple blocks away and I have been there no less than 30 times.  It's nice that they remember what I like.  I can walk in and start eating within three minutes.

Turtle Tower is nice too but it is a different style of Vietnamese pho.
author: Harvey K.

description:
Steph and I went in search of soup for my diseased self at 4:30 this afternoon because we're trapped in the library and 80. We don't know what day or time it is and thats that. Being up for the early bird special meant our regular place was closed. And there was a line at Turtle Tower. So we popped in here. 

2 cheap orders of pho later, I was super delighted by a giant bowl of pho ga withOUT chicken skin, with a yummy broth, and a LOT of noodles. It also had bits of bone in it and while to some this may be a bad thing- to me, it was great- since most of the really good healing s- in chicken soup comes from bone marrow. 

YUMMMM. I'm stoked- this place was way better than TT! Definitely my pick for pho in the TL.
author: Emily D.

description: Seriously I thought this place was going to have a great service due to its popularity. First they serve a tea without asking and if you dont order "enough" they charge an extra 2$ which isnt much but why doesnt it say it in the menu or why didnt the server say it before they brought it. Second, in the menu it says "sides" and i asked for a side of steamed rice but the server said we dont sell the sides unless you get the food tjat involved rice. WTF. Im not as hungry I just came to give it a taste. I have never heard of that before especially from a small business restaurant. Im still in the restaurant and it smells like moth balls. I wish Yelp had a scent detecter through your smart phones so you can smell it. They also took a really long time to serve my food.
author: Beatriz D.

description:
CASH ONLY.

With my group of 8, we were super unhappy when we realized that turtle towers had closed for the day and we were still craving pho. -__- pho 2000 happens to be right next door so we figured we'd give it a shot.

FOOD:
I ordered a #6 small ($6.89)- pho with rare steak flank. The broth wasn't clear like most pho restaurants....instead it was a creamy white color which left me a bit disoriented and confused. This "small" was more like a medium at other restaurants so if you typically order a small/med, the small is MORE than enough. 
pho broth- meh- not special AND wasn't hot enough. 
noodles- good since they didn't stick together 
beef- lots of chewy beef slices for a small
If you're desperate for pho and turtle towers is closed, i guess this will have to do.

ATMOSPHERE:
 I can handle/love cheap good eats but for reason, the lighting of this restaurant made it feel a lot dirtier. We sat on the second floor but they draped the tables with these ugly plastic flowered-green tablecloth that made me feel a bit itchy and dirty as it was just long enough to touch my thigh with my legs under the table. I think i'll just have to pass and trek my way over to richmond if I crave pho again and turtle towers is closed :(
author: Patricia K.

description: One of many mom and pop pho shops in the tenderloin. We came here on a Monday evening because Turtle Tower, just down the street, was closed. The space is small but they have an upstairs seating area too. We ordered the pho tai, cha gio, and vegetarian pho. The cha gio were huge and yummy! Our pho took a while to come out (a table that sat down after us got their pho before us), but we were happy when it did! Beef was sliced thin, noodles were very soft, and the broth was very  flavorful, though a little too oily! Overall I'd come back, especially given the low prices - it came out to $26.50 for the two of us.
author: J L.

description:
Don't let Turtle Tower next door completely overshadow this gem. It's also a different type of pho.  

Highlights include the Rare Beef Pho (#6), the Imperial Rolls, Spring Rolls, and the Bun Bo Hue.

Cash only! Don't forget to grab a stamp card!
author: Monica Z.

description: The broth was aromatic and had good flavors, but it was way too salty for me. The beef was tender. The dish looks a bit sad, not much color and only a few strands of herbs.
author: Thuy T.

description: The bowl I ordered only came in "big" size, and it was still dirt cheap. However, it was mostly noodles and stringy fat with few blood cubes and sparse lean meat. What initially seemed like too much food left me stranded halfway through the meal. Plus, my orange juice was overwhelmingly ice and not much juice. If those things are what 2000's all about, please return the DeLorean to 2012.
author: Dan B.

description: Best  pho in Little Saigon. My go-to place for a quick, delicious, reasonably priced bowl, in a neighborhood with a dozen excellent restaurants to choose from.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Terrifying neighborhood, fantastic soup. Ordered the spicy beef w/pork blood; the best $8 I've spent in ages. 
There was a steady stream of customers, most sitting by themselves slurping large bowls of ethnic yumminess & drinking a pot of tea. The ambiance was an interesting mix of bare bones comfort & soupy happiness. If you can ignore the intravenous drug users outside the restaurant & focus solely on food in front of you, you'll be a happy customer. 
Recommended over TT next door.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and I just came here 3 times to try the foods. My standard for Vnmese food is probably higher than most american.

The Bun Bo Hue is very good, I'd rate it 7/10.

The Goi Cuon is 10/10, no comment.

The Five spice chicken, BBQ pork and egg rolls are just okay. I expected more from a Vietnamese rice plates but the fish sauce and the rice disappointed me. I guess they can't get the right type of rice and fish sauce here in US. 6/10

The Pho is quite good and the price is fair compared to many other places in SF, only $8 for a large bowl, 7/10.

But the Bun Rieu is disappointed. The flavor is still OK, but it's nowhere as near as a normal Bun Rieu in VN. The Bun Rieu here is just like tomato soup with minced meat.
If I have to rate this, I'd rate it 2/10. It's edible but it's not Bun Rieu.
author: Phuong P.

description:
First thing's first: CASH ONLY.
Second thing: you can substitute thin egg noodle in your pho.
 
I get the pho and the combination vermicelli plates.  The pho is great and portion is huge, I'm not a huge fan of rice noodles and this place substitutes with thin egg noodle.  - I pretty much go here for that.

It's a wonderful place with smiley and attentive folks that serve up comfort food when you need a soup to satisfy your weary soul and body.  The imperial rolls are good too.
author: Isa H.

description: Tasty pho, nothing better on a wet and chilly day. Atmosphere seems consistent with the competition in the tenderloin.  service is quick, prices are low. Recommended highly.
author: Greg G.

description: I am no newbie when it comes to pho or bun bo hue. What I can say is this, don't pass this place up. Best bun bo hue I have ever had ever! I also tried the pho and my god that's the best pho broth I have ever tasted too. This is by far the cities best pho place and for that matter possibly all of the bay, in my opinion the best in California. Great staff, was seated promptly, fresh ingredients, and good service. I'll be back when ever I am in San Francisco again. Thank you very much.
author: j j.

description:
I kind of don't want the secret to get out about this place because it's my go-to spot and the pho here is solid! Probably the most underrated pho in the city, and (IMHO) much better than the surrounding places. Not knocking Hanoi style, but this place gives you all the veggies you want in pho and has all the flava. Also the giant pots up front are constantly making broth that is cooked to perfection. 

If you don't mind the casual atmosphere, don't have to wait in line to believe it's good, and appreciate authenticity then try it, love it, Yelp it. Just don't bring so many people that I have to wait in line please, you can do that next door :)
author: Justin B.

description: Instant service, great price, so delicious. They took us in as refugees from Ha Nam Ninh who waited to long too get food. Cannot say enough good things about this place!
author: Jimmy T.

description:
Really good clean pho & open early in the morning when you most need it.. 
Better than Turtle Tower (ew)
author: Joyce C.

description:
Two people, a big bowl of garlic noodles and a plate of super awesome imperial rolls, and a bill totaling $14?

Hellz yeah.

Since this place is right down the road, I'm going to start picking up dinner on the way home from work instead of cooking. It's that damn good.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Pho 2000 is conveniently located on Larkin Street.  The title of the restaurant has the word "pho" in it, so you know exactly what you are getting into.  As much as I want to like Pho 2000 for it's no nonsense attitude, there is something missing.

A small bowl of pho costs $6.25.  The bowl is relatively large and comes with your standard noodles, broth, and choice of interesting cuts of beef.

The noodles disappoint me every time!  I think either the noodles are undercooked before being put in the broth or the broth is not hot enough to thoroughly cook the noodles.  Chicken or egg either way - the noodles maintain that plasticky texture for the first five to seven minutes.

Furthermore, I am a garnish girl.  I like my scallions, cilantro, basil, onions, basil fresh, springy, and full of life.  However, yesterday the scallions, cilantro, and onions were definitely not fresh and springy.  More like withering and dead.  This made me sad.

The redeeming grace is the broth.  However, that stuff is mostly MSG anyway so it's hard to mess up.  (I hope this isn't a rude awakening for any of you.)

Sadly my demand for pho is relatively inelastic so I definitely will be coming back.
author: Fei L.

description:
Always been my favorite place. The service is pretty good (they pour you the tea sometimes) 5/5. The food taste amazing. This is definitely the best pho place in the neighborhood.
btw you can add pork's blood in bun rieu
author: Yumi K.

description:
A-OK.

I've been here at least five times. It's around the corner from my school and for some reason it's our go-to spot for pho, but not because the pho here is extraordinary.  A small bowl is $6.25 and a large is $6.99.  The portions are pretty generous. Sometimes I'll split a large with a friend and not feel hungry when we're through.  

I've had a chance to try a few different soups and appetizers. I really didn't like my seafood noodle soup today. Not enough seafood and it cost more than regular beef pho. I definitely wouldn't order it again. I also didn't like the soup with the tomatoes and ground pork. (Sorry, I'm not familiar with the names) My friend always gets the vermicelli bowl with egg roll and pork and I've never heard her complain about it. The standard pho options are never a bad choice and the spring rolls are fine.  

The servers are adequate. They never give us a hard time for staying well after we get our check or asking for extra bowls. 

There is definitely better pho in the neighborhood, but Jones St. is more sketchy than Larkin, so we choose safety over flavor 9 times out of 10.

This joint is cash only, but at least the hot tea is free. (I'm lookin' at you, Turtle Tower.)
author: Jenn C.

description:
I have travelled Near and Far in my search for the best Pho in San Francisco, this place is very good and well worth the money. (not AS good as Golden Star, which still takes it for me) but its cheaper, the portions are really massive - enough for 2, It comes QUICKLY - and it really is good Pho. Also - the Imperial Rolls, are by FAR the best i've had, really really good. Could I give it 4.5 Stars, I would, it's close, but not QUITE there. still - highly recommend this place.

only thing that bothers me is that they close at 8:30, which i dont understand the logic behind, that being said, I love that I finally found a good Pho restaurant in my hood, as Pho's one of my favorite foods.
author: Adam O.

description:
I come for the Bun Reiu and the Banh Xeo at least two weekends month. Delish! 

Downer, my mobile reception is terrible when I'm inside. Maybe their trying to promote human interaction.
author: Maggie L.

description:
***************** REVIEW 368 ******************

            In the heart of Tenderloin, open kitchen which is extremely rare for Vietnamese restaurants. Walking in, the aroma from the kitchen was amazing. A big pot of Pho broth, with tons of bones & what not, I saw that & I'm melt!

            I can see why my dearest Yelper Susy C. loves this place. Everything is cheaper than their next door Pho place, generous portion & tasty food, oh & GREAT service too!

A few dishes that is really good here:

- PHO combo, & they do serve beansprout, lime, basil here!
- Rice with grilled pork,
- Egg Roll with rice stick & herbs, 
- Spring Roll,

              I will come back anytime for more Pho!
 

PS: CASH ONLY!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Not bad. The price is reasonable.

I was here for a quick meal and I was not disappointed. I ordered a small pho and the portion is huge - way bigger than I had expected.
author: Maria G.

description:
Good stuff. Had the chicken and beef pho and both were delish. Broth is tasty (not bland at all like other people complained about). They definitely give you way more noodles than Turtle Tower here.

Only downside is that it's not the cleanest place.. But then again, what hole in the wall Asian place is? Saw guys bussing tables then touching the sprouts and veggies for the pho without washing their hands in between.
author: Joy A.

description:
No msg, noodle soup comes out boiling hot, quality food!  Had the tomato bue ru and the #1 (everything) beef noodle soup.  I love how the beef slice still comes out raw when placed on top.  Huge portions, the large was even too much for my husband.  They do not lack on the toppings too, portions are plenty compared to the noodles.  Not like other places where you order a large and you get more noodles and a bigger bowl, but not more meat.

So far, ranks high up there within SF competitors.
author: Ju D.

description: Tasty and super fresh shrimp roll and big roast pork vermicelli bowl. Pork was on the fatty side, which makes it tasty, but not for the faint of heart.  Service is super fast.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
3.5, rounded up.  This is a decent place to get a hot bowl of pho on a typical cold SF day. There's nothing too special about this place; I can't really say there's anything here that distinguishes it from the many other pho places in the City.  

That said, it's a pretty solid joint, and their bowls of pho and bun are pretty balanced in terms of flavor and generous in their portions.  I like to get the pho with all the tendony goodness, and the bun with imperial rolls and grilled pork.  Both are solid bowls of food, will fill you up adequately, and you'll leave pretty satisfied.

The service is quick, and the food is cheap and standard for what it is: about $6-7 for a bowl of pho.  

All in all, an easy, quick, satisfying and tasty lunch - there's nothing that sets it apart from other pho places, but if you need your pho or bun fix, it'll do the trick.
author: Vivian C.

description: I had the number 6 and their broth game is on point! Their large bowl is monstrous and they don't skimp out on the meat either. I also like that you can choose the thin noodle or flat wide noodle.
author: Mayra M.

description: It was cold and I was craving some hot warming Pho so I looked up this place through Yelp. I had the chicken Pho which was very tasty. Friendly staff but only take cash. I did not have any but luckily there was an ATM machine across the street inside a store.
author: Sherihan E.

description:
Welcome to San Francisco - CASH ONLY.  ??  Weird.....

Vegetarian Pho?  Excellent for the hubby.  Sketchy neighborhood Fast service and CASH ONLY.  I wouldn't call it PHO-NOMINAL but really good solid Pho and the Vegetarian options allows me to have Pho with the hubby.  

Such a satisfying meal on a cold SF day.  Don't know if I'd venture into this neighborhood alone....
author: Laura G.

description:
First off, I will openly admit I may not have had enough pho to be a pro at figuring out who does it better. With that said, overall, it was good. The broth was yummy, a tad on the salty side but not ridiculously so. I am not sure this is the best pho I have had but it is definitely on the "would do it again" list. I had pho ga - simply chicken, noodles broth and a bunch of stuff to put in. The bean sprouts, basil, and jalapenos were very fresh, definitely making a difference in the quality of the pho. They used mostly white meat which I like and it was not over cooked, very shreddy. I like the shreddy because it absorbs the broth nicely. 

The restaurant is in the Tenderloin, pretty sketchy on the outside. Inside was clean and service was prompt. I would go again
author: Krysten L.

description:
So good, had their vegetarian pho, and it was so flavorful.  This is basically my pho spot from now on.

I would recommend (as others have) sitting upstairs if you want to get away from the noise of the kitchen and the echoing acoustics of downstairs.
author: Jonathan B.

description: It was a rainy day, and I was craving some hot pho. That being said my usual place Turtle Tower was closed. Pho 2000 was open so I decided to check this spot out. It exceeded expectations, super hot, rich broth and a nice helping of noodles. I'm not an expert on pho, but price-wise, portion-wise and overall flavor made me rate this place highly. I will definitely be back here again.
author: Alex L.

description: MMMMMMMMMM, Pho 2000.  A nice place in the city with that family ran vibe I love.  The staff is great which only adds to the fact that they can really make you a nice meal.  I recommend anyone try this place.  My favorite is the crab paste soup, just thinking about it makes me which I was there now =)
author: Christian H.

description: consistently good. lately i've been coming for bun bo hue and bun rieu. I just wish they gave more pork blood in the bun bo hue!!! But my food always comes out piping out and I know it comes from good, CLEAN hands.
author: Susy C.

description:
Found our home away from home pho spot. Don't mess around, get the pho and viet coffee. Reletively clean atmoshere, fast and to the point.

I will definitely go back next time I visit. I can't compare this to the Turtle Towers... yet.
author: Jack F.

description:
This is good, good pho!! 

To be honest it might just be good pho... but when I'm out a bit too late in the city the night before, miss the last caltrain to southbay, this is where I come for breakfast, you walk in first thing in the morning and there cutting the noodles, getting sides ready and boiling a huge huge pot of pho, that I pretty much just want to crawl in like a giant pho hot tub, so that might be my bias.

It is cash only and it is good, marrowy, those nice spices coming through, mmmmmmmm
author: Sarah F.

description:
Have I really eaten here three times in the past week?

Big heaping bowls of fun with a heap of tendons and other cow bits all bobbing under a cover of Vietnamese shrubbery. Broth could definitely be hotter and there are few times when the noodles are overcooked, but overall, a solid meal when you're craving pho. Pick out the raw chunks of beef as soon as they lay the bowl in front of you so that you can preserve some of the pinkness. Squeeze o' lime..mm.

The bun (noodle salady things) and the rice plates are pretty good here too, with a huge fried spring roll that definitely matches the fatty lardy one from Tu Lan. BBQ slices were flavorful but ultimately uninspired, so dunk 'em in a sriracha hoisin mix before eating.

Food comes out quick even during lunch time!
author: Kevin L.

description:
I really like the pho here.  If i'm just planning on eating pho i honestly prefer this place to the turtle tower.

Get:
Pho - Huge Portions, broth tastes great, Cheap, and fast.  Not much more you can ask for.

Avoid:
Spring rolls.... they are tiny... and just taste so-so.

Garlic Noodles - Literally just a plate of garlic noodles... if there is suppose to be meat with it i didn't see any.  If that's all you want then feel free to get it.
author: Steven F.

description: The bun bo hue here is the best I've tasted outside of Viet places in San Jose... A definite must if you're in the city and craving something spicy...
author: Nathan D.

description: they deny me service when i regularly eat there sad :-( they promote obesity and are money hungry Asians with poor customer service skills
author: Dylan C.

description: Came here with my boyfriend on a Saturday afternoon. We sat down and they immediately poured us a cup of tea, which I thought was nice. He ordered a large pho (marked $8.10 on the menu) and I said I won't be ordering, as I wasn't too hungry and planned to eat a little from my boyfriends portion. After we finished, the check came, for $10.30, and when we inquired on the price, the lady mentioned that the tea costed $$ and that as we were two people eating from one "portion" she charged extra service fees. Pretty bullshit in my opinion, considering they never mentioned any of this in the beginning, and we never asked for tea in the first place. The food was OK but definitely won't be coming back in the future - I can't stand this kind of attitude.
author: Ariel Z.

description:
This looked like just another vietnamese restaurant in the hood.  Then I tried the vegetarian pho.  I don't know what they did.   This dish is normally bland and makes you regret not ordering a meaty bowl.  However, here it was based on a clear but very savory broth filled with a generous serving of tofu, vegetables and noodles.   It left me feeling perfectly satisfied in that crisp vegetarian way.
Next time I want to go back with a group so I can try more of the menu.
author: Ric S.

description:
My second favorite place after Pho Tan Hao, and it's $2 less for a large (though it's not as large as PTH). Great imperial rolls and rice dishes round out the Pho, which is pretty much all I eat. 

And this is not an alternative to Turtle Tower. It's much better.
author: Christina And Terence T.

description: Cheap prices, fresh, good food, seedy area (kinda), but overall quite good Vietnamese. Would return. They give you complimentary hot tea when you arrive. Not bad!
author: Ian S.

description:
GOOD PHO.  GOOD CUSTOMER SERVICE.

Sometimes I work at the Federal Building on Golden Gate Avenue off Larkin Street, and if I'm looking for Pho on a lunch break then Pho 2000 is usually my go to place.  I heard they hand cut the Pho noodles here, so that's good to know.  The place is larger then most other Vietnamese restaurants in Little Saigon.


RESTAURANT RULES AT PHO 2000:

1) Cash Only

2) There are 2 floors.  If you want to be in a less crowded, less noisy dining room then sit at the 2nd floor.

3) If you choose the 2nd floor one of the tables has a window above it with sunlight shining down on a sunny day, if you don't like that then try to sit at another table.


SO IF YOU'RE IN LITTLE SAIGON LOOKING FOR A BIG VIETNAMESE RESTAURANT WITH GOOD FAST PHO AND GOOD SERVICE THE PHO 2000 IS YOUR PLACE.
author: Rudi A.

description:
Very satisfying Pho! I ordered the rare beef and brisket pho to go today and man was the broth PIPING hot, even after walking with it for several blocks. The meat was very clean, high quality. And I practically had to step back when pouring the broth into my bowl, it was so bubbly hot. The broth is really rich and satisfying, I highly recommend. I guess the noodles are good, but I'm not a noodle fan, I'm a broth and fixings fan, so I can't comment too much on that. They are super generous with the fixings, too (hoison, mung beans, basil, jalapeno, green and white onion, lime). They were also very sweet and when I had forgotten to request the small portion and the bill came to a dollar or so more than the cash I had on me, they let me pay with what I had. I will be back to pay them back plus tip, for sure! :-)

And I will be sure to remember to order the small next time as this large portion is WAY too big to finish even a quarter of!

Pho 2000 is a must try for pho lovers alike. :)
author: Steenie K.

description: They make a lovely pho broth and I love my tripe. I still think the pho in San Jose is better but this is a very close 2nd. Don't forget to get your loyalty card - get 10 stamps and get a free bowl of pho :D
author: Lisa M.

description:
Surprisingly wonderful.  I stumbled across this place after I put an hour in the meter, not knowing Turtle Tower next store was closed for renovations.  I actually liked it better here for Pho!!  Yes, it's kinda divey compared to TT but the Pho was divine.

The servings were huge compared to TT and the broth was just as tasty!   and I really prefer the tradition of the basil leaves, lemon and jalapeno arriving.  Plus I found the waitstaff very kind and sweet...when I realized they only took cash and I had none on me, they just said, no problem, come back with cash later.  I liked that they trusted me.

I'll be back.  Maybe they've cured me of my TT addiction once and for all...not having to brave the crowds and finding that the substitute next door is just as good if not better. Very cool.
author: T S.

description:
I ate here a few times when I hanged out with my friends. They seem only have waiters, (no waitress? what's up with that?) Oh well, service is great. I can't complain about it. Food came faster after we ordered. The only thing I don't like is the restroom. It's not that clean. 

But i'll come back for pho (for sure). The price is inexpensive, and pho is great.
author: Sam W.

description:
How did I came upon this place? Well, my friend and I we're traveling to San Francisco for an artist signing. I haven't eaten lunch and we decided to try a Pho place in San Francisco. I search on Yelp for the best reviews of Pho in the area. Seem like all the Pho places here all have 4 stars. I thought, "Hmm, what's catchy?" Pho 2000 sounds cool. So, we ended up eating here - us out of town folks. 

I'd got to say, it's a small place, but unique in it's own way. We were served right away. They served us free tea. Provided us our menus and water. We ordered and got our food quick. First thing we notice, "ooh, kitchen is in the front." That means "Hot broth" and "No-mucus-feeling-after-meal." Plus, it's fresh right?

The broth isn't bad. I like the fact that it was served hot and not warm. We actually finished all our bowls. Both my friend and I agreed this place is pretty good. Even after our meals, I was satisfy. No mucus feeling! Yay! I would come here after if I come to San Francisco. A 2-hour drive - this place made the drive fulfilling.
author: LenaRei L.

description:
This place is call pho 2000. So I try the pho. I am chinese Vietnamese. I grew up eating Vietnamese food. So I know Vietnamese food. This place has ONLY okay pho. Not worth the tile pho 2000. 

I had the garlic noodle. Total crap!!

I like their diced mint chicken over rice. But again this place is call pho 2000 not mint chicken 2000. This place need to be renamed or get their pho skill up to bar!!!!!
author: Michael Q.

description:
4 stars for being cash only, but the size of a small and for its price is actually pretty big compared to other places in the city.  We went during Sunday Streets and was able to get a seating with no wait time.

I lost my voice that day and the tea and phó combination definitely healed my throat. 

However I don't think I got to fully enjoy my meal because of me constantly coughing so I'm definitely coming back to give them another try despite it being cash only.
author: James R.

description: This is my favorite pho spot in the city! The broth is perfect, not too greasy like some places, and the portions are large. I love the rare steak with meatball pho, and I always get the imperial roll!
author: Jordan N.

description:
This place takes the cake when it comes to pho.  Yes, it is in the Loin, but that shouldn't keep you from the best pho you've ever tasted!  Seriously, taste the broth before you put anything in it.  It's perfect!

They have a GIANT vat (yes, it is literally a vat) of pho broth simmering away, releasing its delicious aroma as soon as you walk in.  I have a feeling that they constantly add to it, continuously reusing the broth like Louisianans do with gumbo.  The result?  A fantastic concoction that gets better with time.

Although they were a bit skimpy with the meat during my last visit, I was more than happy with my small bowl (which is actually quite large) of pho tai bo vien (pho with rare steak and meatballs).

Also, their coconut water is AMAZING.  Coconut water and pho = best hangover cure ever!
author: Angela D.

description:
Nom NoM NOM: Pho and Imperial Rolls
Blah Blah Blah: Broth could use more flavor.

Although unlike the name suggest they didn't have 2,000 options of Pho but there was a page of your standard offerings.  Their Pho came in small or large size and you can pick what type of noodle you want thin or wide.  We ordered a small which was actually pretty big.  The meat, brisket and tendon were good and so was the noodles.  The broth needed some more flavor but this is definitely the type of place where you drown your pho with your hoison, siracha, lime and  fish sauce to make it to your liking.  For appetizers we had the imperial rolls which came in 2 and were pretty crispy and meaty.  Overall the pho wasn't amazing but good enough to satisfy your craving.

::::::::Breakdown::::::::
Food: 3.5 Stars
Place: 3.5 Stars
Service: 4 Stars
Price/Value: 3.5 Stars
Overall: 3.5 Stars
author: Manohak S.

description:
I'm surprised there's less than 300 reviews for this place!! Everytime I ever crave a piping hot bowl of pho, I think of Pho 2000 these days. It's also a really good feeling when you pass by the ridiculous crowd at Turtle Tower next door (which I think is relocating last time I walked by) and walk into the spacious and clean Pho 2000. Service is quick, food is delicious ---try the chili flake hot sauce with the red cap on top YUMMMMMM--- and you and your wallet will walk out happy.

#4, the eggroll appetizer and the grilled pork vermacelli bowl are SOLID!! Thank you for always making me feel better on weekends Pho 2000!
author: Angela S.

description:
3.5 Pretty good pho! The imperial rolls are also delicious. The rice plates are average. 

Great if you are feeling something casual and want a quick dinner.
author: Jamie T.

description:
I wanted Pho to cure my hangover. I didn't have much alcohol the night before but since I haven't been drinking in a while, my alcohol tolerance is so low and got me this awful hangover the following day. 

We were to go to Turtle Tower, we heard the Pho is good there but this place is good too and the place looks way cleaner. It's just literally right next door to Turtle Tower and I don't need to wait in line! 

I like that you could see where your food is coming from at this place. The kitchen is open and is right by the entrance and you could actually see how your food is made from where you are seated.
author: Lora M.

description: Has some of the best spring rolls in SF! Total hole in the wall compared to the new Turtle Tower next door, but I'd still opt for this place any day. First time eating in the upstairs space today and it's pretty cute with the skylight. Quick and good service- ordered a large 11 and spring rolls with extra noodles to share with the bf and it was just the right amount of food.
author: RJ C.

description: Not the snazziest of joints, as can be said for much of the TL, however the pho was delicious. Turtle Tower closes early (Top 100 things to eat in SF) so we tried this nearby establishment, my pho craving was satiated for a very reasonable price. I also enjoy the tag line on their emplyee shirts, I guess you'll just have to go to find out what it says....
author: Nicole Z.

description:
A-mazing/Pho-nomenal. I went here twice last weekend. Maybe it was because I was hungover both times. But this was literally one of the best pho experiences I've ever had. We initally wanted to go to Turtle Tower but the line was insane and Pho 2000 beckoned. I do not regret my choice.

This will count as a rave review for both the chicken and beef pho. Accompanied by a splendid thai iced tea. They also give you free hot tea to begin the meal. Wins all around.
author: Melinda S.

description: Best pho in San Francisco! I've tried many other places in the city and have made Pho 2000 my go-to spot.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
The Pho here is not very good... 

I've tried both the beef noodle soup, and the vegetarian soup... the broth was very bland in both, and meat, veggies, noodles... were all "meh" also. I had to add a ton of salt, soy sauce, sriracha, etc, to get the flavor to anything comparable to GOOD pho places. Definitely NOT a good alternative to Turtle Tower. I was very sad when I tried this place, as I left craving the yummy goodness from next door.

I'll give 2 stars for the garlic noodles, which are decent, although a little too greasy for my taste.

Oh, and as just as a P.S.... their soy sauce containers smell like ass and leave your hands smelly the rest of the day. Really gross.
author: Lucinda W.

description: I cannot get enough of their bun rieu!  Home style flavor and care like what a mom or dad would make for their family!  Bun rieu all over my FACE!!!!!!
author: Dee Y.

description:
I was trying to figure out what I wanted for dinner this evening. All I knew was thatt I wanted something Asian and noodley. I then realized that I live in the TL, just blocks away from Little Saigon, and I hadn't had pho in ages. After a google search and some yelp perusing, I chose this place. It sounded much more appealing than Turtle Tower.

I ordered the large pho ga to go. The service was insanely fast. I was seriously in and out with my food (including ordering and paying) in under two minutes. The waiter was friendly, and I liked that I could watch them prepare my food. The decor was clean and modern, but nothing spectacular.

The pho was fantastic. Wondefully flavorful broth, tender chicken, and the noodles were perfectly cooked. There was a very good meat to noodle to broth ratio. The portion was enourmous too, which was great since it was about $8 with tax. It also came with plenty of fresh veggies, which I always love.

I will definitely be back as soon as possible to try other things on the menu. I only wish I hadn't just discovered this place, when I'm only a  month away from moving out of the TL.
author: Chelsea T.

description:
I come here whenever my bf or I need to recover from a hangover, because the soup is nice and hot and the portions are huge for the price. However, its only when I need life saving pho can I actually delude myself to believe that this place has good pho.  The pho is laden with msg, and the flavors just isn't the same as pho from San Jose. 

On a good note, the service is always gracious and fast.  Whenever I order togo, I only have to wait 5 minutes.
author: Le T.

description:
I'm from Vancouver, so I've had my fair share of pho and I think this place is as good as it gets -- especially for the price. You get a gigantor bowl of everything-cow soup for 7 bucks. The kitchen is open-style, so you know it's clean. Service is friendly and attentive. Plus, the servers' t-shirts say "pho-nomenal". 

There's a Quickly just up the street, so you can get bubble tea for desert!
author: Rachel M.

description:
Come here for good pho
Be wary of The 'Loin folk
They might steal your pho
author: Jonathan C.

description:
OK I am round eye gringo , who eats a lot of Asian food, and although  no expert I have had enough from other Pho joints  to know that this is one of the better bowls around. Prices are great, portions are generous, atmosphere is cozy  ( 25  seats) family run , you can see them prepare the food right out front, service is fine as you are never more than 25  feet from your server.It feels and tastes like the "real deal" .
We got both some rice plates and a few different bowls, everything was polished off in short order. This is not complicated stuff, but there is a difference.I have been to 3 other places within a block of here ,  and 
P 2000 is definitely the best all around experience.Check it out.
author: Aaron Z.

description: Best pho in town, hands down. Fast service, delicious food and really cheap for San Francisco, what more could you wish for?
author: Patricia D.

description: Been here two times and left full and satisfied both times. The menu is large and varied, the service is good and quick, the prices are low and most important of all, the pho is scrumptious. Also nice that they have 2 sizes of pho, so you can get the small, which is still plenty, but you can finish it in one sitting if you don't want to deal with leftovers, or you can get the large, which is plenty large and probably would feed you twice. Definitely coming back next time I'm in the mood for pho, which is about weekly.
author: Nika T.

description: I have been coming here for a long time but never took the time to write a review till now. I always order the same thing becuz I know it's good all the time. I always start with a cup of chicken broth which is served with cilantro & onion. My favorite dish here is the crepe, best one I've eaten in the city yet.
author: May G.

description:
(See pic)

Came here while they're having a street fair. Busy outside, quiet and "tranquil" inside.

I order #1, like all #1 pho in most Vietnamese places-- everything. It was fairly good. The medium size was pretty big. The soup base was on the lighter and less sodium side. Also had the iced coffee but it was pre-made. I miss the complete process.

They give you the Chinese style tea pot, so is the decoration which this place looks more Chinese than Vietnamese.

They had the door opened to let the fresh air coming in. Normally I love it but somehow I like eating pho in sweaty mode so that I can enjoy the iced cold coffee a little better.
author: T L.

description:
February 10, 2010, Tuesday @ 6 PM

Girlfriend-bonding in the TL and what did we get?

1. Yummy and cheap delicious Vietnamese dinner
2. And a dish we both never had before.

My gf, Rebecca, and I just wanted a relaxed, non-frills dinner.  Of course, pho is the number choice (soba or ramen are the runner-ups.)   In our 11 years of friendship,  we bonded over  countless bowls of noodle soup.  And over pho, we solved guy issues, mended broken-hearts, created our life's Plan B's.....

And at Pho2000 we made history again. My gf had her usual BEEF PHO and she liked it. (I"ve had this many times before and it's 3.5-4 Stars  in my book.)

 I ordered the GRILLED PORK AND SHRIMP OVER RICE which came with lettuce, tomato salad and  fishsauce for dipping. The meat was tender and flavorfu but fried not grilled. Still delicious! (3 Stars)

The star of the show however was BANH XEO (4 Stars):  Crispy crepe filled with pork, shrimp and bean sprouts which you wrap in lettuce and dip in fish sauce. (We both never had this dish before.) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bLa9Jm04dPersyUN7LFrvw?select=Ylz6EZ1JAYgHNCqHaxNa3w http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bLa9Jm04dPersyUN7LFrvw?select=JG7A1a-hPrtfoBie99GXBw

Deep-fried, hot, crispy and delicious!! We gave up trying to wrap it up in lettuce and just ate the crepe as it is.

Pho 2000 is a tiny little mom and pop place but clean.  The open kitchen is widely visible as soon as you enter so you can watch your food being prepared. The staff are very friendly.

And the  portions are humongous! My Taiwanese gf, Rebecca and I, jokingly commented how their large bowl can feed a family of 4 in the Philippines or Taiwan! And my rice plate could easily have been for two meals but since I'm a piggy-wiggy I almost finished the whole thing!

The best part of the meal?  Tab was $20.80 before tip.  

Only in the TL!
author: Leah E.

description: cant say enough good thing about this place. "i" salad and 12 pho - do it
author: tricia m.

description: This unassuming place in the tenderloin is amazing. It's inexpensive, tidy little joint has a great menus and attentive service.  Definitely worth the trip.
author: David H.

description:
Clean, good service, good broth. 

Sometimes I go to a pho place and the chopsticks are icky. Not here, they are clean here. I took my wife's parents here the first time I met them. I introduced my dad to this place. He works early in the mornings. Sometimes he gets there a little too early before they are ready to open but hr knocks on the windows and they will seat him and serve him.  My favorite broth of all the pho places in sf. Not too oily, or salty. I always get beef on the side with extra lemon.  Their seafood noodles is the best. Clean and crisp ask for extra fried garlic. Way better than the noodle place next to it.
author: P P.

description:
Wanted to try this because it seems popular. The plates we ordered looked nothing like the photos other people had ordered or even like the plates of the people around us. Our pho was pretty empty and the the rice plate seemed smaller. Just means a big inconsistence 

The taste was OK, meaning not that great but also not bad.
author: M C.

description:
Best Bun Bo Hue within SF County.  Prices are reasonable.  Portions are above average for pho. 

Although the stuff in San Jose is better, I don't have to drive an hour south now that Pho 2000 is in the mix.
author: Sam T.

description: Cash only.  Wasn't to happy with the soup.  Broth was not very flavorful and made me thirsty.  Threw away most of it.  My order was to go and has the seafood pho.   Fish cake was very chewy and not very tender. Lots of fake crab meat.  Just wasn't impressed at all.  Seemed more like the McDonald's of pho soup joints.
author: Jacob F.

description: My favorite pho in the world, and YES, I spent a month in Vietnam. But this place takes it.
author: Josely C.

description: This place was recommended to us by some random people on the street in union square. We were cutting it very close on time (walking in 2 minutes before they closed), but we're still greeted with tea and a smile. They server recommended the beef noodle soup, which was "pho-mazing"! They also we nice enough to let us (two girls) wait inside after they closed until our Uber driver arrived since the area is a bit seedy after dark. Great service and great food! We will be back!!
author: Maggie G.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and I'm super picky about pho.

The broth in their pho is prob the best in the city. I get the pho dac biet small and the portion is HUGE. The broth is perfectly salted for me and doesnt need tuong and/or tuong ot to flavor it. You know a pho place is authentic when they have nuoc mam on the table. That's how they roll in Saigon, Viet Nam. 

What not to order: their Bun Bo Hue is really bad. Stick with the pho and you'll be a happy camper-- their other stuff is below average.
author: J D.

description:
The bf and I were in the mood for pho and after a quick Yelp search...we found ourselves cabbing it to Pho 2000. 

I ordered my standard meal - vermicelli noodles with bbq pork and egg roll. I believe it was #17 on the menu. Fish sauce was awesome with a perfect amount of noodles, veggies and meat. I highly recommend it. 

The bf ordered pho with brisket and rare beef. He was a big fan. 

Service was friendly and super fast. 

Note - cash only (VERY affordable)

Overall...besides the neighborhood being a bit shady...Pho 2000 is pho'tastic. :)
author: Dru M.

description:
Kkkkkkkk as Joe Pesci would say in lethal weapon(lol) we have found the best pho in San Fran, ladies and gents drum roll please PHO 2000 has THE BEST PHO.
