My Caucasian partner asked the sever who is responsible to make this pho?? The server pointed to the lady chef and on our way out we gave our complements to the chef again.
The broth was just perfect full authentic pho flavored. My partner David says it had the right ratio of the broth to noodle to meat. Right you are honey!
We were afraid that we will leave San Fran without finding the best pho.
Thanks fellow yelpers!!
author: Lana H.

description:
Having just moved to SF from LA, I've been really disappointed in the viet food you find in the city. Most places are owned by chinese people so it's not quite authentic since there's a chinese twist to traditional viet dishes. Having lived in LA, it was a 30 min drive to Westminster, OC which is the land of the most affordable and amazing viet dishes you can find on the west coast. 

The hubby and I have been on a mission until we stumbled upon Pho 2000, don't let the name fool you because they serve all types of dishes and not only pho. The dishes are affordable and pretty legit. I've tried the banh xeo along with the com nuoung dac biet which were super tasty. I'm glad I finally found a spot in the city that I could walk to and grab some authentic viet dishes. If you haven't been, I'd definitely try this spot out.
author: Janet T.

description:
The pho broth was bland (no MSG?) for my liking. Adding Sriracha and Hoisin sauce helped a little bit. The bun rieu was on the sweet side. Adding "mam tom" = shrimp paste and crushed garlic pepper did not help much, and only half the bowl was eaten.

The cleanliness of the place, the modern-ish decor, the non-MSG-laden foods, the sweetness of soup broths, the non-Asians to Asians ratio was 5:1, etc., were not good signs for this pho lover.

Service was prompt and attentive though. Their TV was showing the Niners game, and that it made it a worthwhile visit. So, I don't think I'd return much often but will take non-Asian friends there if they wanted to try the place.
author: Peter L.

description:
I got fooled by Yelp reviews here.  This place is not good, and the high reviews of this place are WAY off. 

Pho- Not that great.  Too much noodle, meat wasn't good, broth was decent.
Veggie Imperial rolls- Tasted like fried chalk
Thai iced tea- Gross.  Tasted like it was powered tea.
Shaking beef- Barely up to par.
Grilled Chicken- Meh

None of us finished our food, and are never coming back here.  If you really want pho do your self a favor and walk over to Pho Tan Hoa.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
Great alternative to Turtle Tower.  Esp if you're not into the thicker rice noodles next door.

Portions are GINORMOUS!
author: Dorothy L.

description: Being from LA and from a traditional Vietnamese background, I have a very high standard for Vietnamese cuisine. I never thought I would find a good authentic pho place in the city. This place goes above and beyond my expectations. The pho here is as good as it gets. It reminds me of the pho I grew up having in my mom's kitchen. The thing that makes this pho the best is the broth and how you can taste it in the noodles in every bite. It also comes at a cheap price which I love. I will definitely be coming back for more.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
I was sick one day and was planning to go to Turtle Tower to grab some chicken pho.  In my state of delirium, I forgot that Turtle Tower closes at 7:30 (I mean why would a restaurant stay open past 7:30? It's ridiculous to expect any successful restaurant to stay open past 7:30...)  Anyway, my roommate and I were in the mood for some sort of soup, so we walked down Larkin trying to find something. We actually passed Pho 2000 since it's so inconspicuous.  

Once we got in, I ordered a large chicken pho.  I was pretty surprised at how much was in it. I mean when you order a large at most pho joints, they would usually just give you a bigger bowl with the same amount of noodles and meat as a small, but with more broth.  Pho 2000 actually gives you more of everything.  The pho was good too and it was the regular southern style that I'm used to unlike at Turtle Tower, which means you get to pile on the Sriracha and hoison sauce!  The spring rolls were good too and I will need to go back a few more times, because they had a lot of other good looking items on their menu.
author: Joe N.

description:
This place is right next to my humble abode so I've been coming here since 2010. They've consistently been serving me good pho. It's not phenomenal but it's definitely worth checking out if you've never been here. 

I like going here for just some one on one time. Just me and the pho. Pho 2000 is rarely crowded so it makes this very easy. 

p.s. Don't go to Turtle Tower next door. It's awful.
author: Andy S.

description:
Maybe it was a off day to eat here, but these are the reasons I gave it 2 stars:

1. Pho was loaded with grease
2. Soup was lukewarm
3. Noodles was over cooked (soggy noodles)
4. Broth hade no depth in flavor
5. Ice coffee was waaaay to sweet. 

Imperial rolls was on point though!

Will i come back....Nope!
author: Sophana T.

description: I'd actually give the food here 3 stars but I tacked on another because we had really great service. We tried the pho and vermicelli noodles with bbq pork. The pho was average and the vermicelli noodles didn't seem cooked all the way through, but the bbq pork was very tasty. I'm a little surprised at all the rave reviews but perhaps we came on an off day. Great and quick service though!
author: Jamie B.

description:
Solid, CHEAP pho in an area over saturated with Vietnamese food. 

Came here looking for a nice hearty bowl of the trademark #1 special pho, ubiquitous to almost all pho joints. I definitely was not disapointed at Pho 2000. $6.25 for a small and $6.99 for a large and chock full of plenty of meat, this is probably the cheapest prices I've seen for the quality meat/noodle ratio. 
I have a big thing about judging pho based on how much meat is left over compared to noodles since I have a strict meat/noodle ratio I go by (OCD anyone?...). If there's meat leftover, it means there's an awesome amount of meat. If I just get by...eh ok. More noodles left and no meat and there's someone getting stink eye at the end of my meal. Pho 2000 falls squarely in the awesome amount of meat category and I'll definitely be stopping by again. Soon.
author: Rayna L.

description: Went here today for my on going quest to find the best Bún riêu.  This place is quite nice although you have to walk through all the nastiness that is the tenderloin to get there.  That however is a small price to pay.  This place has a friendly staff and clean environment.  The portions are HUGE!  Unfortunately as I am always on the quest for Bun Rieu,  I have had much better elsewhere.  This soup had more pork flavor than crab.  I would come back and try their Pho as I believe this is their strong point.
author: Hatman ..

description: Place was good. I order a small tripe and steak; the broth was tasty.  Its one of the top 3 pho joints I've ever been.
author: Sam K.

description:
I imagine they named this place before y2k, as if this restaurant represented the future of pho'. If that's the case, I've been to the future, and it isn't that different from the past. And that's a good thing.

The benchmark I use to rate pho' restaurants is the dish I enjoy the most, pho' tai chin nac (steak and well-done brisket). I'm not a big fan of the chewier innards like trip or tendon, so I'd consider this dish something of a "meat-lovers" pho'.

In my mind there are two things that set Pho2k apart from other pho' joints. 1) It's got an open kitchen, so you get to see the awesomeness being made and you don't have to worry about what may or may not get in your food. 2) The broth. There's a richness here that is hard to describe. My guess is that it's the bones that go into the broth that add a depth and an almost milky quality that I don't normally get from pho' restaurants. Consequently, I'd go light on the hoisin sauce here so you could appreciate its velvety smoothness.

Just walking distance from the Civic Center, Pho2k is great for lunches. If it weren't for the trek, I could see myself eating here regularly.
author: Tony L.

description: A good option when Turtle Tower is overcrowded. Pho 2000 delivers solid pho with friendly, if barebones, service. You can eat a great lunch or dinner here for under $10. I recommend the chicken or rare beef pho with a Thai iced tea.
author: Aaron V.

description: Really good pho and bun. Wish we lived closer by so we could come here more often. They have a card that you can get stamped for a free bowl of pho after buying 10.
author: T C.

description: Out of all of the many wonderful southern vietnamese pho style restaurants, I always return to Pho 2000.  1) They are vietnamese  2) The pho always taste like pho and not plain chicken broth.  It's clean, authentic, and comforting.  Like any other vietnamese offspring will say.. "Not as good as my mama's, but it will do." .. says a lot. They provide fresh basil and bean sprouts and always packed nicely when I order to go.
author: Cezanne C.

description: A friend introduced me to Pho2000 as the best Pho spot in the city...and it lived up to to the reputation.  Delicious food, quick service.  Nothing fancy, but it hits the spot.
author: Krishna K.

description: Came here for lunch and saw that the LARGE pho was HUGE! Hubby ordered the pho but in regular size and it was the same standard size as it in Houston. I ordered the banh xeo and it was nice and crispy but a bit on the oily side. This place was ok, and after seeing the LARGE bowl, i can see why its a bit on the busy side here.
author: Aline D.

description: Cheap and quick with a handful of vegan options. Vegan pho (pho chay) could have more veggies though.
author: W T.

description: They have the most amazing beef broth. This is my favorite pho in the city. I also really like their spring rolls with peanut sauce.
author: J. L.

description: This place was really bad. Broth was entirely MSG.  Large portion came in a misleading large bowl with very little food inside. Bf got beef pho which had barely any meat! I had seafood pho which was the biggest scam--imitation crab is what they consider "seafood".  I've learned my lesson and will only go to turtle tower from now on.
author: T Y.

description: The pho here is not the best I've had but certainly a good contender. They also do a very good job with all the other dishes on their menu. I really like the rice vermicelli with egg rolls and grilled pork. The portions are huge and the price very reasonable. They also have a loyalty program so you should definitely ask about it if you intend to frequent the place. The kitchen is also open concept so I feel a little more comfortable eating here than some of the other Viet restaurants in the tenderloin. The service is also very quick and courteous. I think this place is much better overall than it's neighbor turtle tower.
author: Mai C.

description:
definitely legit. while everyone knows about turtle tower and their amazing chicken pho, many people do not realize that their beef pho is subpar.

pho 2000 has excellent beef pho on the other hand, with a broth that's just rich enough, and good quality beef. imperial rolls are awesome, and iced coffee is served properly. and despite getting here a minute before closing, they didn't try to rush us out or anything. definitely would go back.
author: Mark A.

description:
Came here for PHO right before Wicked.
First time here, and nom nom nom.. my friend definately did a good job recommending this place. It's not a hole in the wall, decor and everything every nice. Friendly staff, big bowl of noddle, at the expense of a small price!
Totally will be returning... if parking is easy. =D
Also, they have the raw beef dish, (not on the menu) gotta special request it.. 
nom nom nom!
author: Monika T.

description: Does not disappoint. A great place for quick pho. I come here whether as an alternative to Turtle Tower or just a destination in itself. I usually get the Pho Ga (chicken), and you get a great amount of chicken pieces in the broth. A small is HUGE. While food comes up fast, service is a bit disorganized. However, everyone is so nice in here.
author: Jason S.

description:
NOTE:  This place is NOT part of the PHO 2000 chain in Saigon. I asked. I had to know, before I ordered.

I can't believe I'm about to say this, but the PHO here is pretty decent. Yep, I actually would consider returning to grub here on a regular basis. EXCEPT, that I'd have to drink gallons upon gallons of water afterward. These folks must pile on the MSG by the ton, but it's okay...

I'm loving that they give you the option of the wide noodles for your PHO.  

Folks, it's sad, but I'm trying to be less of a VietNamese food snob.  I'm really, REALLY trying. I'm THAT desperate for decent Viet grub here in the Bay Area.

BUT MAN --- if you REALLY want O-mazing VietNamese food, you just gotta make the trek down to OC.  Really.  Save your stomach space and stop terrorizing your tastebuds.  

I hear SouthWest and Virgin America have great deals on flights...
author: BrasilPo P.

description: I don't want to even give one star. Ordered catfish claypot to-go for $12 plus tax.  To my surprise, when I got the food, it only fill up less than 1/4 of the container with only 3 thin slices of catfish. Look more like a leftover than an actual dine-in portion. RIDICULOUS!!!!!! ARE YOU KIDDING ME??!!???
author: Mel D.

description: I thought their spring rolls were amazing, however (and this may be because i saw the huge pot of meat right when I walked in) the actual pho was not as good as I have had at other places. There were little bits of chicken skin floating in my soup and it was freaking me out. I loved the jasmine tea they serve with their meals though, but I also was not a fan of their homemade chili sauce. The consistency was off and made it hard for me to make my perfect combo of spice with soy sauce.
author: Brittini S.

description: Really great food. The beef was very tender and juicy. Soup had a lot of flavor. And noodles were cooked just right.
author: Larry C.

description: I LOVE this place . I Love the service , the owner Linda, and the amazing Pho they prepare . As of a year ago I learned how to make my own pho at home from eating at amazing places as Kenny Noodle House in Daly City, Pho Aosen in Oakland , and my favorite Pho 2000. But as far as all three PHO 2000 is my favorite when I am in the city. I learn the true taste of an amazing soup here and am trully grateful for their craft in making an amazing  broth. Thank you LInda for your hard work and dedication !!!
author: Javier G.

description:
Pho 2000 - another Real Deal establishment.

Today, I went to the SF Asian Heritage Festival in the Civic Center.  Our original plan was to raid the gourmet food truck alley with all sorts of things, find a nice place to chill, and enjoy our little picnic.   There were a few problems with that plan... the food truck alley was so crowded - it was almost impossible to make your way down the street.  The long lines at the various food trucks were insane.  Chairman Bao's line had to be at least 6-7 deep.  Add to that the waiting time after you placed your order.  Other problems included lack of a suitable picnic area, the extremely gusty winds, and the crowds and noise created by the sheer number of people there.

Well- how about Plan B?

We hiked further up from the festival along Larkin - I knew there was a smallish Vietnamese town just a block or two away.  We ducked into a tiny Pho place and sat down.   Pho 2000 is really small - there had to only be 6-7 tables.  There was an upstairs area, but I'm not sure just how big it was up there.  The menu had all the usual suspects - various noodle dishes, rice plates, egg rolls (both fried and fresh).  The last page had an extensive beverage menu - including Thai iced tea, which was of the very best that I've had outside of Thailand.

My lunch partners both ordered Pho noodle soup.  They assured me that it was delicious, and very authentic tasting.  It looked and smelled great!  I'll have to give it a try the next time I visit.  I did notice that the fresh condiments for the pho was large, and brimming with lots of fresh basil and bean sprouts.  I also saw that they offered the less spicy anaheim chili pepper slices instead of the traditional (to USA pho places) jalapeno peppers.  Not a deal breaker for me - but die hard heat seekers may want to ask if they have jalapeno slices available.

I ordered the vermicelli Bun dish.  It seemed like a HUGE portion once it arrived at the table.  Heaped ontop of the lettuce and perfectly cooked rice noodles were generous amounts of tender, succulent pork.  I also had them add a few large chunks of deep fried egg roll on the sides.  Once I poured the small bowl of sauce onto it and gave it a quick mix, I was treated to that familiar taste of a truly GREAT dish.

Bottom line?  Pho 2000 knows their stuff.  If you want a quick pho fix, this is your place.  I can vouch for the authentic flavors and great tasting food.  Do yourself a favor - pop into the tiny GEM that Pho 2000 and check it out.  You will not leave unsatisfied nor hungry!

a very solid 4 outta 5 stars from me - maybe 4.5 if there was such an option.   Thank you Pho 2000-  You rock!
author: Gibson T.

description:
a good alternative to turtle tower?  you must be joking.

bland and flavorless.  i won't be back.
author: Josie M.

description: Good vietnamese food, fast, good price can't complain. Can't really compare to so-cal but its best to look at whats available in the area.
author: Dang L.

description: We did take-out on the way to Yosemite. Ordered Grilled beef and lemon grass chicken. Good price and pretty good food. Good amount. Grilled Beef was interesting because it was in the shape of rolling green onion stick. I like any kind of onion so it was nice. In the middle of nowhere, it is good to see some Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Kristen Y.

description: Feeling cold and hungry after a long stay at the library and craving some pho.  Walk up to the tenderloin and there are many choices.  I've been to many Vietnamese spot in the city there are so many hits or misses for me I just hate to run into another bland soup.  Luckily today is my lucky day, I found P2.  Ahhhhh, chicken pho have chicken-flavor soup, sorry Turtle, you are not even close to P2.  Pork chops with rice: the meat have lots of flavors(lemon grass)and the rice is done perfectly with a little side salad the way I like them.  It comes with a small side soup.  I walk out the door stuffed. Service is super fast,  and the waiter watch over everyone like a hawk, you can't ever say they ignore you.  Over all a very good experience.  The other pho places must pay attention to what people want; I hope they will learn and improve by reading comments from customers. Then the over all pho standard can improve in the city.
author: Mar H.

description: In Seattle this place would get 4 stars, but San Francisco suffers from a serious lack of quality pho.  Other than this and Turtle Tower, I have not had anything that I would eat again, except at gunpoint.  But really, there's not much I wouldn't eat at gunpoint.
author: Ian S.

description:
Really?  Four Stars?  Maybe just me!

I ordered a seafood noodle soup.  It was decent.  Nothing special.  The broth was just ok.  

I also ordered the Fresh Lemon Soda and it was lack of lemon flavor........

One good thing is the price is pretty cheap compared to other Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Liza T.

description:
Best pho in the City!!! Straight up. 

I went there during today's bomb scare at 450 GG and they weren't even scared! In fact I walked out of there after slurping up a small bowl of pho ga (#13) feeling like Chuck Norris and was going to diffuse the bomb myself but it turned out to be false alarm. That's how good the pho is.

I got pho juice on my tie and plan to throw that away because pho juice is so powerful it might make me super attractive to all walks of life and my lady ain't having it. The pho is that good. 

And if you eat there with your boss and 2 lady coworkers on a strictly platonic lunch meeting, you won't feel like your eating in a rickshaw as you would at Turtle Tower. That's how good the pho is. 

The waiters even have shirts that are lemonade yellow because they bump Gucci Mane in the back... the pho is just that good...
author: Marcos M.

description:
Typical vietnamese restaurant selection. But it has the rice dish with pork chop, shredded pork, and quiche that I like.

Service is good. Restaurant is small but cute.
author: Novalina N.

description: Don't bother to try this place. First there was the argument over what we wanted to order.... They told us it would take too long to make it!!! What? Then they actually made us move tables before our food arrived. Not a relaxing weekday lunch and at this point I don't really care what the food tastes like.
author: Jenn S.

description:
If I'm sad, if it's raining, or it's Monday you'll probably find me at Pho 2000 for lunch.  It makes me so happy.  And, it's fast, cheap, and quality.

$10 gets me a bowl of pho, a Sprite, and includes tip.  Bonus- people are just friendly enough.  Nobody tries to talk to me, so it's perfect for being anti-social and for reading while eating at the table...even if your mom says it's bad manners to do so.
author: R M.

description:
Well I must admit that I'm really surprised by the positive reviews about this place, because I just got out of it with the fear of death!!! Ok so I ordered the number 15, there was supposed to be some crab, shrimp and pork, but it was actually some terrible paste that doesn't look like nothing but shit. I barely touched it and couldn't dare eating it. The smell of the soup was really dubious, and the eggs had a really weird color.

Only one star for the cheap price (thank God I haven't paid more than $7 for that!) and for the noodles, cuz the noodles were actually good and I was hungry.
author: Sherkane D.

description:
I vehemently disagree with the statements that this place is better if not an equivalent to Turtle Tower.  The broth at 2000 is mediocre with a hint of either anise or some other spice I can't quite put my palate on.  The noodles weren't soft, but they weren't tough either...I prefer the texture and width of Turtle Tower, as well as the broth.

If TT is packed, I'd rather wait than eat here.
author: Khristian B.

description: this place used to be very consistent a few years back. i gave this place another shot the other day and man the food was horrible. the service as well here now also sucks. takes forever to order. no one ever goes around to check up on the customers to see if they need or want anything. definately no longer dining here any more. the pho was so hard to put down. too much star anise in the broth that it overwhelms the soup base and thats all you can taste. no matter how much sauce you add you can not mask it. horrible pho
author: Art N.

description: Oh my word this place was delicious, quick and gave HUGE PORTIONS! My large pho was literally a bucket of pho, very generous with the meat and the broth was excellent. My boyfriend had a bbq pork with imperial rolls rice place and it was heavenly and filling, even comes with soup. Service was excellent, I think we've definitely found our pho joint!
author: Kalong W.

description:
My go-to Pho place!!!

Food is consistent and cheap, and the staff is always friendly.
author: Y L.

description: Service rushed and bland as their food.Ordered crab soup, shaken beef and Vietnamese crepe. I asked to bring main dish after we finish soup, but got everything at once, I reminded server my request, he took everything back to the kitchen (open kitchen I could see everything) after we finished soup, cook reheated beef with garlic noodles in a microwave with salad leaves, which came out cooked. Crab soup(bun rieu) had no crab flavor what so ever, bland. Shaken beef was actually good, but garlic noodles weren't garlicky enough. Vietnamese crepe was super greasy, tasteless and starchy. Never going back!
author: Natasha S.

description:
this place has now become my go-to pho place and i have now started comparing other places to this place so i knew i had to update my review.  I come here at least once a week with my coworkers.

#13 small with extra noodles...and a fork.  thanks.
author: Ray R.

description:
The first time I came here it was by accident. I was hungry and confused and trying to go to a recommended Pho place next door. Thank god I stumbled into this place! I had Pho Tai here; my favorite Pho and it was great! The service rules, the complimentary tea is good, and the food is flavorful

I did eventually end up going to the place I had originally intended on that day, Turtle Tower. It didn't stack up to the reviews. I'll be back at Pho 2000 as my go to Pho place from now on!
author: Hope D.

description: Pho 2000 is the nice alternative / plan B / option two to a CROWDED Turtle Tower. It's sorta like when your princess wants the something-something-encrusted salmon and the waitress said they ran outta salmon, so she gets the sea bass, but isn't happy; so she starts sulking and doesn't say much and I know I'm in for a long night of pouting. Well, Pho 2000's pho ga is like that sea bass, except it has the great & tasty broth and the soul-warming aroma with the slurpy noodles. If we ate here and she got the pho ga, then I'm sure all would have been better that night. Hehe...ie, get the pho ga. 3.75 stars rounding up to 4.0.
author: Derek N.

description: I have to say this is one of the better pho place that I have eaten. The broth was great and everything was great. We only got pho so I don't know much to review. It wasn't out of the world pho but I will come back to try their vermicelli to give it a better update and review since those things are the ones that I can review a little better of.
author: Hei Ming C.

description:
I dropped by here for lunch for the first time, the restaurant itself is very clean.  No sticky tables here, definitely a plus for a hole in the wall.  Service was attentive and our orders came out super quick.  

I had the bun rieu and my gf had the bun bo hue.  We both agreed that our soups were okay.  The broth wasn't very flavorful for either.  The bun bo hue did come with a lot of meat and veggies.

3-stars
author: Veronica N.

description: Ordered the mint chicken and bbq pork with shredded pork and steamed egg.  Both were decent but overloaded with MSG.  Cash only.
author: S H.

description:
my absolutely favorite pho in the city! yes it is a bit of a dangerous area so i wouldnt go alone at night (but who eats alone anyway?!?!)

the portion is huge. if u get a large, it is literally bigger than your face. after tax and tips it is slightly over 10 dollars which is not bad for pho in sf (in socal that would be a crime). ive tried 5-7 places around the TL and this is definitely the best one. the broth is amazing! my go to is the pho tai bo vien :) trust me u wont regret it!

tip: u will need to ask fr water...its a super viet thing for them not to bring it without u requesting. but they do give u tea without asking! lol
author: Thach N.

description:
I tried their BBQ pork over rice ( i think they have a name for it, i forgot) it was the best BBQ pork over rice i've ever tried. they don't just use regular steam rice like most restaurants use, they use this special flavored rice. It was super duper good. And yes, like most reviewer mentioned.....the serving size is huge (u get way more than what u pay for) so i even had some leftover for my little brother. he had it for dinner now he is bugging me to go there again. 
oh, and i like.......no i love .......i love how they have the kitchen up front. Don't we all wanna know what we are actually eating? ......... they have the kitchen up front and it is really clean. Definitely going back again soon. 
Pho 2000, if u guys are looking to open another restaurant, please please please come to Millbrae.
author: Kayla A.

description:
While this is my go-to pho joint in SF mainly because of its proximity to me, I still prefer Pho 2000 over pho places in the Tenderloin area for two reasons:

1) The portion here is ridiculously big. A large bowl here is by far one of the bigger bowls of pho I've eaten (and decently priced at $7).

2) The jasmine tea they serve is bombbb. It's free and it's pure delight.

Warning: finishing one of those big bowls is likely going to induce a zombie-like state for the next 3 hours, so don't plan on mountain-biking or something right after.
author: Tom P.

description:
Had a interesting night in SF, so to recover, had to get the cure for hangovers, so decided to get some Pho. This was close the place we were staying at, so decided to drop in. First off, make sure to read the sign outside! (Cash Only) 

So right when you walk in, it's a small restaurant with a second floor. I was kind of worried since we had a big party, and I wasn't sure how they were going to accommodate that. But they took us to the second floor and put together the tables. 

Well the portions are HUGE!! There was a 50 cent different between the small and large, so I had to ask how big was the small. Showed me the other customer who was on the other table, and yeah, a small is good enough for a person. Other friends got the large, and they couldn't even finish. 

Prices were good for it's portions. But I wasn't really digging on the broth. It was kind of bland for me, and had to add more hot sauce to just give it a little bit more of a taste. Overall, it's a good place to go for lunch breaks. The service was decent, the food came out really quick. The servers weren't seen much since we were on the 2nd floor, but they did check on us once.
author: Marc M.

description: Average. Somewhat dirty but fast, reliable service. Pho wasn't bad but too many noodles and not enough veggies/tofu. Definitely better Vietnamese restaurants around the city.
author: Julia W.

description: Love this place.  My favorite vietnamese joint in SF.  Good pho and noodle bowls.  They also give you pretty good portion for being in the City.  I prefer it over Turtle Tower because it is less snobby, has better service, better prices, and better beef broth.
author: J. W.

description: i  haven't Written a review in a few years, DO NOT GO HERE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO. The only reason i did, it was after 5, and the best pho in the TL closes at 5
author: rae m.

description:
It's my go to spot for pho in the neighborhood.  Yes I like southern pho, and these guys seem to know how to do it best.  And I've dared try new things with them like the Bun Rieu Bun Bo Hue, and stuff outside the regular Pho #1, #2, #3.  The soup is actually on the sweeter side, but I guess that's what I like since I can't get enough of it.  With a large only costing $7.40, who can complain.  

I've come here countless times now and it never dissapoints, so this one's here to stay.  Sorry, but no more Them Ky for me.
author: Vincent K.

description: The absolute best tasting Pho in the City.  Fresh, clean, wonderful flavors.  If you are a true Pho lover this is the place!
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description: Their portions and size make it hard to complain.. it's good.  There's really nothing to complain about this hole in the wall place.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
This place has become one of my go-to spots for lunch in the area - and i frequent a lot of them. in general, i think Pho 2000 has always been one of the best bangs for the buck of *any* of the lunch places in the TL. as i've gone through more of their menu, i think they also serve one of the best all-around meals.

compared to my last review, i've stopped ordering the pho because i've found a true treasure in their curry dishes - i like to order the #38 (chicken curry) or #44 (beef curry). i like them because they are a filling, well-rounded meal - you get a descent portion of protein, a good helping of mixed veggies, and a large mound of rice. (love the veggies because it's so hard to find them in a meal these days).
also, while not written on the menu, 99.999% of the time i get served a small bowl of soup made from their pho broth, tofu, and a mixture of veggies (most recently they've started to add mushrooms as well). it's definitely a nice starter to the meal. and, to top it off, they bring you a small pot of tea as soon as you sit down. both of these are at *no additional charge* ! (many of the places around here will charge for tea)

to recap - hot tea, soup, and a filling, well-rounded meal for $7.60 *and* served at any time of the day ! that's Hells to the Yeah mind blowing in this city of 10$+ lunches (i'm also being generous putting out 10$).

Pho 2000 is always a great value for your $$, thus will always have a top spot in my Lunch Rotation.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description:
I honestly come here way too much. I go to school in the Tenderloin, so it's just a short walk up Larkin to get to Pho 2000. I honestly don't understand Turtle Tower's appeal over Pho 2000 (which is right next door). 

The service is speedy, and the broth is always pretty light. Excessively salty food = my pet peeve. I used to get beef, but lately I've switched over to chicken, because the broth tastes lighter. People here are nice, and the spring rolls are delicious. My friend is a vegetarian, and when they're not busy and we want to split an order of spring rolls, they make half just shrimp, and half shrimp and pork (for me). I think that's nice. Lol. The only downside is that the noodles are kind of inconsistent. Sometimes theyre perfectly chewy and not overly soaked, but sometimes they're sticky and starchy tasting. I've only been disappointed a few times though. Overall, delish.
author: Lillian K.

description:
I work around the corner and have tried both Turtle Tower and Pho 2000 and they are both delightful, however I do prefer Pho 2000 for a few reasons:

1. No waiting. Turtle Tower almost always has a long line. I've never experienced more than a few min wait at Pho 2000.
2. The service: Lightening fast  and friendly service. You get your Pho, free tea, and plate of fixins in mere moments.
3. The ingredients/quantity: I'm a slave to rare beef Pho and they really hook it up here. Lots of really delicious pieces in every bowl. Also, their broth is just right. Meaty, hot, salty, and not too oily. 
4. The slogan: On their shirts it says "It's Pho-nominal." I love me a good pun. 

Don't be afraid to avoid the masses next door and try Pho 2000!
author: Lindsay W.

description:
Just got takeout from this place-- it was fantastic. Totally worth a trek through the not-so-fun TL. I will usually only get pho from Turtle Tower in the outer Richmond: it's been a reliably great tradition near my parents house. I  couldn't get to the outer Rich tonight, so I tried to visit Turtle Tower's new location on Larkin. I couldn't believe they closed at 5, so I visited Pho 2000 instead. 
I always get a large chicken pho and an imperial roll appetizer. I was extremely pleased with both. This place uses thin noodles and I do like the flat noodles better. But in any event, I could tell they were really fresh and thats's the most important thing. They include a good amount of thinly sliced white onion, which I love. The chicken is Just cooked when you get it, so it doesnt get over cooked when you reheat it, which is brilliant. A lot of places can't get that right, and the chicken ends up getting dry and chewy. There was some really delicious crunchy topping that came on top of the chicken and noodles. I'm guessing that there are various styles of pho cuisine from different regions, because I notice where I get some toppings, I don't get others (fish sauce).  The rolls were way better portioned than what I get at Turtle Tower, and not greasy at all. All in all, better value here than Turtle Tower, I think.
author: Elle M.

description:
This place is a hidden treasure in the Tenderloin. Great big bowls of piping hot pho loaded with meat. Lots of great authentic dishes and outstanding appetizers like spring rolls. Make sure to bring cash, although a "Jackson" will get you a feast and then some. 

Delicious, cheap, clean, English, fast...the place is just money!
author: Ed L.

description: I had the pho tai chin (brisket and rare steak) and it was delicious! I am from the Orange County area so I have had plenty of Vietnamese cuisine (I am Viet afterall) and this place took me by surprise with how good it was. The soup was perfect, light but with enough flavor that i actually did NOT need hoisin or sriracha sauce (I usually douse my pho soup with them). The beef though, man oh man, the beef was so fresh and tender - most places I've been too seem to serve old, dry, chewy beef pieces - but THIS place did it so perfectly. AND AND AND, your pho comes out in less than 5 min from ordering.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Much better than Turtle Tower next door!

Small Pho $6.95
Large Pho $7.95 (I think)

But they really should rename the dishes on menu:

Large Pho $6.95
Bucket of Pho $7.95

Seriously, guys.  This portions here are simply ridiculous (in a good way).  I'd strongly recommend this place for two hungry people-- order 1 Bucket of Pho and 1 Spring Roll ($5.95) to split.

The pho here tastes so much better!  Though it's the ordinary machine noodles here, and rather ordinary noodles, this place is consistent.  Great hangover food.  I don't know why people talk up Turtle Tower so much.
author: Eugene L.

description:
It was a cold and rainy day...perfect for pho!  A cursory search for "top rated" pho places led us to turtle tower...but there was a line out the door, and Pho 2000 two doors down.  Easy decision, we sit down at pho 2000 and make our tummies happy.

I got the pho special (as far as I could tell it had everything in it), and it was flavorful and not too small.  I feel like my broth wasn't hot enough, though, as it didn't burn me at first sip and didn't soften the sprouts I put in.  But, I don't really care that my sprouts weren't cooked and burning my tongue isn't my favorite activity anyway.

Parking at Sunday around noon was quick and easy, so I would see myself coming back.
author: Cathy Y.

description: Maybe its just because I don't like weird meat and that is what I got in my pho at Turtle Tower, that I like Pho 2000 better...but I think its also the thinner noodles, the atmosphere, the service, the imperial rolls, and the veggie option that make me really just like this place a lot (more). The people who work here are super nice, the restaurant is cute and cozy and the soup has great flavor - I love the Veggie version - very fresh and plentiful veggies & tofu. Also, the imperial rolls are the first I've found in a while that are served with the lettuce, cukes, and mint leaves - I LOVE this (plus they can be veggie!). I look forward to trying other things on the menu, but its hard when I know how good the pho is!
author: M-Britt L.

description:
It's strange that not many people would dare to try this place just because it's next to turtle tower. Don't judge too quickly based on the number of reviews these two places have had.  

It's important to note that turtle tower serves northern styled Vietnamese pho, whereas we're more commonly subjected to that of southern types in san Francisco. 

That said, I'd have to admit that despite the odd name of this place and it's horrid location, it still remains to be one of my favorite pho places based in how honest this place is. Fresh ingredients, non fussy service and occasionally a baseball game in the background really adds up well.
author: Denise T.

description:
Surprised this is rated a 4 star overall, ordered #1.

Broth - too strong in anise and cinnamon.
Noodle - avg
Herbs - basil was not fresh
Meat - beefball seemed like it was what you can buy from the grocery, and not a good texture, the rare meets were avg.

with all the competition in the neighborhood, expected to be wowed... but came away extremely disappointed.   Don't be fooled by the cheap price, $6.99 for a number 1... i rather pay a dollar more for better broth, herbs, meats at Ha Nam Nimh.
author: Vien C.

description:
Today was my first time sitting upstairs since I'm always seated on the first level. I always thought there was another kitchen upstairs haha. Must take a lot of experience to be carrying bowls of hot liquid up those stairs and hoping not to trip... cause man that would suck.

Been here a few times, and yes the portions are BIG. The regular size is more than enough, lots of noodles and lots of meat. But the large bowl... you can see from afar how big it is! 

The soup could be more hotter. Since I requested my steak on the side, the temp changed rather quickly.  Noodles today were not al dente and quickly soggy mid-bowl. Broth however was delicious mmm. My pho spot in the TL
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I was in the area for Jury Duty and it was really cold so  Pho sounded really good.

Ordered the Rare Steak and Beef Balls Large and it was good. Lots of meats and the soup were tasty. 

Next day I opted for the Rice Plate: Grill Pork with Egg Rolls. It was nasty, the pork were hard and looks like it was cooked earlier but reheated.  Egg Rolls were pretty good though.

I've should of known Pho 2000 = Soup only
author: DVS A.

description:
Came here with a friend who really likes this place... I thought it was okay. I got the Bun Bo Hue because I felt like something spicy. It actually didn't turn out to be spicy at all, so I was pretty disappointed. I did, however, really like the vermicelli noodles because they were the perfect thickness and bounciness. The meat, mainly the cha lua, was pretty good (would've been better if I were feeling the burn from the spiciness). Oh, and the portions are huuuge.

Food came quickly and service was good - our busser was an eager beaver and wanted to take away our bowls every time we put our chopsticks down. The place itself is kind of small but has a decent amount of tables. Everything looked and felt clean, so we're good on hygiene. 

I usually rate pho restaurants based on their pho, so if I'm ever in the area again (probably never), I'll try the pho and post an update.
author: Katie M.

description:
When I'm craving a solid bowl of pho, quick service and reasonable prices, Pho 2000 is my go-to place in the Tenderloin.  I'm not a Turtle Tower fan. Give me my bean sprouts, hoisin sauce, and sriracha any day!

Like most Vietnamese restaurants, Pho 2000 has huge bowls of pho for very reasonable prices.  Although I was seated upstairs, the service was quick and efficient.  

Tip: Cash only!
author: Monelle A.

description: Not bad... at least in comparison to their neighbor Turtle Tower. I liked their imperial rolls better. I ordered bun bo hue and the broth was pretty good not too salty, just enough kick. Warning XL is HUGE!!!! Thankfully I didn't get that size.
author: Stephen Y.

description: This is our spot for pho. Cheap, delicious, fast and friendly service. As long as you're cool with some homelessness near by (thank you, Tenderloin), you'll love Pho 2000.
author: Shayna M.

description: The pho tai was delicious!  The shrimp fried rice was good, but not amazing...but we were not even hungry for it after the amazing pho. I'll go back!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
I was feeling terrible of becasue of my sore throat and headache. I needed some pho ga to fight off this impending sickness. It was late lunch time on a Monday - walked right passed the line next door at Turtle P(t)ower.  I walked right in and sat next to another guy and shared a table. He was quiet and was finishing up, cool... Service was quick and efficient. I ordered a small $6.50(if I remember correctly) chicken pho. Large was $6.99. 

The pho was tasty and it came with the usual basil, lemon and sprouts. It was Delish!! I added the siracha, and the sweet brown sauce condiment -- I forget the name... Anyway I felt like I was cured! but it was only short lived... Definitely would recomment to anyone and will go again.
author: Ron P.

description:
Oh my little pho-bot, you do all sorts of cray-cray things to my mouth.  This latest time, I got a HUGE steam burn on the roof of my mouth after popping a delicious piece of freshly fried Imperial Roll, wrapped in lettuce leaf, garnished with a mint leaf and drizzled with this golden syrup and noodle-like stuff.  

Did I learn after this one painful blast to the roof of my soul?  Nope.  I wrapped up another leaf with the same condiments, thinking that if I DROWNED the Imperial Roll in the sauce, it'll chill the steam.  I was so wrong.  And now, there's no more roof of my mouth.  Only a hole to the top of my head.

Oh to the pho:  I got the #7, tendon and rare steak, this time with the beef on the side.  I've decided this is the way to eat it.  And I'll tell you how so you don't troll the interwebs for some vague reference to this cuisine procedure.  You take a slice.  Float it around on the soup.  Let it turn the appropriate pink color.  And then shyly dunk in the vat of red hot sauce and fish sauce.  Then place atop your spoonful of noodle.  Slurp.  Wipe red spatter off of nose.  And off of forehead.  And off of your chin.  DO NOT walk out of restaurant with red splatter all over your chin.  It will be humiliating to be more stared-at than the crack addict sleeping on a fold out.  

The only thing I do not like about this place is the lack of ventilation.  I get quite hot when eating pho.  Quite hot.  And i'd like to not sweat through my shirt like a menopausal elephant.  

Did I mention that this bowl was the size of my bathtub?  For $5.75.  Yes.  You can bath in beef broth for less than it costs to take the BART to the airport.
author: Christina C.

description: I like this place, " PHO 2000!"  Pho in the twenty first century, pretty cool.  I've eaten more than a few times.  They have a user friendly menu with photos to refer to.  Fast service.  I'm usually at, Pho Tan Hoa on Jones St., but the pho is, "Pho-nomenal!" which is spelled out in the back of their polo shirts.  I like their rice plates too.  I usually order the BBQ Pork & egg roll over rice with vegetables.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Turtle Tower was closed, so I wandered in next door at Pho 2000. Not disappointed that I did. It's a beef house, but very respectable broth and very friendly and prompt service. Good find!
author: David G.

description: To sum it up in one sentence: I just called them and they put msg in their food, but this is the best pho I have ever tried.
author: Kyle C.

description:
+HUGE bowls of pho, and I'm just talking about the regular size
+Great prices for the portions
+Quick service and never too long of a wait
+Friendly service
+Great menu options to choose from
+conveniently located close by other eateries like Red Crawfish, Saigon Sandwich, Hai Ky, and other options!
*Cash only


Cheers to a good find! I came here with coworkers because today just felt like a "pho day", and you know what I'm talking about. I read about the big portions at this place and that was enough to sell me. I looked over the menu and as I did, I looked over and saw spring rolls at another table. It looked so delicious that it was no longer a pho day but a vermicelli day! I ordered the charbroiled pork with spring roll vermicelli for $6.99. It came first and I was impressed. Again, it was served in a huge bowl with tons of noodles and a good meat ratio too! The spring rolls were crispy and delicious. 

The regular pho bowl costs about $6.25 and the large was a little over $7? Either way, the food was really great and there's plenty of seating downstairs and upstairs. They also have guava candy when you pay at the register!
author: Connie C.

description: Deceptive customer service. We popped in for dessert and they charged us a $3.50 "service charge" - without telling us. If they want to assess such a charge that's fine, but at least announce it so we can choose to pay it. Shame, because the food is good.
author: Aneesh R.

description: Good vegetarian pho at reasonable price. The Pho was flavorful and the rice noodles were very good. Definitely recommend this place to vegetarians and non-vegetarians.  It will be my go to place when I am craving for spicy soup.
author: Sid P.

description:
Good, solid place which is consistent with service and their quality of food.
Free tea? Yes please!
Huge array of veggies to go with your pho- thanks! Could use more peppers though.. I always have to ask for more.

1 medium bowl of hot, delicious pho tai (rare beef and noodles), and a huge glass of coconut milk comes out to around $10 including tax. Which sits right in my book. 

There's tons of seating- I like sitting in the upstairs area. I always see groups of people here so I'd say it's a great place to brings friends to enjoy some yummy vietnamese food. 
The family that runs this joint are accommodating and really nice. 

The broth, in general, is so flavorful! A huge step from Turtle Tower (I understand they're souther vietnamese so maybe thats the difference). 

Its starting to get foggy again, and the cool, crisp, fall air is setting in. You beat your bottom dollar you'll find me here on my days off!

Ps- CASH ONLY!
author: Amanda S.

description: YESSS! This is my favorite place to get pho in SF! It cures hangovers, fills me up and warms my heart on a cool SF day. If you love pho you need to try this place. SO GOOD!
author: Shanna T.

description: The large bowl of Pho is pretty massive, taste is o.k.  For me the price point bumps em up from 3 to 4 stars.
author: Eric C.

description:
The food is just okay but they earned the 3 stars with their service. 

I received my take out within a few minutes and was offered tea while I was waiting.
author: Jacky Z.

description:
3.5 stars 

Haven't been to this area for a while.  There are a few new places since and after looking around and debating for a while, Pho 2000 is the chosen spot - part of the reason being they serve bun bo hue.

It's small with sitting downstairs and upstairs.  The noodle making kitchen is to the left as you enter with large pots brewing the broth.  We sat down near the back and scanned through the menu although we both knew what we wanted.

Hubby had the #1 - combo large ($6.95?) and I had the bun bo hue ($6.95?) along with the imperial rolls ($5.50) and an iced coffee ($2.99).  

The imperial rolls - there were two in each cut into 4 pieces served with leaves of lettuce, rice noodle, cilantro, mint leaves, bowl of sweetened fish sauce and a few pieces of pickled carrot and cucumber.  The rolls were crispy but the filling wasn't very flavorful so the dipping sauce was needed.  

The combo large was quite generous with lots of noodles and fixings.  The broth was light and flavorful.  It's served with the standard bean sprouts, slices of jalapeno peppers and basil.  

The bun bo hue was ok, even though I asked for extra spicy.  Luckily, they have some chili oil that I can add.  There were quite a bit of meat, which I don't care for and only 3 small cubes of the pork blood cake, which was good and a few thin slices of the pork loaf.  The soup was ok, not rich like it should.  This was served with thinly sliced cabbage, bean sprouts, slices of jalapeno pepper and a kind of leave that's long and narrow with a nice scent/taste.

The iced coffee was good.  They brought out the dripping coffee and a glass of ice - while we were eating the pho, the ice melted.  The man behind the register replaced it with a glass of fresh ice - that was really nice and the first time this had ever happened at any restaurant.
author: Gloria H.

description: My friendly neighborhood pho spot. When I am not in the mood for chicken pho I go here. They have a huge selection of Viet and Chinese dishes. Clean and clean need I say more.
author: Linda L.

description: Pho broth had great flavors. Not at all salty. Had the pho tai. Large portion was huge. Could not finish it. Fast and efficient service.
author: Cara D.

description:
I mostly gave this place 5 stars because I absolutely HATED Turtle Tower next door -- overpriced, couldn't even finish my meal there. I read somewhere on here that someone wanted veggie pho? I don't know WHAT that is but the Pho Tai rare beef was excellent. The broth is exceptional. The service was fast, and they were even kind of polite -- politeness isn't something I'm used to, as I usually eat pho in Westminster, CA. This isn't the BEST pho I've ever had, but this is definitely on my top best bowls of pho ever. Inexpensive, at that.

Come here, don't go to Turtle Tower -- it's overpriced and not run by Vietnamese people. It tastes so inauthentic. I don't trust a Swedish person would know how to make authentic Mexican food well, would you?
author: Sharee R.

description:
Holy Shit, I love PHO! 

This Pho is great, cheap and hot! Just the way I crave it on a hangover morning or a cold night.
author: Nene D.

description: This review is long over due.  Hands down the best PHO ever.  The staff is great, the room is great the food is FANTASTIC.  So comforting, the first spot i stop at after being out of town.
author: Paul O.

description: Great Pho place, 100 times better than turtle tower.. funny how people say turtle tower has some better dishes but that place is real dirty. Pho 2000 is nice and clean and they make really good viet food. Probably one of the best places in the city.
author: Ryan U.

description:
I walked into here expecting to order Bun and had even ordered it when I saw a big hunk of meat floating at the top of a pot of soup. When I saw that I had to turn it around and I ordered the Pho Tai and boy howdy am I glad I did!

Not saying the Bun isn't good, looked like people probably enjoyed it, but the broth of the beef soup was souper tasty. The meat was a little less than plentiful, but the soup itself was enormousness!

The ice coffee was standard.

Only big downside to this place is that if you want rolls you have to come with a group of people. There is really no way to get rolls for a single person here...They come in groups of 6 as pictured on this page...But other than that, awesome sauce!
author: H B.

description: Being Vietnamese, I grew up eating Pho. So I do call myself a Pho expert. I have traveled around the nation eating Pho. The Pho here tastes like diluted broth. Probably the worst Pho I have ever had. There seems to be a miss on spices like star anise, cinnamon, etc.  I actually tried the pho twice ( on two separate occasions) just to confirm that my palate was right. I think they really need to evaluate their broth (since it is the most important element in PHO. The 2nd time I had PHO there, they gave me wilted bruised basil. I don't know if they were just not caring that day, but for me, that shows I was not important to them. I would never give my customers anything that looks dead. Presentation is key. You guys really disappoint me. Sorry. I will no longer support your business. Twice was enough. On a positive note, the tea was good..
author: Linh V.

description:
I was bummed to find Turtle Tower closed on the one day I was running errands in the City. That joint is the shiznit of pho, imho. Yet, I had a pho-king hunger to fill and only 25 minutes on the meter. I noticed this new place, it was crowded, so I rolled my dice.

I ordered the bun bo hue, which was decent except for the pork blood. Didn't taste fresh to me, but the noodles were good and there was enough beef and fish cake to satisfy me. In addition to the sprouts and rau ram one finds on the side with jalapeno slices and a wedge of lime was shredded cabbage, which didn't really break down well in the broth and scratched my throat as I tried to eat it with my noodles. The broth was savory, not very heavy and tasted very beefy.

It was enough to satisy my pho-king hunger.
author: May T.

description:
This place must get a lot of the leftover turtle tower customers who show up to eat there after 7pm and realize they're already closed. that's how we ended up here. 

Turns out that it's actually pretty good. Broth is not oily, yet still flavorful. Lots of meat. Spring rolls are good. Had the crepe last time and it was yummy even tho they messed up and gave us the vegetarian version. 

I've been eating soooo much pho! This place is on my list of pho places in the city from now on.
author: Cynthia C.

description: I like the customer service here. People were very nice to me. I order chicken pho and spring rolls. They were both very decent. Highly recommended for lunch
author: Aniko N.

description: Very decent pho place based on my one lunch experience here during which I ordered the crab paste noodle which comes in a tomato soup base which often hits the spot.  Actually, that day my plan was to visit Turtle Tower, only to find that they closed their original location and is still in the process of construction their new one on the same block.  When in this area for Vietnamese (especially when walking on this block of Larkin Street), Turtle Tower gets most of the attention. In the meantime, I may have more opportunity to visit this shop if in the area.
author: H K.

description: I have been dying to try pho 2000 and today was that day. I had an especially crazy craving for banh beo and decided to call pho 2000 to make sure they had it. The guy said yes therefore I was like cool!  I'll get to try the bun bo hue and satisfy my banh beo craving, but upon my arrival and requesting banh beo they said they didn't make it. I was shocked and let down! But their bun bo hue was AWESOME & YUMMY. My friend had the bun rieu, she's the bun rieu queen and she said pho 2000's bun rieu is alright. Overall, on the bun bo hue alone I will give them 5 stars!
author: Jackie M.

description:
Best Pho in San Francisco. Nothing compares to San Jose Pho, but Pho 2000 comes the closest.

The large bowls are very BIG, so order at your own caution. A regular bowl is just enough to consume, even if you are starving. 

You can't go wrong with spring rolls here, either.

The staff are friendly and courteous, and if you speak Vietnamese, do so.You get a discount! Gotta love those Vietnamsssss!
author: Mike N.

description: The beef pho was disappointing.  The eggs rolls are awesome.  The crab soup with noodles is the dish to order.
author: Fatty A.

description: After eating 6 blow pops in one morning, I needed some sugar anti-venom.  Enter vegetarian pho.  Nothing better on a rainy, cold, stressful Friday. The seating area is pretty large considering how small the restaurant is, and the service was great.
author: Lynn M.

description:
0. This place is the bomb Ph spot in the TL. Turtle Tower is overrated. 

1. Sit downstairs and watch the flatscreen or upstairs and watch the people downstairs. You won't be bored!

2. Remember to order your Ph with beef on the side, don't be an uncultured rube. 

3. The rice dishes are good too. The BBQ pork over rice was tasty as hell!
author: JT X.

description: Oh my God! What great food!  Fast service as well!  I highly recommend this restaurant! I had the #17, noodles with pork and spring roll! Cannot wait to go back!
author: Paul M.

description:
My trip to San Francisco landed me in the heart of Little Saigon where my hotel happened to be located (Phoenix Hotel, to be reviewed later.) I am literally spitting distance from great Vietnamese food. So many choices, so many decisions. 

Well, I took a chance and it paid off. SF is the Bizarro world version of LA.- there are great bars in walking distance, people are friendly with no attitude, people are stylish and smart and a place called Pho 2000 actually serves really awesome pho. It's located next to revered Turtle Tower, a popular and alluded pho establishment according to locals, but I am so glad I chose Pho 2000. They were quick, the broth was hot and yummy and they served free jasmine tea. At $6.25 for a bowl, it was a great deal. They also had the freshest sprouts I had ever seen- so lily white and crisp!

Made me very happy to eat here :)
author: N Justine K.

description: My friend and I were working a convention in SF and we were craving some pho so we Yelped a place in downtown Little Saigon.. the place we originally looked for was closed so we walked a little further and found Pho 2000.  Really happy we came here.  The spring rolls we ordered were very fresh.  The pho was absolutely fantastic.  The broth was so savory and the meat was very fresh.  We came back a few days later and I had the Bun Rieu.  Again, the broth was excellent.  The crab/ minced pork meat was hearty but I would have liked to see some bigger chunks of it.  But I still thoroughly enjoyed it.  I would definitely come back again and again when i visit San Fran.
author: John B.

description:
Their regular Pho is decent and price is reasonable.  When they first opened, my partner and I frequent this place religiously to help it grow and hope it makes the cut.  After ordering Vegetarian Pho, we stopped coming to this place and noticed the place is empty most of the time and constantly looking for new waiter and kitchen help.  If a place is going to put an item on the menu, at least make it decent enough so the customer don't feel like they are throwing away their money.  The veggie was raw and the broth was water and MSG.  I could make a better Veggie Pho at home.
---------------------
Like - cheap and decent pho
Dislike - Bad Vegetarian Pho, rice dishes are average, egg-rolls not tasty enough and sometimes burnt, service is average.

-----------------------------------
Parking - street parking only
Recommend - go nextdoor to Turtle Tower for Chicken Pho - you will be glad you did.  Sorry Pho 2000.  I don't know if I will try you again though to change my rating.  Maybe an invite from you will help.
author: Duke D.

description:
In my opinion a lot better than Turtle Tower next door, but not quite as nice and refined as Golden Star.

I really liked their Pho broth, and the meat has a good taste as well. Vietnamese iced coffee always recommended. Haven't really tried anything else.
author: X O.

description:
Large #1 and Cha Gio!

The broth that they have for their pho just tastes a lot better & cleaner than any other pho shop in the city.  It might be because the kitchen is fully transparent or I might just be crazy.

I love that their fried egg rolls comes w/ the vermicelli, lettuce, celantro & cucumber.  They are pretty big too.

Need to try their Bun Rieu and BBH next time.
author: Bill Z.

description: Very very good, and amazingly large portions, I was unable to finish a medium portion of Pho and spring rolls. I am considered a big eater :)
author: Olivier D.

description: I'm actually not big on Pho, but these places always have the rice plates and noodle dishes I love.  Had the #17, Vermicelli bowl with pork and egg rolls (imperial rolls).  Great rolls.  Fine amount and quality of pork.  Could have used a tad more in the veggie department.  Note to those how hate cilantro as I do: they put a TON on it which I didn't know, however luckily it was piled up in one spot so I could scoop it mostly out.  Just need to ask for it not on, so no big deal if that's not your thing.  Clean restaurant, especially considering where you are coming off the street.  Toothpicks at the table and all the sauces you could want.  Fair price at $9 out the door.  Oh, and the tea was probably the best free tea I ever had.  I'm not that big on tea, but I could see this bringing it up to a 5 if I were.  Very flavorful and flowery tasting.
author: Marc S.

description: The service was quick and friendly. I had the number 4 and was rather put off by the meat quality and hard noodles. The broth was decent but not great. I shared a table with someone who ordered the same bowl and I noticed him picking out the unsightly meat. Let me put it this way, the flank steak literally made me gag. That was when I gave up, paid and left.
author: Crystal P.

description:
Amazing Pho! Amazing price! BRING CASH!

Get the #6 Beef Pho, it will change your
Life. A light and buttery broth, so delicious. The spring rolls are dynamite. Anything with pork here is flavor central. A nice selection of vegetarian options as well. 2 entrees, 15 bucks! Ask for Sam, he's the man. Consistently great food and service.

Everyone raves about Turtle Tower next door, but the real Vietnamese gem is right here! And the staff, very attentive and nice to you. They want you here.
author: Sean S.

description:
when i walked into this place, i was reminded that i had been here before, but it was a turkish restaurant at the time.  fast forward 5 years later, and it's now a pho restaurant.  we shared the imperial rolls, veg banh xeo, and i had the seafood pho.  everything was good.  the pho broth is a bit sweeter than i would have liked, but it was nothing a squeeze of lime wouldn't fix.  the rolls were awesome and came w/ a ton of garnishes, including rice noodles, lettuce for wrapping, etc.  

portions here are huge, so it's a great bang for the buck.
author: Helen T.

description:
Consistency. 

That is why I like this place.  Growing up in Orange County, home of the best Vietnamese food in the country, I was awe struck by the high prices and bad tastes of Vietnamese food in other areas such as West Los Angeles and certain parts of San Francisco.  Pho 2000 provides a consistent middle of the road option.  It is not fantastic, but its not bad either.  It is basically a run of the mill joint similar to those back in OC with reasonable prices as well.
author: Bert N.

description: One of the newer establishments in the area, I was wondering how well they would do amongst so much competition. We are in Little Saigon. I think they do quite well. I was very happy with my Pho and GF loved her "chicken noodle soup". In fact, we pick this spot over the always-packed Turtle Tower Restaurant just a couple of doors down.
author: Helen L.

description: This is our go-to pho place when we want pho. I think their pho is better than Turtle Tower. The portions are big, the broth is done right, the restaurant feels authentic, and the prices are reasonable. Pho is the bessst!
author: Jamie C.

description: Was in SF and looking for some good Vietnamese food. I had no issues with the place. The staff quickly seated me and took my order. The portions were huge and was very good. I would come back again.
author: Omar K.

description:
It's places like these that make me miss San Francisco and the Bay Area, and when I say "places like these," I mean, REALLY good Vietnamese food that isn't difficult to find and doesn't break the bank.

My family and I came here for lunch today and we shared two orders of the banh xeo (Vietnamese sizzling rice crepes), an order of beef pho, and an order of bun bo hue (spicy beef soup with large, round rice noodles). The banh xeo here is probably one of the best ones I have had at a restaurant - super crisp on the outside, slightly chewy on the inside, and very generous with the pork and shrimp fillings. Most places tend to skimp on the fillings, but not Pho 2000. 

The bun bo hue had a really flavorful broth, and again, lots of beef - no skimping here! I didn't try too much of the pho, but the broth was really rich. The nuoc mam/fish sauce here is also pretty tasty - perfect for dipping my banh xeo.

I like the loft setup of the place - we sat on the second floor and watched them cook at the front of the restaurant, an open kitchen setup. Service is really friendly and fast. Ambiance is very modern and casual. Lots of people were eating here (Vietnamese people speaking Vietnamese!), so you can rest assured that this place is not catering towards those who do not know their Vietnamese food.

Not a huge fan of the name of the place, but who cares when the food is good and the service is friendly and efficient?
author: Yvonne W.

description:
Basically doing this review cause i just came in to order food to go since i was still hungry after eating at Pagolac about 4 houses to the left.

Can't really give much review since i ordered to go, instead of eating at the restaurant. Ordered a rice plate and 2 vermicelli dish, which i forgot the name. Ordered it sat down, and the waiters were nice enough to give us tea, even though we ordered it to go. Gave them props for that, thats why it's 4 stars. Rarely you see people being that considerate to offer anything when you order to go. 

Didn't really eat the vermicelli plate till right now, as i am typing the review on it.
The meat taste great, even though it was left cold for about 4 hours.
The egg rolls are okay, prob cause its cold.
Other than that, i give props to those 2 Vietnamese guy waiters for being nice. Hopefully they do that to almost everyone.
author: Alex M.

description:
I'm one of the many who come out to Turtle Tower and discover it's closed so walk over to this nearby place instead. The strange name aside, I'm glad that me and a friend decided to venture in here when Turtle Tower was closed.

You'll be greeted by a pretty clean interior (notable for the Tenderloin district it is in) and friendly attentive service. They have a pretty good sized menu besides just pho (it does not have 2000 varieties of said pho however) .

Pho wise it was pretty good, nothing fancy that I would write home about but for the price, it was definitely right. In addition, the tea they served here, I dunno what they have in it but it was addictive and I couldn't get enough of it.
author: Roland C.

description: My fiance and I went here for lunch. We have been making our own pho at home and did not think much of what we had. Staff was very friendly though and the place was lively. Very reasonable prices, just watch the homeless and drunks in the street.
author: craig s.

description:
A rose by any other name, is still pho. Funny that other reviewers also have an issue with the name of the business. "Pho 2000" evokes to me a pretty cheesy name, some sort of technological or modern reference that has no bearing in the pho/restaurant business. If anything, Pho 1850 (or some turn of the century date) would have been more appropriate in evoking a long standing business, with old, mysterious ways of cooking pho broth. Maybe we'll revisit this place in 30 years and it might make more sense. 

In any case, on to the food - I was having a sore throat, so I had some shivers and lack of appetite. We were supposed to go to the pho place literally around the corner, but being that it was already closed, we went to this one instead. As pointed out above, the name made me raise an eyebrow as to question the quality of the food within, but luckily for them, they had a 'Yelp loves us' sticker, which reassured me that this wasn't just any hole in the wall place, and on we went.

I ordered the pho ga (raw beef) and, despite the fact that I couldn't eat much of the vermicelli noodles, the soup itself was pretty tasty and it had a fair amount of meat there. The place was clean and well lit as well, so I can see myself keeping it as an option for vietnamese should I be around the area.
author: Rogerio F.

description: Moved to San Fran four months and have been on a mission to find the everyday pho place! And this is it!!! Great price, great service and awesome pho! We will definitely be back a lot!
author: Rachel O.

description:
Beef pho here has no depth of flavor in the broth. It's just not very good.

After eating lunch here, my 2 friends and I had massive stomach aches. Granted, it's somewhat aggressive to eat pho for lunch but still... MASSIVE. There's so many other pho spots on the block, it just doesn't seem worthwhile to give it any more chances (2 is enough).

Their bun "bowls" are also overpriced.
author: Alli J.

description: We walked quite a blocks looking for some pho from Japantown and we found 2 pho restaurant, one was next door and was packed so we decided to come here. We were wondering why it was so dead and next door was so packed? I think maybe it was "Cash only" but neways I had to go to Lee's sandwiches to withdraw cash. We ordered some eggs rolls and pho. The egg rolls were good. The pho was good too but I didn't really care for the cinnamon taste in my broth. Although it satisfied my soup and pho cravings I would like to try the one next door the next time I'm in SF.  Then I'll decide which one has better pho. The place was clean and service was good!
author: Meuy R.

description: Doing a pho tai taste test in the TL.  (Excluding Northern Vietnamese pho).  I walked away thinking that it was the best pho in the TL.  (The broth is on the sweet side though.)  Pho 2000 also can make you a vegetable pho.
author: Wakako U.

description: True authentic Vietnamese flavors in Little Saigon.  All your familiar Viet dishes are done better here.  A large selection of soup noodle not available at other places like pork blood pho.
author: Laurence H.

description: Their broth is delicious. I had a bbq pork rice plate with a side of soup and left pretty stuffed (dinner under $10) The layout is an open kitchen with a seating area so you get to experience other patrons food as well with everything being done about 2 feet away from where you sit. The bathroom was pretty clean too!
author: Maria M.

description:
I immediately admit I am biased as I just got back from visiting Vietnam and gorging on pho on a daily basis (even twice a day) - so I expect the same soupy awesomeness from US establishments!
Straight to the test with a classic pho bò tái (the beef soup with half-done fillet + tendons and tripe) - the bowl is big (and that's just the regular) and has lots of noodles - which can be good or bad, but in this case it filled me up to bursting - moderation, you say? not me, especially when it came to all that salty goodness that came with the soup.  Overall, it was a normal ok south Vietnamese soup, nothing special but good flavor. 

On a side I ordered a bowl of plain bún cha (chopped-up egg rolls served over vermicelli  and nc chm salad) - salad was good, egg rolls were really A-OK - will not get them here next time.

I will stick to the good ole pho!
author: Paolo D.

description:
This place is pretty decent, cheap and open later than the other vietnamese places in the area. 

The pho is pretty standard and large. I just had the rare steak and it was good. My boyfriend got the rice plate with pork and egg rolls which looked ok. Good place to go if you're craving cheap vietnamese late.
author: Abbey S.

description: Was ok - trying to find good Pho is hard to do - comes down to broth and freshness - I've been trying to find anything to beat Turtle Tower  and am coming up dry - was an interesting place, good service, nice Imperial Rolls, but when it came to the beef broth for the Pho (I am usually ordering the Beef Pho with rare sliced beef, tendon and brisket), it wasn't up to TT benchmark - not bad, not great, average
author: Richard D.

description:
yes it is good. it has yummy broth, it has enough meat, it's a very good portion and the  price is very good for what you get.  The place is clean, the people are friendly and service is standard for a pho place.

I had the spring rolls too and they were good. Not the best thing ever, I think my bf and I make better ones but these were good.  

Will definitely come back. Very satsifactory.

On a scale of 1 (low) - 10 (High) 
Level of satisfaction overall: 9
Taste: 8.5
Price: $20 for 2 people (2 bowls 1sm, 1 lrg and spring rolls)
author: Zu W.

description: The vegetarian vermicilli had that special "something extra" that made it not just good, but extraordinary. A quck, clean and inexpensive place to eat.
author: Thomas C.

description: I had better bun hue elsewhere so this one wasn't very impressive. There's something missing.....perhaps the soup is not spicy enough? The bun hue here is not entirely bad, at least compared to other mediocre pho places in SF. The thing I like here is the portion - it's really big for the price. It was great to sit upstairs overlooking the open kitchen and the lower floor. I might come back again for other dishes,
author: Jamie L.

description: Go there at night.  Plenty of parking.  There's so many Vietnamese restaurants to choose from.  This one is bright and the yellow walls is so cheerful.  Good broth in the pho.  Small size seems so big.  They do give the basil leaves and the bean sprouts.  Imperial rolls are crunchy and not at all greasy.  Loved the Jasmine tea, can't figure out if there's rose flavor in it.
author: Helen L.

description:
As the servers at Pho 2000 proudly wear emblazoned on their uniforms, this place is "PHO-NOMENAL!!!" Leave it to an off-yellow shirt with red script to summarize the experience at this cozy restaurant.

For being in the neighborhood that it's in (hey, no disrespect- I heart the 'Loin), this restaurant is clean. Boasting two stories of pho-tastic space, Pho 2000 gets all crazy and switches it up by having the kitchen in the FRONT!! Whaaaaaaa? We can actually SEE what's going into our food. That immediately made me smile.

The wait staff are efficient and aim to please. They hustle as needed and they don't cop any attitude. Willing to make substitutions, answer my dorky questions, and accept my 15% off coupon (score!).

On the important stuff- the food is pho-king awesome. I'm a bun (vermicelli) junkie, so I order the standby bbq pork & imperial roll over vermicelli at every Vietnamese restaurant I go to. It's my barometer for tastiness. Pho 2000 does not disappoint. I decided to forgo the bbq pork for tofu- and I am sooooooo glad I did. Delicious pieces of marinated tofu accompanied by shredded cabbage, carrots, and mushroom. All this atop a plentiful pile of vermicelli (which, by the way, was not stuck together- as is the case in some Vietnamese restaurants). There was a little saucer of Magi sauce and not the typical fish sauce that they expect you to douse on your food. The imperial rolls were pho-bulous. Thick wrapper enveloping stuffing of ground pork, silver noodles, mushrooms and carrots. 

I'm a selfish b*tch so I didn't offer any of the rolls to my friends (hey- I only get ONE with my order). Apparently, they looked so damn good that my friend ordered an appetizer dish for himself. His rolls came out in this ginormous plate with two huge pieces of imperial rolls, vermicelli noodles, pickled carrots and cucumbers and a stack of lettuce, basil, cilantro and mint. YUM!!!

I cannot review the pho because that's not my forte, but for what it's worth, my friend said it tasted like the broth was spiked with Worcestershire Sauce (what the pho?!).

Anyhoo- check this place out. It's a nice addition to the neighborhood. I much prefer it to its surrounding competition.

That's it pho now. =)
author: A A.

description:
I may be increasing the stars soon, when I return for the bun with bbq pork and rolls!

I had a bite of my friend's, and it made me crave it sooo badly for the rest of the day! I bought some spring rolls to try to ease the craving..

Unfortunately, I had the chicken pho, which is good but not great. The meat was pretty decent, as were the noodles and the condiments were plentiful. Pretty standard. If the broth were hotter, I think I would have been happier.

Overall, good for a Vietnamese place, could be great after I get my own bun.

Oh yeah, and the portion sizes are huuuuge!! The bun seriously looks like a baby tub. Probably good for two meals. And prices are decent- about $6-8.
author: Cathy S.
